name: Der Präsident. -
text: I declare the session suspended on Thursday 23 October 2014 to be resumed.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: (2014/2920(RSP)) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for his excellent work. On 9 November, 25 years ago, courageous men and women tore down the Berlin Wall – a wall fortified by barbed wire, guarded by soldiers, a wall that arbitrarily divided families, an entire country, an entire continent. This arbitrary division of Germany and Europe was ended by a peaceful revolution on 9 November 1989. No tank rolled, no shot fell, no drop of blood flowed. That night, on 9 November 1989, a European freedom movement culminated in Berlin. Wherever this year of miracles – as the historian Timothy Garton Ash called it – in Europe in 1989, the spark of freedom was ignited. And it was not superpowers, nor were they leaders of states who wrote history, it was the peoples of Europe themselves who wrote their own history and changed the course of the world. Let us remember that workers had gathered at the Gdansk shipyards around Lech Wasa, and Solidarity' peaceful action was not guided by violence, but by John Paul II, who shouted to her: "Fight evil with good!" In Prague, the Velvet Revolution took its course when hundreds of thousands of demonstrators in Wenceslas Square shouted, "Havel on the castle!" Hungary dismantled its border facilities with Austria – a rift in the Iron Curtain through which tens of thousands fled to freedom. From Vilnius to Riga to Tallinn, a human chain stretched, and the Baltic peoples gained independence with their Singing Revolution. In Leipzig, civil rights activists carried the resistance from the church to the streets with the cry "We are the people!", again and again "We are the people!". Whether in Berlin, Leipzig, Warsaw, Prague or Bratislava, Vilnius, Tallinn or Riga: the paths to freedom and democracy were different, but they always were: they were peaceful. What they had in common were the people who demonstrated their peaceandiness and courage. It is thanks to you, ladies and gentlemen, the freedom fighters in all these countries, that democracy and freedom prevailed over injustice and dictatorship. These people wanted to get rid of the Soviet yoke. But they were also concerned with something else, a different guiding principle of 1989: they were concerned with returning to Europe. These peaceful revolutions of 1989 were logically completed only with the reunifications – first German and then European reunification by the eastward enlargement of the EU ten years ago, the return of the peoples of Central and Eastern Europe to their rightful place in the family of nations of Europe. The fact that we, ladies and gentlemen, the representatives of these peoples of Europe can work together here – for example today – is due to the courage of the people who took to the streets for their convictions. My dear colleagues. the retrospective transfigures many things. But that banners and candles, flowers and singing, prayers and keychains triumphed over tanks and rifles, over walls and borders, was not guaranteed! How easily these demonstrations could have endd in bloodshed, as in 1953 in Berlin, 1956 in Budapest, 1968 in Prague, or a few months earlier in Tiananmen Square in Beijing. We must remember this today if we are to understand the courage that men and women have had on these streets. Therefore: Nothing describes the epoch after the fall of the Berlin Wall, after the end of the separation better than the first sentence of the Berlin Declaration of 2008, which should also be our leitmotif for the future: "We are united for our happiness!"

name: Herbert Reul
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has all been rapporteur for her excellent report. The wall is gone. Twenty-five years ago, the Berlin Wall fell; for 25 years, the division in Germany, Europe and the world has been overcome. The wall fell because citizens in the GDR peacefully demonstrated for unity and justice and freedom, because they felt that the authorities were no longer strong enough to stop them. The wall fell because people, politicians in Germany, Europe and the world condemned the oppression in the GDR, the unnaturalness of the wall and believed in the unity and unification of Germany. The wall fell because systems that deprive people of freedom cannot survive. The wall fell because bankrupt systems cannot survive. The wall fell because people in Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, and Poland created conditions for this change. But it was not a miracle, nor was it a natural event, but the result of a peaceful revolution unprecedented in history, which for months had been rushing from one climax to another at a breathtaking pace. What is certain is that without the numerous civil rights movements that developed into popular movements in the late summer of 1989 and expressed their desire for change in peaceful mass demonstrations, this 9 November would not have existed in Berlin. This fall of the Berlin Wall took place in Berlin, but it is, of course, an event of European significance. How many times have I stood at the Berlin Wall as a young guy! I was very unsure if I would ever see this wall fall. And what uncertainty or even fear did I have when I went to the GDR for visits and had to go through investigative procedures about me at Friedrichstraße station, for example! This repression, this surveillance, this feeling of being monitored, perhaps lasted a few hours for me. The people of the GDR lived under such a regime for decades. All this is over, and that is why we are celebrating these days. But these 25 years since the fall of the Berlin Wall have also brought a bit of normality: it has become normal, one does not remember. Some 23 million Germans cannot even remember the fall of the Berlin Wall, because they were born after 1985.  But these young people can also learn from the fall of the Berlin Wall, just like we politicians do. However, we must ensure that young people learn from it. Politics must pursue and sustain long-term goals and not give up, as parts of the world and German politics have done on the issue of reunification. Politics must also seize opportunities, but it cannot be done without courage. Helmut Kohl seized this opportunity and seized it. We Germans are infinitely grateful for reunification.  And we Europeans have since continued to write our common history. It would not have been conceivable 25 years ago that we would commemorate together in a democratic parliament with Members from 28 Member States.  The world will continue to change. We in the European Parliament can work on these changes. And the fall of the Berlin Wall reminds us that borders can be overcome, that seemingly given conditions can change, that we must never be too sure. This also means that we must defend and fight for achievements worthy of preservation. We must defend and develop this Europe, which we have created together. The fall of the Berlin Wall has become a symbol of overcoming authoritarian systems in Eastern and Central Europe. And this memory must also be kept alive. The South African Nobel Peace Prize laureate Desmond Tutu has formulated a wise sentence with which I would like to conclude: nothing, not even the most modern weapons, not even the most brutally powerful police, no, nothing at all will be able to stop people once they are determined to win their freedom and their human right. Thank you very much!

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for the Lebanese writer Kahlil Gibran, sadness is nothing more than a wall between two gardens. As President Martin Schulz said very well in his effective speech, the fall of the Berlin Wall was an act of liberation: the victory of life against the sadness of oppression. Celebrating the anniversary today means, first and foremost, remembering the victims of that wall – the political dissidents and the many citizens whose lives were disrupted – but it also means remembering those reformers who, before others, understood the true nature of real socialism. I would like to remind you here of Alexander Dubček, whose silence last Friday celebrated the anniversary of his death. But today we also want to look to the future. The first lesson to remember is that against the resurgence of new walls and conflicts, the only antidote is Europe. Europe is a bridge that bypasses any wall. This European vocation for peace is now being called into question by the emergence of new walls, such as the new imaginary wall that divides Ukraine. We will never accept violations of fundamental principles of international law, such as that of territorial integrity, but nor do we accept that some cold war nostalgia should use the Ukrainian tragedy as a wedge between Europe and Russia. The new walls are not just in Europe. Federica Mogherini did well to make her first official visit to the Middle East. Europe, thanks to its new activism, can become a protagonist in the peace process in the region. It is only by tearing down the Gaza Wall, that is, by rebuilding acceptable living conditions in that region, that we will be able to bring peace and development. I understand the appeal of walls, including with regard to migrants, non-EU citizens. The walls evoke enclosed universes, such as the Maginot line that the French eed to protect themselves from the Germans. But then we know how the French fort ended: it fell suddenly and the historian Marc Bloch spoke of strange defeat, because the collapse had occurred first in tempers. Even today, the real European wall does not pass through borders and geographical maps. The real European front is in spirit. After the Berlin Wall, it was believed that the story was over and that it was no longer possible to imagine an alternative to unbridled capitalism. This paved the way for unbridled neoliberalism and inequalities increased. New, often parasitic, pension-based oligarchy has emerged and all too often Europe has been incapable of challenging single thinking and proposing an ambitious agenda of market reforms. Today, Europe must continue along the path of regulating finance if it is not to fall victim to the financial lobby of this great power which threatens the democratic resilience of this great construction which is Europe. It is now up to Europe to show that history is not over, but that the aspiration for equality, freedom and solidarity remains the polar star of our community.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. After 25 years, my compatriots showed once again last weekend how happy they are about reunification and how proud they are that it was possible without bloodshed. But the Germans are also grateful. Of course, the East Germans showed us at that time how to demonstrate courageously, and West German politicians also reacted decisively. I am thinking here of Helmut Kohl, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, Willy Brandt. But on this day I would also like to remind you of those who used to be courageous and more determined than we were. My personal first memory was the attempt by the construction workers in East Berlin on 17 June 1953 to shake off the communist yoke. In June 1956, the Poles rose up against the communist rulers in Poznan. In the autumn of 1956, the Hungarians rose up. The whole world held its breath at that time, leaving Hungary alone. I will never forget the names Of Imre Nagy and Pél Maléter. In 1968, the Warsaw Pact tanks from the Prague Spring made a Prague winter. Another name that I cannot forget and which has already been mentioned: Alexander Dubéek. In 1977, the Czech and Slovak blueprint for freedom was published: Charter 77. We remember with gratitude the names Pavel Kohout and Vaclav Havel. Then, in 1978, a Pole was to change everything: Karol Wojtya, the Polish cardinal who had long opposed the communist system, became Pope John Paul II. He probably contributed more to the collapse of the Berlin Wall than any German. In 1981, again in Poland, Solidarity, the model for workers' movements striving for freedom, emerged, with Lech Wasa at the helm. In 1984, another name that kept the world in suspense for weeks and gave me sleepless nights at the time: the Polish priest Jerzy Popie-uszko, a martyr of the Catholic Church and Solidarity alike. In 1989, the Czechs opened the gate to the West to many East German refugees and the Hungarians opened the fence. The name - we all know him: Gyula Horn. In all these years, however, there have also been frequent fighters for freedom of expression and the press and martyrs in the USSR itself, to whom we Germans also owe a great deal, for example Andrei Sakharov, after whom the European Parliament has named his human rights prize, or Sergei Kovalev, one of the co-founders of Memorial. Today, russia is not only a memorial, but today Russia is once again at risk of freedom of expression, freedom of the press and human rights. The Germans also know that none of this would have been possible without the steadfastness of a Ronald Reagan who shouted in front of the Brandenburg Gate in 1985: "Mister Gorbatchev, open this gate!" And you know that it would not have been possible without a Gorbachev who did just that. Or think of the Western Allies soldiers who protected us in Berlin. Here we have a group colleague, Geoffrey Van Orden, who was indeed also a British officer in 1989. Yes, the Germans are happy about the collapse of the wall, because they have been reunited. Yes, the Germans are proud that all this was possible peacefully and without bloodshed. But the Germans are also grateful to those who made this possible in the first place. (Applause)

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, at the time of the worst fraternal war in Europe to date, at the time of the Peloponnesian war, Pericles expressed the following wisdom, which still holds true to this day: the secret of happiness is freedom, but the secret of freedom is courage. And who better than all the people who have been reminded of here who have taken to the streets in Eastern Europe: 1953 in Berlin, 1956 in Budapest, 1968 in Prague.  We in the West were fortunate enough to grow up in a freedom fought by courageous men and women against fascism and National Socialism. Our friends in Eastern Europe have stood up against the second great inhuman ideology that came from Europe, communism. And I am grateful that Hans-Olaf Henkel also reminded us of those who fought against communism in the Soviet Union; I am thinking not only of Andrei Sakharov, but also of Lev Kopelev, Jelena Bonner and everyone else. Their actions were punished with camp detention, exile and exile. This courage that these people have shown is due to the courage to which we today owe our happiness to live together in freedom here. Therefore: the fall of the Berlin Wall was the result of an East German civil movement, but it was part of a European freedom movement. And how much courage it took to rebel against communism was seen on June 4 of the same year, as in Tiananmen Square – what a name! – a massacre was carried out, which the then communist leadership in East Berlin even officially welcomed! The actions of the Chinese authorities against the peaceful student uprising in Beijing were officially welcomed in East Berlin! You can imagine what it meant for people in Leipzig, Rostock, Dresden, Berlin to hear such words. The fall of the Wall, the open Brandenburg Gate – the event and the building – are therefore symbols that belong not only to the Germans; they are symbols of freedom, they remind us to defend this freedom again and again, and they are symbols of hope for people who still have to live in oppression to this day. Yes, things can turn for the better, yes, happiness and freedom can take the place of violence and wall. We want to send this symbol of hope into the world from here. It is possible – where oppression still prevails today. The message of the fall of the Wall, the message of the open Brandenburg Gate, is: Yes, there is reason for hope. Don't despair, we'll stand by you!

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Ladies and gentlemen! It is also important to say, on the occasion of 9 November 1989, our commemoration of that day, what ultimately led to a divided Europe, a divided Germany. There was a war that originated from Hitler's Germany, from fascist Germany, and which cost millions of lives. So it should not be pretended that the existence of two German states, the division of Europe, simply happened by chance. I think we should also think about it. I was born and raised in the GDR. For me, the time of the GDR was a time full of contradictions. It has been an important time for me, and I am still concerned today with why the GDR, why state socialism has failed. All the contradictions are important to me. I don't paint a black-and-white picture, no matter how much others like to do it. For me, the courage of those who did not want to let their dream of a free, solidarity-based, just society be taken away is the example. The peaceful yet powerful protests of Leipzig, but also of 4 November 1989 in Berlin on Alexanderplatz: for me, that was the way to see why the Berlin Wall fell. Without these protests, 9 November would not have existed in this form. But it is also the case on 17 January 1988, when people on the sidelines of the Rosa Luxemburg/Karl Liebknecht demonstration in Berlin rolled up a banner that read: "Freedom is always freedom of dissidents" than the GDR regime, not accepting that there are other views and that this is part of a life and a free society, arresting these demonstrators. This has been a signal to many citizens, including myself, that the future of the GDR is in disarray and that things cannot go on like this. (Call) I do not want to talk to you about who understood what in his life and when. But there is also not enough time to record the hopes and illusions with which many citizens of the GDR associated the fall of the Berlin Wall and the opening of the border between the GDR and the FrG – a border on which both camps, NATO and the Warsaw Pact, were heavily armed, a border that had a dual function on the GDR side, because it was directed inward and prevented people from leaving their own country. But there is enough time to make the following clear: 9 November is no longer just a German day of fate. At the latest with Kristallnacht, the Reichspogromnacht 1938, and the fall of the Wall in 1989, 9 November has reached a significance far beyond Europe.  For me, 9 November remains a day of remembrance and joy – of remembrance of the darkest chapter of German and European history, but also of the joy that the fall of the Berlin Wall has revealed an incomparable contradiction: one cannot build a better society in which the freedom of all, the collective, is directed against the freedom of the individual. The reverse is true. We cannot build a better society in which social freedoms, fundamental social rights without democracy and personal freedoms are fought for. However, 9 November was soon followed by a call: freedom instead of socialism. This is just as wrong as the idea that socialism would be possible without freedom.  The turning and fall of the wall were made possible primarily by the people who no longer wanted to accept that change was not possible. The Cold War was not ended by politicians. If it had been for the rulers of NATO and the Warsaw Treaty, they would still be hostile to each other in the struggle for power and influence. The current conflicts between NATO and Russia show how quickly old images are brought up again and old confrontations are revived. Political and economic structures are man-made. People can change them. Just as the rulers in the GDR and in other countries of state socialism deceived themselves when they thought that socialism in its course did not stop the ox or the donkey, so even today many who hold political, economic power in their hands and think that there is no alternative to their policies, who think, for example, that the power of the financial markets is all-encompassing, they think that the debts of the banks can always be burdened. In conclusion, the cry of 'tear down the walls', should also apply today. It should be our responsibility, it should be a European responsibility to have the walls around the European Union broken down so that all with equal rights can also live here.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which As a German MEP and as a child of the periphery of the zone, it has never been difficult for me in the last 25 years to rejoice on this day in November about what happened in Germany 25 years ago, because it immediately gave me the result in my immediate surroundings that my freedom has increased. My first trips to the East of Germany as a West German, my later trips to Poland and Central Europe – I don't want to try to explain what happiness and what great satisfaction this means for me to this day.  Germany has changed a lot since 1989 – absolutely for its good. I am glad that many people from all over the world, especially many young Europeans, have made Berlin one of the cities of their heart, and that too was palpable when you looked at what has happened in Berlin these days. "Thankfulness" has fallen as a vocabulary, and I can only underline that. For Germany must be grateful for the fact that, especially in the European Union and in the tension with the East, we were then made possible to be this united Germany again.   Since then, we have not only changed, our reputation has not only improved, we have also become insanely strong than Germans, as Germany. The fact that Germany is again a hegemonic power is not good for everyone today. I am often in southern Europe to understand the tensions, including the new tensions. Germany must continue to be grateful for its new hegemonic strength and use it for the benefit of the whole European Union. Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen from Germany, we should also reflect on this on such a day. And a second thing is also important: in 2014, which is also 100 years after the beginning of the First World War, and it is a bad thing that the war has returned to Europe this year, and the Euromaidan movement is the continuation of what the fall of the Wall still stands for as a symbol.  Ladies and gentlemen, Germany, together with the European Union, must ensure that this bloodshed in eastern Ukraine ceases. We must not allow Russia today to try to challenge the results of 1990 and 1991. Personally, I was also lucky enough to meet Mr Gorbachev, and I greatly appreciate him. But I think he should not only preach reason in Berlin, but he should provide for common sense in Russia, in Moscow. The Minsk agreement must finally be respected, and that too is something that counts on this day.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the Berlin Wall was demolished 25 years ago. It seemed that this was the end of the Cold War and the victory of democracy, the free and united world. It seemed that not only the Wall but also Cold War ideology, flushed with the blood of innocent people, collapsed. Yet 25 years after the fall of the Berlin Wall I ask myself and all of us: can we really say that the Cold War as a political concept belongs to the dump of history? What does the Russian President, Vladimir Putin, mean by saying that the break-up of the USSR was the greatest geopolitical tragedy of the 20th century? What does the military occupation of sovereign territories of Georgia and Ukraine mean? Are they not attempts to restore the Great Russia and the Soviet Union? Does that not look like building a new wall between the West and Russia? Let us celebrate the historical events in Berlin that we witnessed 25 years ago, but do not let anyone build the new walls of a Cold War today. That is our duty and responsibility as politicians.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, twenty-five years ago, the fall of the Berlin Wall showed that no barrier, physical or ideological, can stop the will of a people, the desire for freedom of a people, and gave us hope that a different Europe would finally be born. But that was not the case, unfortunately. Since 1989, the European Union and the European institutions have built a very high wall, ever higher and more dangerous. Beyond this wall are the citizens of Europe. There are 122 million European citizens at risk of poverty, there are 25 million unemployed, there are businesses that close, young people with no future, elderly people who do not even have the money to live. Ladies and gentlemen, no more façade hypocrisy! We have to decide which way to stand, whether to be brave or cowardly, whether to be with the citizens or with the Europe of banking, austerity, taxes and financial lobbies. We're at a crossroads. We can be the courageous voice that interprets the needs of its citizens or stand with the economic dictatorship of this Europe. We all have a great responsibility. We are fighting to change this Europe. Let us finally create a People's Europe.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – On 9 November we celebrated the 25th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall and the Iron Curtain that divided Western Europe from Eastern Europe. This event earmarked the beginning of a new era of freedom, democracy and cooperation in Europe. It also brought about a stronger sense of European unity towards which the EU plays an important role. In the last decade alone, we have extended these values and many Central and Eastern European countries have joined the Union in 2004, 2007 and 2013. As Europeans we must remain vigilant that we do not allow the creation of a new line of division in Europe. The fight of those who brought about the fall of the Berlin Wall was founded on their right to determine their own destiny, their aspiration towards the rule of law and respect for human dignity. The same spirit and resolve that led to the fall of the Berlin Wall must continue to guide us as we move forward in our European project.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing – the Berlin Wall was a tangible symbol of the Cold War, which has divided the people of Europe for more than 40 years. The fall of the Berlin Wall was heralded by the fall of the USSR and the unification of Germany. This weekend marks the 25th anniversary of a historically significant event for the entire democratic world. It is necessary to highlight the democratic movements in Poland, Hungary and the former Czechoslovakia, which have inspired the people of the GDR to stand up to dictatorship. It is very important that we do not forget the horrors of the Cold War and constantly commemorate the heroics of the people who fought against the unfair system, for which they paid the highest price, with their own lives. It is very sad that we have not been able to learn lessons and are failing to change things for the better, as evidenced by the situation in Ukraine, Syria and Iraq, where hundreds of innocent people are still losing their lives today and where individual states are stifling the fundamental rights of their citizens. Europe must remember precisely the ideals that led to the fall of the Berlin Wall and, with much greater intensity, to protect those who are the target of political repression and violence in several regions of the world.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – 25 years after the events in Berlin and everything that happened to them, the date was transformed by some into a symbol of the definitive triumph of capitalism and the defeat of socialism. First of all, that's what they celebrate. It follows, however, that the capitalist system, which at the turn of the 1980s/1990s presented itself as the best of the worlds in terms of democracy, human rights, economic development and social progress, not only proves incapable of solving the problems of peoples, but tends to aggravate them more and more, to the point of jeopardising the very existence of humanity. The defeats of socialism have not changed the essence of capitalism, but have made its unjust and inhuman nature more evident. The violent exploitative offensive that workers today are confronted with and which threatens the world with a social regression of civilizational dimension, the destabilization and destruction of entire countries and regions, the advance of fascism, the danger of a new war of catastrophic proportions, all this - to the anguish of some - not only belies the theses on the end of class struggle and on the death of communism, as they show that socialism is more current and necessary than ever before.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Twenty-five years ago, many people's dreams came true when the symbol of communism, the Berlin Wall, fell. The "winds of change" had already stretched the gates they thought were unbreakable. At the end of the summer, the first East German groups crossed the Hungarian border, and in September the Iron Curtain disappeared.  My generation was a watcher of the rebirth of Europe, but we believed that we would be citizens of a free and solidarity Europe. Many of the politicians of that time, however, did not admit to fighting for themselves or for a new world. Years later, it became clear that our dreams of democracy had largely not come true. We're going to hit walls again today. The political majority, with nepotism, political charades, the laundering of hundreds of billions and the constant search for scapegoats, made intelligent public discourse, real politics impossible. After the economic shock of the regime change, sustainable economic policies could not be achieved, with the disintegration of solidarity, millions sank into hopeless poverty, lost their livelihoods, became victims of punitive social policy - questioning the social contract itself. Yet we must celebrate November 9th with pride, and we Hungarians still feel our souls warm after decades. Even if there have been setbacks, it's now our responsibility to improve things. We know it's all part of a process, and we believe there's hope. The hope is that, as a member of a European value-making community, we can collectively make what seems to be lost come true.

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE)
text: in writing. – In 1988 I had a chance to visit East Germany with my family. I was 11 at the time. Since Estonia was still part of the Soviet Union, visiting East Germany was a big step forward. I remember that we visited different sights and at the Brandenburg gate, my father told my brother and me ‘Breathe in, it is the air of freedom that comes from the other side of the wall’. In 2014, we take freedom for granted but we should not. Freedom is precious and it is a pity that we only understand its value when it is gone. I am grateful that I come from a generation who remembers the time when we were not free and who has been able to witness the immense change we have gone through.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece has withdrawn and condemns the anti-communist fiesta on the Berlin Wall, which aims to slander socialism, to counterfeit history and to highlight the exploitative system as the only choice of peoples. Anti-communism goes hand in hand with the fierce anti-grassroots attack by the EU, civil governments and monopolies against the peoples in all member states. In spite of its counterfeiters, the historical truth is relentless: The creation of two German states was a conscious choice of the imperialists. The war between the US-NATO imperialists and their allies against socialism, open subversion and provocations against the socialist state of the G.O.P. imposed the construction of the Berlin Wall. The festivals of the bourgeois cannot erase from historical memory the unprecedented conquests of workers in the GLD, the USSR and the other countries of socialist construction. Capitalism erects daily walls for the life and rights of workers condemning them to live in poverty, relative and utter impoverishment, bloodshed and war. The people will turn the wheel of history forward. In socialism-communism that will rid humanity of the disgrace of human exploitation by man, highlighting the working owners of the wealth they produce.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. - Twenty-five years have passed since the historic event, which marked a turning point, a new beginning and a European future for many member states. Human courage has succeeded in overriding blocks of concrete and triggering processes that many citizens, not only German citizens, can be proud of.  Unfortunately, today we are witnessing some new "walls" that are not exclusively concrete, but at least as efficiently move many people away from their fundamental rights. The Berlin Wall serves as a symbol of breaking down barriers among people who have united their rights, but it should also be a reminder and inspiration to all who are able to decide that fundamental human rights are no longer threatened by any physical, economic or security divides.  Twenty-five years after the demolition of the Berlin Wall and the promise of freedom for millions of people, we must not let some new "walls" hold new millions trapped in unmaid and hopeless.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. – The fall of the Berlin Wall on 9 November 1989 ended the block division in Europe and allowed German reunification. The democratic transition in Central and Eastern Europe began, and the lives of today's generations have been changed from the root. There is a wide range of political and sociological interpretations of the causes, consequences and significance of the fall of the Wall and the collapse of communism.  The most important aspect is that the process towards the realization of freedom and democracy dreamed up by the peoples of Central and Eastern Europe, which by acquiring historical circumstances were part of the former communist bloc, was initiated. It also opened the way for the enlargement of the European Union. In 2013, Croatia also became part of the continental political project. Membership in the European family was achieved after demanding reforms, but primarily thanks to the sacrifice of Croatian defenders in the Homeland War.  These days also marks the 23rd anniversary of the fall of Vukovar - the city of symbols of Croatian freedom. Bearing in mind that in 2014 we also remember the 100th anniversary of the beginning of The First World War and the 75th anniversary of the beginning of World War II, which brought humanity the greatest tragedies, it is extremely important to stop the hybrid aggression against Ukraine that breaks down the fundamental values of global order and international law. The creation of new frozen conflicts could lead to divisions that take Europe back to the time before 1989.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. – The fall of the Berlin Wall 25 years ago meant optimism for me then a young man and my entire generation. New opportunities such as public appearance and freedom of movement and expression have had an extremely stimulating effect on the whole of Europe. The fall of the Berlin Wall leads to the construction and restoration of democracies in eastern and southeastern Europe, which strongly opens the space for the development of civil society, economy and citizenship.  Although Yugoslavia was not behind the Iron Curtain, the Cold War was its reality. As a buffer zone between east and west, locally it felt ubiquitous global threats. In today's Europe, is anyone still thinking about building atomic shelters? For us, it was everyday life. Then and today, in the region and in the world, there are constantly forces that want to build walls. It is not only about physical walls, but also about various energy, cultural and financial walls of blackmail.  Sometimes it seems easier to build walls than to build the involvement of societies. The European Union has great potential and strength to prevent conflicts in its neighbourhood and to connect states and societies at all levels. The memory of this important event of the demolition of the Berlin Wall should be an example and impetus to all generations that freedom is the right of every individual not only in our Community but throughout the world.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: in writing – The fall of the Berlin Wall was one of the greatest milestones of the last century. It was proof that central planning and totalitarian restrictions on freedom do not work and that the market and freedom are much more effective. Unfortunately, a large number of people have forgotten these principles or never even related to them. That is also why, today, more and more people want to tackle the crisis by restricting the market more. However, the cause of the current crisis is not a market failure, but, as in 1989, it is excessive central planning. The solution today, as then, is more market and more freedom. In the 25 years since the fall of the Berlin Wall, the world has changed significantly, but economic principles remain the same. And if anyone thinks that greater state intervention benefits, there is no better counter-argument than the differences in living wage between the so-called "red line". Eastern blocs and Western countries. That is why, even after a quarter of a century, we must not forget the fall of the Berlin Wall and, above all, the legacy that symbolises this fall.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing – The fall of the Berlin Wall is a fundamental historical event for the whole of Europe. Its anniversary commemorates the defining moments of our common history – the tearing down of the Iron Curtain, which has divided the continent for decades. The end of the Cold War was brought about 25 years ago by human courage in the form of the fall of the Berlin Wall in Germany, the Solidarity movement in Poland or the Velvet Revolution in czechoslovakia at the time. 1989 brought a series of events that are now key symbols of Europe's unification. Without them, the European Union could not exist in its present form. Celebrating a quarter of a century is proof that the European project is unique and still up-to-date, and only its continuation will bring about a real and final deletion of the Iron Curtain from the mental map.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – With the fall of the Berlin Wall, the strongest symbol of the dissolution of the Eastern Bloc, the world has radically changed, but also the world public's view of communism and the communist system, and preconditions have been created for the democratisation and removal of iron curtains from north to south of Europe. Since I come from Croatia, which has been under communism for 45 years, I sympathize and understand the fate of people who lived under the auspices of this totalitarian system throughout Central and Eastern Europe.  In the following years, the collapse of the Soviet Union and SFR Yugoslavia occurred, and many peoples gained independence, while the 1989 revolutions marked a shift in the balance of powers as well as the beginning of the post-communist era and democracy. In most new countries, governments are engaged in establishing a stable market economy, and Croatia at the same time faces war and aggression, while many of the fallen defenders have built their lives into the foundations of modern Croatia.  It is a pity that even today there are politicians who view this authoritarian system with nostalgia. Referring to the European Parliament's resolutions on the need for international condemnation of the crimes of totalitarian communist regimes, I urge the Commission to insist on condemning those who still glorify and highlight symbols of totalitarian systems, including communism, taking into account the evil and injustice that the system has brought to citizens across Europe and beyond.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: In writing. 25 years have already passed since the fall of the Wall, which separated Europe in two. Everything seems to have gone so fast and the continent, despite the current economic crisis, seems to have found a modus vivendi that has no other equal in the world. Yet we must bear in mind that this peace is fragile. There is no shortage of examples of "stable" countries that have fallen into collective madness, history is there to remind us. This memory must be all the stronger as the current international context is sensitive. Therefore, let us continue to focus on dialogue without denying ourselves. Indeed, the temptation of totalitarianism is never far away and renunciation is the best way to achieve it. That is why, even if peace is an obvious achievement for the younger European generations, it must never be put in the balance of any negotiation. Freedom is not negotiable. Part of Europe has suffered too much, but, paradoxically of history, it is this same lack of freedom that has helped Europe to shape itself.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: I am pleased to welcome six members of a delegation of high-ranking officials from the Brazilian Congress, led by the Director-General of the Chamber of Deputies, Mr Sérgio Sampaio Contreiras de Almeida, to the official gallery. Welcome, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The final draft of the agenda for this part-session, as defined in the Conference of Presidents in accordance with Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure, has been distributed. With regard to this draft, I would like to propose the following to you: Wednesday: I have proposed to you, in agreement with President Juncker, that, in the light of the ongoing debates and after today's meeting of the College of Commissioners, Mr Juncker and I have agreed that I propose that Mr Juncker make a statement at the beginning of our meeting, followed by a round of group chairmen. I would ask you to include this item as the first item on the agenda. If you agree with this – And I do not see any contradiction – then we could see the order of business in this way. In addition to this point, I must make another statement: the debate on the Statement by the Council and the Commission on the fight against tax avoidance will then be put on the agenda after the election of the Vice-President. I propose that you amend the title of the joint debate on the amendment of Protocol 31 to the EEA Agreement as follows: 'Amendments to agreements with EEA countries and Switzerland'. A debate on a Commission statement on the European Union's position in the EU-Switzerland Joint Committee on the amendment of the Agreement on the Coordination of Social Security Systems will be added to this joint debate. In addition, in the light of these debates, the sitting will be extended until 11.30 p.m. today. Thursday: The Hautala report on the request for the waiver of Ana Gomes' immunity will be included directly in voting time on Thursday.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI). -
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the European Mr Dear colleagues, The fact that the President-elect of the European Commission, Mr Juncker, is suspected of serious economic abuses, and that makes the whole press loud, is a subject of such gravity that at least spontaneous debate on the part of the President should be up to it. You celebrated for an hour that communism was over, democracy had begun... (Interjection from the floor: 'No debate! no debate!') Why do you say no debate? You were celebrating the end of Communism for an hour and the beginning of democracy, so why do you not show us what is the difference between Communism and democracy?

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Thank you very much. (The order of business has therefore been adopted.)

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on a statement by the President of the Commission (2014/2945(RSP)."

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Commission President. Mr President, given the circumstances, given the questions, given the doubts that may have crossed some minds, I find it normal, without having been summoned by your Parliament, to appear before you this afternoon at the first possible parliamentary occasion. I was Prime Minister of Luxembourg, you knew that, and I am President of the Commission, you know that. I am not speaking as a former Prime Minister of the Grand Duchy, but as President of the Commission, which has been a long time in his life as Prime Minister of Luxembourg. There would be a lot to say, but I would like to focus on the substance of the problem.  The problem we are discussing is early tax rulings, which in "English" are called tax rulings. The Commission has repeatedly confirmed that advance tax rulings are in line with EU law, provided that the same rules apply in the same circumstances to all businesses without discrimination. This is what Luxembourg's tax law says and that is what the administrative practices of that country apply to. The tax law has always been respected and no illegal practice is known to me. But there has probably been, at least I get the impression, an excess of tax engineering in Luxembourg, as in other countries. You should know that early tax decisions exist, and you know, in 22 european Union countries. There is therefore no Luxembourg specificity. We are facing an almost ecumenical phenomenon in Europe and, moreover, also beyond the limits of the European Union. How is it possible that such overinterpretation could take place? This is possible because there is an interaction between different or different national laws as to their nature and normative scope. The fact that there are divergent normative tax rules, the fact that they are applied in several European Union countries, is nothing more than the result of the logic of non-harmonisation or insufficient tax harmonisation in Europe. Yes, we are dealing with the consequences of non-harmonisation or insufficient tax harmonisation in Europe. We - the Commission, the Council - have reacted to this lack of pre-standards that can be reconciled with each other. I myself , there are many witnesses in this room , have worked, whenever Luxembourg or I chair the Council of Ministers, to advance tax harmonisation. I have often told you - and you will laugh today as you laughed at the time - that every time a progress on tax harmonisation has been made in Europe, it is under the Luxembourg presidency. I would remind you that in 1991 we harmonized VAT rates and excise rates. In the face of the disparity in national tax standards, we have adopted a code of conduct against unfair tax competition, which has been implemented and which, in many countries, has led to significant legislative changes, and so on. We discussed this issue within the College this morning. There is an urgent need for action, since many of our citizens do not understand the difference between cleaning up our public finances and imposing businesses and corporations in a fair way, since the impression that emerges from this debate is that fiscal injustice is insufficiently combated in Europe. I made a commitment to you to act on that. I said that during the election campaign and during our debates, when not everyone was the same focus on demanding further tax harmonisation. Tax harmonisation does not mean the end of tax competition: it aims to establish fairer rules between the different Member States of the European Union. We discussed this this morning in the College, and I proposed to my colleagues what I said to you when you did me the honour of electing me President of the Commission, namely that the Commission's ambition is to do everything possible to ensure that Europe, in tax matters, has the same tax base, since in many cases in many cases , advance tax decisions are possible because our plates (gemeinsame Bemessungsgrundlagen) are not in place. We'll do it. The Council is also dealing with a proposal for a directive to this effect and we will do everything we can to encourage it to adopt this directive and get it to adopt it as soon as possible. In the meantime, Commissioner Moscovici will use all the instruments that are available to him today to achieve the same goal. We recently adopted the first part of the mother-subsidiary directive, which puts an end to another source of prolonged disparities and which consists of abolishing the architectural possibility that the different legal characterization of so-called hybrid loans made available to tax administrations. This directive will come into force on 1 January 2015 and will eliminate whole sections of the constructibility of early tax rulings. To date, all Member States of the European Union have abolished bank secrecy. This was not the case several years ago. I proposed to the Commission this morning, and the College unanimously accepted it, that from now on we should ensure, after a review of the existing arrangements and an initiative taken by Commissioner Moscovici, to carry out an automatic exchange of information on early decisions. Commissioner Moscovici and I will propose, from tomorrow, in Australia, to extend the principle of automatic exchange of information on early decisions to the whole of the G20. One of the priorities I mentioned before you was the ambition that was, and remains, ours to fight fraud and tax evasion effectively. There are a number of investigations that have been launched by the Commission into different Member States, including the country I know best. I do not see and understand the comments on this, and I do not understand why there is an attempt to uncover at all costs a conflict of interest for the President of the Commission when it comes to examining these investigations within the Commission. The Commissioner in charge of competition has a wide range of autonomy and I do not intend to interfere in her decision-making process. If I did so, even if I did not have the slightest intention, I would lose all authority in the Commission. If a Commissioner intervened in a state matter in a violent, unreasonable, thoughtless manner in such a decision-making process, the Commission on this point would no longer be able to function. The Commissioner of Competition is free of her actions and movements. I do not understand why I read, and even sometimes I hear, that this is a Juncker v Juncker case. Has there ever been any talk of a Timmermans case against Timmermans because the Netherlands is under investigation? Will tomorrow, when France is the subject of a Commission investigation, will we talk about a Moscovici case against Moscovici? You will discover Commissioner Moscovici in all the fullness of his talents shortly. I repeat that the Commission will do its job. There is an investigation against the country I know best, launched with my agreement by the previous Commission. President Barroso had asked me, as had Joaquin Almunia, if I would rather wait for the arrival of the new Commission. I said, "Do what you have to do." And that's what they did. On all these points, we want to act. We will act resolutely and with ambition. I have a duty of abstention with regard to investigations against the country I know best, but I also have a duty to act, which is to advance taxation and tax harmonisation in Europe. Don't doubt it, I will. But to do that, I need your trust. Without your trust, nothing is possible.

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has We are certainly discussing an important issue here today that is moving the citizens. Citizens pay taxes, our small and medium-sized enterprises pay taxes and read in the newspapers that large corporations are sometimes squeezing around their tax obligations. It is a big question of justice, and that is why it is important to discuss this here today. But, ladies and gentlemen, when I consider the powder vapour of the last few days, I would like to ask myself the question: have we all been surprised by a new subject? Ladies and gentlemen, even before the European parliament elections, we took a decision in principle on how we deal with tax justice in Europe. The Commission took decisions on this in 2012. So today we are not discussing a new issue that has suddenly appeared. Some clarifications are needed. Firstly, is it a Luxembourg case? Of course, it is also a Luxembourg case, and that must be examined. But God knows it is not a Luxembourg-only case. We have a long tradition in Belgium of the rich settling better in Belgium because there are better tax rates there. The Netherlands is known for being particularly attractive to foundations. I come from the Austrian border region of Germany and I also know how many of our top earners are leaving for Austria. It is nothing, ladies and gentlemen, as far as Luxembourg is concerned.  The second observation I would like to make is: is there a breach of the law? Ladies and gentlemen, after the Treaty of Lisbon – and it is precisely the side that is strongly standing up for the nation states here in Parliament who will fight for it – tax law remains national. It must therefore be said that this is not a breach of the law, it is an interpretation of the respective national facts, competition and, in some cases, unhealthy competition from tax systems. That is behind it! This is not a breach of the law in the European Union! The third thing that needs to be clarified is the question of procedure. I am grateful to Jean-Claude Juncker for making it clear today that he will withdraw from the procedure. He released it and said: of course the Commission must investigate. But he will withdraw. And Mrs Vestager confirmed yesterday in the ECON Committee that there was not even a conversation between her and Jean-Claude Juncker. It will investigate independently, and this will also be done with the blessing of Jean-Claude Juncker. These clarifications are necessary. Ladies and gentlemen, we now come to the political part of the debate, to the question of trying to shake the integrity and also the credibility of Jean-Claude Juncker. Ladies and gentlemen, four days before we voted on Jean-Claude Juncker in the European Parliament, the Financial Times published a very large article on this very issue. So it's nothing new. And although this article was in the newspapers, I voted with complete conviction for Jean-Claude Juncker, because I trust him that he will solve the problems that are on the table. On the whole group, I would like to say that we trust Jean Claude Juncker to tackle and resolve the issues that are on the table for the citizens of Europe. The fifth thing I want to make clear is that do you know what annoys me the most in the whole discussion? That we are once again giving the citizens the impression that the European level has failed on this issue. We are once again playing the ball between Parliament and the Commission. Who didn't get the theme baked? The fact is, ladies and gentlemen, that it is the Member States that are failing. The Council is not present for this discussion. The Member States are failing. How long did it take for the Finance Ministers to finally be able to at least get a grip on tax evasion by private individuals, and we now get automated data exchange? It took decades! Billions of taxpayers' money was evaded because the Member States were unable to deliver. I hope that this time we will be able to get to the bottom of it more quickly, that we will make progress and put an end to tax evaders and stop the initiative accordingly. These are mistakes by the Member States and not by the European level! We would have been active and we were active. Mr President, I would like to end by saying that the future is important. How do we solve the issue? And here Jean-Claude Juncker addressed the right points: we need Transparency in the rulings, as has been indicated. We need initiative to unify the tax base, and we need global initiatives at the G20. Jean-Claude Juncker has our support in this.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Juncker, thank you first of all for being here in Parliament. Your presence is an act of sensitivity and responsibility, and we Democratic Socialists sincerely appreciate it. I would like to say straight away that the first feeling you get when you read about the cunning of multinationals to pay less tax is still one of indignation, even when one knows it. Indignation at those companies that make billions in profits and do not pay taxes in the countries where those profits are made. Indignation at those Member States that enter into confidential negotiations with multinationals and are complicit in the attempt. Look at the fact that, as Mr Juncker has said, this is not just a matter for a few Member States. It is a European and global phenomenon. And is it shameful that, while some states – remember Greece? – horse care was imposed in the name of austerity, somewhere else, also in Europe, multinational companies were evading billions of euros from the public purse by not paying taxes. And the worst thing, the most shameful thing, which Mr Juncker himself recalled with great honesty, is that those multinationals, in most cases, avoided taxes without breaking any European laws or regulations. We must no longer allow this! If there is one thing that should unite this House, it is the tenacious and strong will to no longer allow a phenomenon to happen by changing legislation, because we need to change the legislation so that this phenomenon is eradicated. Many of the companies accused of tax avoidance are the same companies that then queue to obtain funding and support from the Member States. The philosophy is to draw on the state when it suits, but to privatise profits. This is the logic of rapacious capitalism, which has little to do with the thousands of small and medium-sized enterprises that are measured on the market every day, without cunning, and which constitute the real marrow, the backbone and the salvation of the European economy. But denunciation is not enough, let us move on to the proposals. Mr Juncker, when the European Commission took office, even when he won our confidence, made commitments, which he reiterated this afternoon. We, as the Group of the Party of European Socialists and Democrats, are calling for a precise timetable for implementing these commitments, and we also add some of our proposals. Fiscal harmonization is all well and good, but we need a stronger boost to the political, social and economic integration of Europe. We also propose to the Commission three measures which come from the report by one of our former colleagues, Mojca Kleva Kekuš, which was adopted by a large majority in this Parliament. First proposal: the Commission could and should adopt a clear definition of a tax haven, which is extensive and also takes account of dubious practices such as tax rulings. The second proposal is that those who are smart must pay. The competent authorities must suspend or revoke the banking licences of financial institutions that help organise fraud. At the same time, companies that lend themselves to these practices must be excluded from European funds, because it is not acceptable to try to escape tax and then beat cash. Thirdly, we want financial information to be reported country by country in the budgets of multinationals. It is right that people should know where multinationals make the profits because it is in that country that they have to pay taxes. I repeat: taxes are paid in the country where they make the profits. On these commitments we will heel the Juncker Commission, we will support it in this way. The Member States are essential, but the Commission makes its proposals. Parliament will help the Commission to defeat those Member States and to show the European public that the responsibility for the fact that the reform process is not moving forward lies with the Member States, not with Parliament, not with the European Commission. Let us go on like this. We do not accept weakening the newly elected European Commission and President Juncker. That would be a gift to Euroscepticism, to Europhobia. It would be a gift to inaction, because our citizens are waiting for answers and we can have the answers with a strong and authoritative Commission and with a President legitimised by the strong will to resolve and reform this sector.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Ladies and gentlemen! There are no blue cards in this debate. That is why I do not allow them.

name: Kay Swinburne
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, todayʼs discussion has been precipitated by LuxLeaks and the allegations in the press last week. Firstly let me thank the President of the Commission Mr Juncker for attending today, but with all due respect it is Commissioner Vestager who should be here today discussing these matters. She is leading the Commission investigation into tax schemes in Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Ireland and several other EU countries. As a quasi-judicial investigation, I believe we should await its outcome before rushing to judgments or holding a witch-hunt. The ECR was pleased to hear Commissioner Vestager yesterday tell the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) that she would include the leaked information in her investigation and that she would widen the scope of the investigation if it proved necessary. Although as there has been some confusion today on whether there will actually now be an investigation, a reassurance from the Commission is necessary that this is going to be the case.  The ECR Group has long argued for further action at national, EU and global level to tackle tax evasion, tax fraud and, indeed, aggressive tax avoidance. People are frankly not willing to accept companies that go out of their way to avoid paying what they legitimately owe. Global country-by-country reporting by companies of their sales and profit is long overdue. Although it is a global problem, the EU can play a meaningful role in this field. At Commissioner Vestagerʼs hearing I specifically asked her what she was going to do to close the ʽdouble Irishʼ tax loophole as it may constitute state aid. She confirmed last month, before all these allegations, that it was firmly on her agenda within the framework of EU competition law. However, let us not forget that tax is a Member State issue. For the EU to play a role does not require more EU legislation or centralisation of powers, nor does it need tax harmonisation. Tax competition is of utmost importance in the EU and it encourages us to remain competitive globally. The solution lies in proper enforcement of existing national and EU systems and through greater transparency and greater international cooperation in tax matters through the G8 and G20 level.  I am proud to say that it was my Prime Minister during the UKʼs Presidency of the G8 last year who led these discussions on reporting and tax transparency, and it will be discussed again in Brisbane next week. If Commissioner Vestagerʼs investigation raises questions that need to be answered, then they must be answered here in this Chamber. They cannot be avoided.  Clearly this investigation needs to have the trust of the public. They need to know that whatever the Commission concludes is the result of an independent, thorough and public proper inquiry. We should base our actions and debates not on leaks and not on part of the picture, but on a full, independent assessment by our own competition authority that reveals all the facts.  The ECR calls on Commissioner Vestager to deliver her investigation as quickly as is feasible but also asks for reassurance today on the independence, the scope and the procedure for keeping this Parliament informed.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, may I say something as a point of order outside my speaking time? No? OK. I am wondering where Mr Farage is today in this debate. He was a specialist in offshore tax schemes in the Isle of Man – he is a specialist and he is not here today! Where is he?  (Applause) We have a specialist there. Mr Juncker can be the specialist at the government level but Mr Farage is a specialist at the private level, so we have somebody who really knows how things work. It is not possible to have him but … (The President reminded the speaker that this was included in his speaking time) Yes, Mr President, you can count my 40 seconds and let us hope that he comes back.  I have three things to say to Mr Juncker and the first is that we now have an investigation by the Commission. Let us be honest about it. It has to be a serious investigation and not just about three special cases in three countries. It has to be about practices in general. The investigation has to be about whether this is in accordance with EU legislation. The consequences of that are very clear. If this is in accordance with EU legislation, there is no problem. Admittedly, if there is no problem then there is a problem with EU legislation, and we have to work on the basis of proposals by the Commission, but if it is in accordance with EU legislation, then OK. Alternatively, if it is not in accordance with EU legislation then, Mr Juncker, you know you have a problem and we have to discuss that together and accept the consequences.  That is my first point. Let us have this investigation but my request is for an investigation before the end of the year. It is impossible for the European Union to continue with a shadow hanging over the Commission for six months now. We already have one lame duck in Washington, it is not necessary to make a lame duck here in Europe right now, so my request is that Ms Vestager be asked to conclude this investigation before the end of the year. My second point is that we need to have a special committee in this Parliament too. Yesterday the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) discussed this and I think there is common ground between all the groups that we should have a special committee. Because this is not only a question of the executive, of the Commission having to look into the matters of the Member States, it is also our task as a European Parliament to have a special committee and to look into these practices. My request to the two big groups, and the other groups, is to support this special committee at the Conference of Presidents. My third point relates to the content. I think it was fantastic how Ms Swinburne tried to explain that it is not necessary to have more Europe. If there is one topic now where we need more Europe, we have it here on the table, and it is a clear indication that what you are saying does not make any sense. How do you avoid these practices if not at European level – with a convergence code at the European level, with European tax compliance legislation at the European level? That is my point to you, Mr Juncker. You have spoken about two decisions taken by the College this morning and I am in favour of that exchange of information. In fact I want to ask you two things, one on European tax compliance legislation – because we need that if we want to enforce a number of practices – and the other about the convergence code.  I do not agree by saying, like Mr Pittella, that we have to harmonise everything. Harmonise everything at what level? Not at the Belgian level, I hope, (inaudible words off microphone), that is completely crazy, not at the French level as regards some taxation. I think we need a balance between, on the one side, enforceable measures and, on the other side, room for manoeuvre for the Member States based on the convergence code. My call to you is to come forward with these proposals. There is a shadow – and you must know that, Jean-Claude – hanging over the Commission. You know that better than anyone because you have enough experience to know that, and we have to remove it as fast as possible. That is the reason why I ask you to speed up the investigation on the one hand, and to come forward with additional proposals on the other.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, I have a point of order. You allowed Mr Verhofstadt additional speaking time to criticise a Member of the European Parliament who is not even here. This is supposed to have been, and he claims this to have been, a point of order. Now a point of order under Rule 186 should be considered as a point of order, not granting additional speaking time to somebody to make a personal attack in a way which would not be accepted in any sensible parliamentary democracy anywhere in the world. (Applause from the EFDD Group)

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Mr Juncker, you are making it very difficult for us and for me personally, because I do not have the slightest desire to intervene in any way, for example, in the dispute between the German Federal Government and you. I do not like the heme that was felt in some media, not all of them in the Federal Republic of Germany. I don't think it's good. However, I think that the path that you have now proposed, which is based in principle on two axes or two pillars – to say that I am speaking here as President of the Commission and not as a former Prime Minister of Luxembourg, nor as a former Minister for Finance – is very difficult to understand. Because you are here as a person, you are not a divided person, you are the President of the Commission here for us.  You have started with a biography, and just as I have to justify my biography all the time, regardless of the options, for my biography, you too must justify and explain why you have used all the means – certainly from a legal point of view – to ultimately take advantage of tax advantages for your own country. If that is nothing more than that national interests within the European Union's internal market are ultimately put first in the foreground in order to bring businesses to Luxembourg, in order to ultimately divert much-needed taxpayers' money to public budgets, if this is not a position that says that, in the end, I do not care – or not only to you, but many others, it has been tolerated by many governments, it is not just your problem – that we have less money to ultimately fight poverty and social exclusion, to create jobs, to do many other things that are urgently needed and what the citizens expect, but to look first and foremost at the fact that as many people as possible come to their own country then I know no more. that is what we are actually talking about! I expect you to comment on this very much! Secondly, I would like to ask briefly whether it is true that you can confirm that the Commission's cooperation with Luxembourg has improved from the moment you were no longer Prime Minister. That was the answer we heard yesterday.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR). -
text: Mr. President! That is what the Rules of Procedure are all about, Mr Schulz. I would like to know from you, on the basis of which Rule of the Rules of Procedure you simply do not take note of and, secondly, on what basis of the Rules of Procedure do you not even reply to points of order? Is this a hollow right of Members, or does that right have any meaning?  (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Madam President, thank you very well Points of order must be justified on the basis of the relevant Rule. The previous point of order, to which you apparently referred, had no basis, was not substantiated, no reference was made to any Rule of these Rules, but merely stated that Mr Verhofstadt had approached a Member who was not present. That is permissible under our Rules of Procedure. That's why I didn't have to intervene. I do not know now what the violation of the Rules of Procedure is. If a group chairman finds that a Member is not present, that is perhaps more the problem of the absent Member.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Mr Juncker, I have not been surprised, but I must confess that I remain revolted every day to see how the richest taxpayers manage to evade tax, often legally, with the complicity of states in a Europe which is a rich continent. This fiscal injustice is for us a fundamental break from the social contract in Europe. Worse still, it is, I think, a breach of trust, the confidence of our fellow citizens in the capacity of their institutions and in the will of their elected representatives to defend the public interest. You know, self-employed people, unemployed workers, social beneficiaries are often blamed. But it is often - and LuxLeaks reminds us - at the top of the income and wealth ladder that the worst profiteers of the system are, not at the bottom. You are, of course, not alone, Mr Juncker. I remember that it is the very liberal Mark Rutte and his counterpart, the not very socialist Jeroen Dijsselbloem, who are at the helm of a tax haven - I am obviously talking about the Netherlands - which is no less raucous than the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, which you had the honour of leading. I am not talking about all these tax arrangements that many European states, including my own, have hidden in their tax code, all of which are tax arrangements that make their state a tax haven. Mr Juncker, as you said, the central issue is harmonisation. It is time for the European states to stop fighting a tax war whose only beneficiaries are big business and big heritage, and the victims, the health of our public finances and through them, the health and well-being of all our fellow citizens. It is this tax war that must be ended by tax harmonisation. You said that you were not going to interfere in the ongoing investigation. I ask you to intervene. I ask you to give Mrs Vestager all the means she needs to expand and deepen this investigation in order to put a definitive end to these tax quibbles of which we are all victims.

name: Paul Nuttall
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, it seems from Mr Juncker’s opening remarks that he is blaming everybody else and not himself and in a desperate effort to throw everybody off the scent he is calling for more EU tax harmonisation. Rubbish, I say. Let us get to the rub of it. The definition of hypocrisy in the Oxford English Dictionary is the practice of claiming to have higher standards or more noble beliefs than is the case, and I do not think anyone in this Chamber could disagree with me today when I say that this perfectly sums up the position of the President of the European Commission here today. When Mr Juncker was campaigning for the post, he stood on a platform of stamping out aggressive tax avoidance by multinational corporations across the European Union, yet it is now clear from recent revelations that he had not practised what he was preaching. Under his tenure, Luxembourg was a magical fairyland for multinational corporations where tax rates of as little as 1% were paid on profits. Mr Juncker, you said that this was within the rules, but equally I say it is morally bankrupt. When asked by one of my UKIP colleagues back in July how you could justify advocating tax standardisation across the European Union whilst overseeing a tax haven in Luxembourg, you simply dodged the question and now we know why. Could this possibly be a case of history repeating itself, because Mr Juncker’s predecessor as Prime Minister of Luxembourg, Mr Jacques Santer, was forced to resign as President of the Commission under a cloud of corruption back in 1999? I suppose that, if you think about it in those terms, Mr Juncker’s appointment can be summed up by Albert Einstein’s theory of insanity, which is doing the same thing over and over again and expecting a different result. I would like to finish by asking this Chamber why the people of Europe are increasingly sceptical about the European Union. Allow me to tell you with one simple sentence: it is because it is always a case of ‘do as I say and not as I do’, and therefore I believe, Mr Juncker, you have two options. One is to honourably resign or, two, at least stand down while an independent investigation takes place. (Applause from the EFDD Group)

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI). -
text: Mr President. Mr Juncker, I do not know if you are personally guilty, having to resign from your government after a scandal affecting the special services, but what I do know is that you have been for a very long time, not only Prime Minister, but Minister of Economy and Finance, and that you have practiced an extraordinarily aggressive policy towards, precisely , from your European neighbours. With a consummate art, I must say, of the distribution, you use the scandal that affects you to ask us to increase your skills. But, Mr Juncker, we do not need to harmonize - in reality to unify - tax laws. All that is needed is a very simple rule that must be implemented, under which multinational companies will be taxed in each Member State because of the turnover or profits they make there. This will be enough to put an end to the fictitious situation that is yours. I am well aware that, even on the socialist benches, Mrs Pervenche Berès approves of your appointment by saying that you may be a godfather (a mafia godfather - it is Mrs Berès who speaks) repented. I am well accounted that Napoleon and, after him, King Louis XVIII appointed the convict and former convict Vidocq chief of police, and he performed his duties in an extremely effective manner. Recognize, however, that according to this logic, it is as if the former murderer of single women, Landru, was appointed Minister of The Status of Women. It's still a little too much to ask. We are told of an investigation, but the investigation will be done by your services. I agree with what Mr Verhofstadt said about the need for an independent investigation. I do not throw you the first stone, as Christ did not want to do to the adulterous woman, for those who are guilty here should leave first. They are the very people who voted for the free movement of capital, without any control, for the benefit of multinationals.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Commission President. Mr President, I understand that everyone agrees that the problem is not just Luxembourg. The answer cannot therefore be exclusively Luxembourgish.
