In fact, I am no longer in charge of this country, and for the rest, I do not apologize for what I have been able to do for my country. I have never given instructions on a particular tax file. Luxembourg's finance ministers have no instructions to give to the tax authorities. Just as the tax authority does not have to report to the Minister of Finance. Be aware that there are other countries where finance ministers make decisions on early tax decisions. This is not the case in my country. I'm not saying it to relieve myself of my responsibilities. Politically, I am obviously responsible for everything that is done by the tax administration or any other Luxembourg administration. But you have to know the rules. What I have meant before you, as I have said in my time in the various parliamentary groups, during the various televised debates, in the debate we had in plenary, is that the Commission I have the honour of chairing will fight against tax evasion and tax evasion. Why can tax evasion and tax evasion exist? Because we have before us an arsenal of disparate national rules, which facilitates tax evasion by involving tax administrations that must enforce the laws as they are. If they are disparate, and if you organize, with a formidable talent for tax engineering, this interaction between the different national rules, you come to the result that unfortunately we have arrived at, which does not correspond to the requirements for tax fairness. I'll do it. Those who have been with me for a long time, who have been with me, know what my deep convictions are on this point. Do not question the ardour of my convictions on these points. Don't describe me as the great friend of great capital. This must have been a lot of fun in the upper floors of Luxembourg and European companies. Big capital has better friends in this house than I do, believe me. Mr Verhofstadt, I am not very impressed by the fact that you are asking for my resignation, because I do not owe my position to your support. You are consistent on that. You voted against me. It seems to me quite normal that you should ask for my resignation in every respect. Mr. Gollnisch, you need to know before you speak. First, I have never been minister of the economy. I have always had ministers of the economy either liberal or socialist, because I governed with the socialists and the liberals. Secondly, I have not resigned as Prime Minister of Luxembourg. We held early elections, there was no resignation from me. In light of these initial errors, you will allow me not to answer your other questions, which in reality were not questions, but simple insults, to which I will not answer. Frau Zimmer, Sie besch-ftigen sich mit meiner Biografie. Das ist ein weites Feld, wenn Sie dies tun. Ich habe yesterday als Kommissionspresident geredet. Es ist doch wohl die Erwartungshaltung des Parlamentes, dass ich prezise anfàhre und ausf-hre, was die Kommission gegen Steuervermeidung und gegen Steuerbetrug zu unternehmen gedenkt. Genau das habe ich getan und darauf hingewiesen, wieso und weshalb es zu diesen Phenomenen in mindestens 22 Lundern der European Union kommt. Die Kommission arbeitet nicht besser mit der luxemburgischen Regierung zusammen als zu meiner Amtszeit. Es gab wenige Premierminister in den letzten Jahren, die sich so intensiv um gute Beziehungen zur Europ-ischen Kommission bem-ht haben, wie ich das getan habe. Deshalb werde ich auch versuchen, als Kommissionspresident ohnlich gute Beziehungen zu anderen Regierungschefs zu haben, wie das freher der Fall war. Mr Verhofstadt, dear Guy, what about? I am told first: "Do not intervene, do not interfere in the current instructions." Then I was told, "Please ask Mrs Vestager to complete her investigation before the end of the year." I will not do that, because I am not involved in the way Ms. Vestager intends to perform her role. I have every confidence in her. She doesn't need your advice or instructions on what she wants and what she will have to do. (Applause) If it turns out that non-authorized state aid has been decided by some Luxembourg body, why do you want me to resign as President of the Commission? Then I would have a problem. You've been Prime Minister. Can you get up right now and say, "Never has there been state aid refused and cancelled by the Commission during my time as Prime Minister."? You don't know that. I am in for a broad and profound investigation, in all countries. Maybe, then, you'll have a problem. (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Thank you very much. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. – Revelations about secret agreements with hundreds of companies to lighten the tax burden in Luxembourg are extremely serious. While this was happening, a policy of extreme austerity is implemented with dramatic consequences for many citizens and for many countries. Mr. Juncker, stop it. When inequalities grow, we have unbearable unemployment rates, poverty increases, especially child poverty, Europe must ensure zero tolerance for fraud, with tax avoidance and dumping. Zero tolerance, Mr Juncker, with tax havens. There are plenty of words and no compromises. We are at a crucial moment in European construction. It's urgent to investigate. It's a necessity and a demand. It's in your hands, Mr. Juncker. Either Europe gives hope back to citizens or citizens will definitely lose hope in Europe.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. – It is not unknown that luxembourg, as in many other Member States, e.B. Belgium, the Netherlands, great Britain or Austria, have tax-saving schemes, nor is it unknown. Competition between countries - including in the area of taxation - is also to be welcomed at first. However, unfair competition in the field of taxation must be combated, because tax injustices are unacceptable and must not be tolerated. That is what we have been fighting for in Parliament for years, but we are failing because of the opposition of the Member States. Possible unfair competition must be investigated on a case-by-case basis by the competent competition commissioner. I am very confident in this, because Mrs Margrethe Vestager comes from a small, corruption-free country and will certainly do justice to this task in full. However, we must also move forward with common tax standards at EU level in a timely manner. A common tax base, which still does not yet exist, would be a first step in this direction. The overarching objective must be to restore tax justice. Member States continue to play a prominent role in this.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. – We consider positive the steps taken by the Commission to address tax evasion through the fight against aggressive tax planning, efforts to repeal banking secrecy, especially in the countries around us, as well as agreements with these countries to establish mechanisms for the exchange of automatic information. Even so, it should be emphasized that much work remains to be done in the field of combating fraud, especially in the case of large companies. In this regard, recent news about the Luxembourg government and its previous tax arrangements with large companies to significantly reduce their taxation by acting as a European hub for this purpose are of concern. Citizens can see on the one hand a certain inaction by the national and Community authorities — since it can well be concluded that many of these practices are legal, even if they are clearly unfair — and on the other hand a certain collusion between those authorities and the companies that benefit. Moreover, that trust affects the image of the head of the newly elected Commission, it is entirely counterproductive and it is necessary to act with the utmost force.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. We will not be lenient. During the composition of his Commission, Mr Juncker placed the candidates in the most toxic places for them (a speculator - Mr Hill - to market regulation, an oil tycoon with climate and energy, etc.) by arguing, basically, that poachers are the best field guards. Therefore, let us apply this reasoning to its author: who better than Juncker, former prime minister of a tax haven, to put in place real tax harmonisation. We demand no less. We demand that tax harmonisation be put in place, that each Member State proposes the same taxation for businesses to avoid tax dumping. The credibility of the President of the European Commission depends on the establishment of a European tax justice system

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. I believe that the behaviour of the Prime Minister of Luxembourg over the last eighteen years has been highly immoral, allowing his country and the multinationals to thrive through elusive tax behaviour towards the tax authorities of the other Member States of the Union. That is why I do not consider him to be the right person to hold the office of President of the Commission at a sensitive historical moment where a firm stand is needed against countries that favour tax conduct of this kind.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The next item on the agenda is the election of a Vice-President of the European Parliament in accordance with Articles 15, 17 and 20 of our Rules of Procedure. I have received the following nominations: Mr Fabio Massimo Castaldo and Mr Ioan Mircea Pascu. The candidates have informed me that they have been proposed by their agreement. First of all, however, Mr Castaldo asked for the floor. Please, sir.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today, as I did five months ago, I was not standing for office, I was applying for a principle, as a humble defender of democracy in your home, which I respect and honour. But here the rules for opponents apply, for friends they interpret themselves. This has been demonstrated by those of you who have trampled on the D'Hondt method, which has always been shared, by those who have ghettoised the dignity of millions of votes behind a new wall. Principles always apply, not for convenience. That is why I am giving up the socialist candidacy today. That is why we are calling for all our posts to be returned, removed from a petty pact by people who are honouring their mandate with commitment. Many of you are ashamed of it and have confessed it. Mr. Rehn, if you don't want to kill democracy, you and the others must resign! You must resign!

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Mr! I understood that you do not want to run. Thank you very much. In democracy, it is actually the case that competition leads to democracy. In this respect, it might not have been a bad thing if you had maintained your candidacy. I now have a candidacy, that is the candidacy of Mr Pascu. Mr Pacu has informed me that he has been proposed with his agreement. Since there is one vacant seat and one candidate, I propose that you vote by calling. That is why I ask: are there other candidacies that are now being put forward spontaneously? That is not the case. (Calls require electronic voting.) Now that an electronic vote has been requested, we must make this very precise. You can vote 'yes' or not to vote, which is tantamount to abstention. That is the rule laid down in our Rules of Procedure. (The President explained the voting procedure. This is followed by a test vote with a fictitious name.)

name: Ashley Fox (ECR). -
text: Mr President, the procedure you have outlined is very confusing, and I think Members will be wondering why you ask us to vote in favour or abstain, thus giving us no opportunity to vote against. It is the most extraordinary procedure. It is quite undemocratic, and you might wish to reflect on giving Members the opportunity to vote against. (Applause)

name: Anne-Marie Mineur (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, I have another complaint about this procedure, which is that it is not secret. If someone votes in favour, their light turns blue. If they do not vote there is no light, so that is not a secret vote.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Ladies and gentlemen! The usual practice in this House so far has been that we use this electronic vote in by-elections to vice-presidential elections. The procedure is also relatively simple: we have a candidate. If you want to vote for this candidate, press the yes button. Voting is secret because the blue button lights up, no matter which button you press. If you do not want to take part in the vote, it would also be visible in the event of a ballot paper vote, because you would not appear in the list of Members taking part. In this respect, this is not an argument. The usual practice so far has been exactly that, and i therefore believe that we should also proceed to this procedure.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE). -
text: The reason for the electronic vote is to ensure that the vote is secret. Whether you can only vote for or not. If I do not vote, the whole plenary knows that I did not approve this choice and I may want the plenary not to know whether or not I have approved this choice and therefore what I ask is that it should be reconsidered because this system does not ensure that the vote is secret.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: No, we cannot allow another debate on the Rules of Procedure now. All vice-presidents of this House, all of them! – have been elected in this election mode, which you have all agreed to. No Vice-President has been elected differently from the electronic vote. If you do not take part in a vote that is taken by ballot papers, it will also be visible in the register, because all those who took part are published in the Minutes and those who did not take part are not in the Minutes. So it is obvious to everyone that you did not participate. In this respect, this is not an argument. That is why the usual practice so far has been that we vote electronically. If you want it different, we can do it differently. Then the House must decide autonomously what it wants. We are welcome to vote by ballot paper. I have not received a request of this kind.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR). -
text: Mr. President! We did, of course, vote electronically on the Vice-Presidents. But we have always had the opportunity to vote 'no'. I do not know what the practice was like now. This has happened recently in Crimea, which could only be voted 'yes'. The referendum in Crimea was ... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Der Präsident. -
text: Mr Sulik, that is not the case. In the vice-presidential election, a list election is held. You can elect individual Members. You are not voting 'yes', 'no' or 'abstention', but you are voting from a list of fourteen or fifteen proposed candidates who you want to vote for. You are giving a 'yes' vote, not a 'no' vote. That's so. Those who wish to vote in favour are voting 'yes'. Otherwise, your vote is counted as abstention. (The vote was taken) (The President announced the result of the vote) Votes cast: 461 votes in favour: 284 abstentions: 177 This means that Mr Pacu has been elected. Congratulations, sir.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, I would indeed like to make a point of order. What has just happened in this House is a travesty of democracy. To give us a vote in which the option is to vote ‘yes’ or to abstain is bad enough, but when you look at Rule 17 of the Rules of Procedure of this House, it does not provide for such a system. Rule 17 speaks of how vice-presidents of the Parliament are elected. There is nothing whatsoever in that rule that gives you the authority to hold a ballot where the choice is ‘yes’ or ‘abstain’. This is democracy EU-style!

name: Der Präsident. -
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the council and Commission statements on the fight against tax avoidance (2014/2944(RSP)).

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: membre de la Commission. - Monsieur le Président, Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, comme vous le savez tous, la Commission a joué, au cours des dernières années, un rôle clé dans les efforts déployés récemment au sein de l'Union européenne ainsi qu'à l'échelle mondiale pour lutter contre la fraude et l'évasion fiscale. Je veux vous assurer que nous allons continuer de montrer la voie et la voix, à la fois vocalement et dans le sens de montrer un chemin à suivre en la matière. D'abord, quelques mots sur la dimension mondiale. En cette fin de semaine, avec le président Juncker, je participerai au sommet du G20 à Brisbane, parce que l'évasion fiscale est, de plus en plus, un phénomène planétaire et, à ce titre, la coopération avec les chefs d'État du reste du monde est primordiale si nous voulons apporter une réponse efficace à ce problème. À Brisbane va notamment se poursuivre un travail important sur l'érosion des assiettes d'imposition des transferts de profit. C'est ce qu'on appelle l'initiative BEPS et c'est un élément central du programme de travail. La Commission, jusqu'à présent, a été très active pour promouvoir de nouvelles normes ambitieuses. Elle n'a pas eu peur de formuler des propositions et d'être un étendard de cette lutte. Cet engagement porte maintenant ses fruits. Nous nous engagerons afin d'assurer que les travaux sur le BEPS soient finalisés comme prévu, en 2015, pour mettre en place un environnement fiscal mondial plus juste. De la même manière, l'engagement fort de la Commission en faveur d'une plus grande transparence fiscale à l'échelle mondiale a commencé à produire des résultats. Cela veut dire que nous avons contribué avec détermination et avec efficacité aux travaux de l'OCDE sur un nouveau cadre mondial d'échange automatique d'informations, qui garantira un niveau sans précédent d'ouverture et de coopération entre les autorités fiscales du monde entier. J'en viens maintenant à la dimension communautaire elle-même. In parallel, the Commission has also been raising the bar for good tax governance in Europe. Following the 2012 action plan it rolled out a series of legislative proposals and political initiatives to enhance tax transparency and to tackle aggressive tax planning.  In terms of transparency, last month the Council agreed on the Commission’s 2013 proposal to abolish bank secrecy and to apply the global standard for automatic exchange of information from 2016. This was a major achievement in a remarkably short time frame, particularly taking into account the unanimity rule, which we all know is a problem. In addition, negotiations are well under way with our five close European neighbours: Andorra, Lichtenstein, Monaco, San Marino and Switzerland. What for? To ensure that the automatic exchange of information is cemented in our bilateral relationship with them. In terms of creating fair competition, the Commission’s initiatives against aggressive tax planning are also taking root. Member States have agreed to propose changes to the Parent-Subsidiary Directive which will close loopholes and block a common form of tax avoidance. I am heavily investing in the ongoing negotiations on reinforced anti-abuse provisions in order to get to an agreement by the end of the year – this was not totally reached in the last Ecofin Council, but I am optimistic that we will move on. This work runs alongside the ongoing cases, steered by my colleague Margrethe Vestager, which also have fair tax competition as their goal. She appeared yesterday before the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and was able to provide all the necessary details on this issue. A few words about that. In any event, as you may already know, the Commission is currently looking into the practice of tax rulings by Member States that could favour some specific companies. The Commission is in close cooperation with the authorities of the Member States concerned to proceed in a constructive and cooperative manner in this area. We have not seen all the information published yesterday. We have at this stage not yet formed an opinion about it as a possible formal follow-up by the Commission. On a more general note, Commissioner Vestager’s services have asked for information from various countries and she will be vigilant to enforce state aid control in a fair and justified manner. For the future, and beyond this, it is clear that we need to take a more systematic approach to the problem of corporate tax avoidance. We need to look at the root causes and consider long-lasting remedies. This includes digging into the question of how to ensure more appropriate taxation for the modern and digital economy. With this in mind, and in line with the mandate given to me by President Juncker, I will give high priority to advancing the common consolidated corporate tax base (CCCTB) proposal. This proposal is, as you all know, not a mere technical one, far from it. It is mainly political. The CCCTB could fundamentally change the corporate tax environment in Europe, ensuring a closer link between taxation and economic activity and shutting off major channels of avoidance. It must therefore be considered as a key element in our work to secure fairer taxation. For this reason the CCCTB will remain an important political file for me and for this Commission, and we discussed that this morning in the College alongside the proposal which was made here by President Juncker.  The Commission’s recommendation to the Member States on how to clamp down on tax havens is also still on the table. We should explore how this could be taken forward and fully implemented. Finally, as you know, the Commission will not hesitate to complement our toolbox with further initiatives if needed. In this context, we decided this morning – it was discussed a few minutes ago – to further enhance tax transparency, including through more information exchange, and enhance transparency on tax rulings. Madame la Présidente, je conclus en disant que l'engagement de la Commission à lutter contre la fraude et l'évasion fiscales n'est pas nouveau et n'a jamais été mis en question. Cet engagement est aujourd'hui plus ferme que jamais. Efficacité économique, concurrence loyale, justice sociale: voilà trois principes qui sous-tendent la lutte contre l'évasion fiscale. Ce sont ces principes qui, pour moi – dans la tâche qui est la mienne –, comme pour la Commission dans son ensemble, sont et seront au cœur de notre action. C'est la raison pour laquelle le travail de la Commission pour lutter contre la fraude et l'évasion fiscales va continuer avec ambition et détermination pendant ce mandat. Toutefois, il faut souligner – ce n'est pas une façon de se défausser, mais une réalité – que la compétence est essentiellement auprès des États membres. Cela a deux implications. D'une part, si la Commission peut proposer une quelconque initiative dans le domaine de la lutte contre la fraude fiscale, seuls les États membres sont habilités in fine à voter et à donner leur accord. Une prise de conscience et une acceptation de leur part d'agir dans ce sens sont donc indispensables. D'autre part, en raison de la règle de l'unanimité – dont je disais il y a quelques minutes qu'elle était sinon un problème, du moins une difficulté – l'acceptation des États membres peut prendre plus de temps que ce qui serait approprié, voire – je ne le souhaite pas – ne jamais se produire. À cet égard, le rôle à la fois des opinions publiques, des parlements nationaux et de ce Parlement européen est tout à fait décisif pour permettre d'accélérer les choses. Voilà l'esprit dans lequel j'envisage de travailler en collaboration étroite avec ce Parlement européen, votre Parlement, dans les années à venir, pour atteindre nos objectifs communs dans ce domaine qui – croyez-le – sera tout à fait prioritaire pour cette Commission.

name: Burkhard Balz
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The fight against tax avoidance is, of course, also an extremely important issue for the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, but it should be tackled with effective solutions. The issue as such, I believe, speaks for itself. Nor does it necessarily have to be a joke in the past of the President of the Commission or to launch personal attacks against individuals. Last year, including in these last few months, the Commission has already begun important work on which we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats would very much like to build on. The Commission has adopted an action plan and helpful recommendations that need to be implemented. Important progress has also been made in the automatic exchange of information, both at European and global level.  And the exchange of information is now being extended. The OECD standard is becoming an essential tool for making tax evasion increasingly unattractive internationally. Nevertheless, it has to be said that much remains to be done. Tax issues, as we know, have a horizontal character. They therefore also need a sound analysis of the situation in the Member States of the European Union. I believe that the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs is the right place to work out and demonstrate our further action. In this way, our colleagues can make a full and, above all, constructive contribution. We are in favour of an integrated approach, which can then also be developed by the experts in the technical committee. I think that quick shots, mood-making are really out of place. In the end, they do not do justice to the great importance of the issue either. We want serious, effective solutions and, of course, a comprehensive exchange. And we support the Commission's independent competition investigations. Because the honest taxpayer, whether it is a citizen or a company, must experience the positive rating he deserves.  What Europe can do and can do in terms of coordination here, or legally, must be put in place in the end.

name: Elisa Ferreira
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – The revelations about what is happening in Luxembourg were not new and, nevertheless, they are a scandal. They are a scandal because they have allowed everyone to see, all citizens, the extent and sophistication of aggressive tax optimisation practices in a Member State. But the most serious thing is that, as we know, this is not just a luxembourg practice. The European Commission has 7 investigations in different European countries, but the most complicated thing to explain is the fact that many of these agreements and many of these practices turn out to be legal. The great offices of consultants and lawyers assure you and there is a great deal of immorality here. Companies are operating in European Union countries, they are paying taxes almost nowhere and, above all, they are not paying them where they should be paid. Citizens are crushed in those same countries with taxes and austerity policies, while large multinationals defraud the taxman by billions of euros. This is deeply immoral. And when situations become immoral as is this case, they cannot be protected by European law. The law is for this: it serves to make compatible what is illegal with what is morally unbearable to citizens. That is the function of politics and that is the function of legislation, which means that legislation has to change and has to change at European level. Jean-Claude Juncker knows better than anyone the practices of his country of origin and the credibility of the European Commission and its entire team is that he is the leader, the central agent of a radical change in the European agenda by advancing serious proposals to end these situations. We need a much clearer compromise than the one presented here today, with a comprehensive timetable and a clear commitment to this Parliament that something will change radically in the European Union after this huge scandal. This is what citizens demand and this is what the Council too must recognise by reviewing its traditional law of unanimity, because it impedes the progress that is needed. (The speaker agrees to answer a question posed under the "blue card" procedure (Article 149(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE)
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". I would like to ask the Honourable Member if we have heard President Juncker talk about tax competition. The competition that I was used to in the European Union, on the free market, is between companies that produce products and not between states of the European Union itself. I ask you whether this notion of tax competition between States is not a form of betrayal and disloyalty between the States themselves and of treason to the very founding principles of the European Union.

name: Elisa Ferreira (S&D)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – That is exactly the interpretation of our political group, is that competition takes place between companies and that between states there must be in their practices, whether administrative or fiscal, the minimum harmonization to prevent the efforts of the actors of the economy from being overcome by these practices. Having said that, I cannot fail to recommend that, within your liberal political group, you make that same question and a strong debate at the moment at the level of both your colleagues and at the level of prime ministers and members of government who continue to block the minimum of tax harmonisation at Council level.

name: Bernd Lucke
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for We have on the agenda the fight against tax avoidance. But the President of the Commission left the Chamber when this item was raised. This is regrettable, because today we can no longer talk about tax avoidance without mentioning the name of Jean-Claude Juncker. The leader of the Liberal Group, who is also conspicuous by his absence, having just criticised another group leader for this, has rightly said that dark clouds are hanging over the European Commission and over the European Union. It can also be put to the fore, because these are days of shame that we are witnessing here, days of shame for a Commission that is trying to fight against tax avoidance and, at the same time, has to work under a President who is exposed to precisely these accusations that his country has enriched itself in tax revenues at the expense of other countries, that his country has bruised other countries for the tax revenue that they are actually entitled to. That a president violates the fundamental values of our society ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, once again we are discussing here a new crisis of confidence. I think it is very urgent that the dark clouds that we have all observed are lifted. My group leader has rightly said that the United States, since the last elections, is a lame duck, and the world cannot afford a second world power which is completely paralysed by another crisis. So the EU has to act swiftly. There has been a lot of finger-pointing this afternoon, but let us just recognise that we all have a shared responsibility; the Commission, the European Parliament as well as the Member States. I would like to say that I see Eurosceptics of the Left and the Right are smelling blood, but all they propose is to stick to the status quo. I would like to know from the Commission exactly what the investigation entails, other than the four cases of potential illegal state aid. What about the other hundreds of agreements that were exposed by LuxLeaks? Incidentally, I would propose that the special committee for an investigation, that we suggested be set up in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, looks into that matter. I heard from Commissioner Moscovici, who is representing the Commission in this case, about future legislation aiming in particular to eliminate tax avoidance. We would also like to know about past cases that are being investigated, and I would like to have seen here our Liberal Commissioner Ms Vestager whom, incidentally, I trust 100% to lead the investigation. (The speaker agree to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: , blue-card question. – I noticed with interest that you compared the tax situation within the European Union to the United States of America. Would you not agree that there are fundamental differences when separate nation states are involved? To be looking at it from that angle is completely missing the point and shows why this place is not really appropriate to deal with this kind of issue.

name: Sophia in 't Veld (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – Speaking of missing the point, Mr Etheridge, I did not compare the tax system of the United States to that of Europe – not remotely. As a matter of fact, we do not even have a common tax system. All I was saying is that the US Administration at the moment is a lame duck as the result of the elections, putting the Administration opposite Congress. I am afraid that the European Union will also become an administrative lame duck because there are these dark clouds hanging over the administration. That is what I was comparing, Mr Etheridge.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr Juncker, Mr Moscovici, we do not trust you because your governments and your parties have made this legislation, maintained it and implemented it, so that there is this blatant tax avoidance of large multinational corporations with secret tax agreements. The result is that employees, pensioners and small and medium-sized enterprises pay more money. Mr Juncker told us it was legal. Yes, but it is also immoral and unfair and provocative and that is why the legislation must be changed: if we want there to be no tax havens in the heart of Europe there needs to be minimum tax harmonisation that prohibits and severely punishes them. The Commission's investigation is not enough because it is time-consuming and has so far proved ineffective. We are asking the European Parliament for a special committee of inquiry, which will quickly draw a conclusion, and we are asking you to finally make commitments with a clear timetable.

name: Sven Giegold
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, Commissioner Moscovici, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work she has What we have seen here in this discussion is a triple form of distraction. A first distraction, as if Luxembourg were a normal country, which, like other countries, is tax avoidance. No, Luxembourg is an extreme case, because in many ways everything is combined: corporate taxes, taxes on petrol, taxes on Internet trade, benefits for the fund industry. Luxembourg is not a normal country, it is an extreme case. However, it is also a distraction in that attempts are now being made to moralise Mr Juncker's tax avoidance problems, so to speak, on him personally. Because Luxembourg is not alone, but at the same time we have the case in the Netherlands, we have the case in Ireland, we have a system of tax avoidance, namely a market without common tax rules. This does not belong in a social market economy. It is therefore right that we are not talking about it now and wondering whether Mr Juncker alone is the moral responsible person, but that action should be taken now. And that is where the measures matter. I would like to know from you, Commissioner, that your actions are now effective or not? So far, you have said a common tax base and referred to the Commission's proposal. However, the proposal is not binding, but sets up a 29th regime. This proposal by Parliament wants the proposals to become binding. Will they become binding, yes or no? If we get a binding tax base, then the question is: are there common minimum tax rates? Because if we don't have minimum tax rates, it will lead to even tougher corporate tax competition. Are you going to propose minimum tax rates now? Finally, Mr Juncker did not respond to Mr Pittella's suggestion that we should finally be transparent about tax payments in the various countries. Will there now be a proposal for all sectors to distinguish between countries, who pays how many taxes in which country or not? Will you put forward this proposal, Mr Moscovici? These are the deeds by which we measure you.

name: Marco Zanni
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is not with these empty speeches that the Commission can convince us that it wants to change this shameful system. Juncker embodies the very symbol of the EU's failure and represents its worst image. He has favoured his country on the backs of all the European partners he would like to represent today. Shame! But the most embarrassing thing is the behaviour of the Socialists. President Pittella has said in the newspapers that he wants explanations, otherwise he would have distrusted Juncker. Are you satisfied with these non-answers? When are you going to end up with this double play? Be indignant in the newspapers while then in here, for the quiet living, you do not have the courage to take a strong stand against these shameful practices. Juncker represents that European policy that has dragged us into the abyss. You fought it by pretend during the election campaign and then you agreed with the PPE. We will put forward a motion of censure and see who will have the courage to follow us with a concrete act and who prefers to talk in the newspapers and that is it.

name: Mario Borghezio (NI). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thanks to the investigative journalism that exposed this obvious situation, the conflict of interests of a man who, for twenty years, from 1989 to 2009, was also Minister for Finance. He was President of the Eurogroup. He packaged this system of circumvention, which allowed banks, financial institutions and multinationals to steal money from the real economy that produces and employs Europeans. It is a disgrace to have voted for it, dear Socialists, dear Christian Democrats! It is a disgrace to have voted President of the European Commission as a symbol of high financial power, of speculation on derivatives, a great visitor to the Trilateral Commission and the Bilderberg. Only here, when we discuss his responsibilities, has he slipped away and made us still sigh his presence. Then shame on you! We defend the real economy. A Committee of Inquiry of the European Parliament to see him and those who supported him in the dock.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, let me first - on behalf of the People's Party, the party that supports the Government of Spain — support Mr Juncker. Moreover, today, when he has voluntarily decided to appear before this House. I have no doubt that the debate we are having today would not take place if we had done enough to advance the much-needed and long-awaited economic union, fiscal union and, ultimately, political union. Nor do I have any doubt that what has happened in recent days is an opportunity, precisely, to achieve what we have not done and to move forward in that long-awaited fiscal union. But let's not forget that tax union doesn't mean equal taxes. We must create a fiscal union flexible enough that popular fiscal policies, which are precisely one of the hallmarks of the Socialists, can be implemented. And I have no doubt that what happened these days is also an opportunity — as Mr Juncker rightly said today — to keep fighting, even more so, to make tax havens a thing of the past.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done It's a slap in the face for all the people who pay a damn lot of payroll tax – a lot of sales tax, of course – when they see that there are companies that end up paying zero percent, one percent, two percent in taxes. This is deeply indecent and unjust! Taxes - corporate taxes - are traditionally national sacred cows. Take it all the more as a stumbling block for the Commission to tackle this issue at european level.  And there is now a whole bar to be done, which we have already pointed out with the report by Mojca Kleva. You mentioned the consolidated corporate tax base, but of course there is much more at stake: more transparency and country-by-country reporting and blacklisting, but it is also about developing minimum tax rates. We owe this to the citizens of Europe, and now is the right time for that.  However, please also take with you consequences from company law, namely the question of seats! It should also be separated, namely where an undertaking has its registered office, which should ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Sander Loones (ECR). -
text: The fight against tax fraud, as has been said repeatedly, must be stepped up, not in order to start a witch-hunt, but because the tax burden in several Member States is far too high. This is also the case in my country, Belgium. The fact that Mr Verhofstadt acknowledged this in his intervention earlier was, in my opinion, the strongest point in his speech. If we want to reduce this tax burden, we must ensure that everyone pays their fair share, and i was personally disappointed by the words of President Juncker. He opts for a purely legalistic argument. He hides behind the law and nothing but the law. But, ladies and gentlemen, there's more. There is morality and ethics, and for that my party chooses tax competition. Because it is good for our competitiveness, good for our economy. But we oppose disloyal competition, because it is unethical as far as we are concerned.  That is why we are also calling for a thorough investigation into the Luxleaks, an investigation that is objective and is being carried out quickly.

name: Michael Theurer (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, dear colleagues! It is not just about Luxembourg. The fact that tax-saving models exist via Luxembourg is nothing new. But the extent to which the revelations have brought to light is absolutely outrageous. The ordinary citizen, the ordinary family that pays taxes, the medium-sized entrepreneur, the master craftsman who pays taxes, and at the same time the international corporation, which pays no taxes: that is not acceptable! A social market economy is also open to competition for location, but it must not be ruinous. That is why we, as the Group of the European Liberal, Democrat and Reform Party, are proposing to set up a special committee, which will then analyse in more detail what the tax loopholes are. We are also talking about the Member States, which have been blocking in the Council for many years, that there is framework European Union legislation that prevents such tax avoidance strategies.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul For me, this is not about legality and illegality, it is about politics and it is about trust. Juncker has pursued a policy that invites big business to tax avoidance while pursuing a policy of austerity and privatisation. Luxembourg's tax policy and trickery are right-wing politics at its worst. Public money that would have gone to our common welfare has disappeared. No one else has undermined confidence in Juncker, as was suggested here. It is, in fact, the policy he has pursued that is unacceptable. I have heard his arguments, but I am not convinced. Now Juncker says he will harmonise fiscal policy. It seems a bit like asking the wolf to guard the sheep, at least if you are left and want a solidarity-based tax policy that exists to finance solidarity.

name: Philippe Lamberts (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President, Mr Moscovici, you obviously have a golden opportunity to make a name for yourself here in Brussels. So we're going to wait for you at the foot of the wall on two fronts. The first is transparency. Transparency itself does not solve the problem of tax competition, but let us say that it increases the political price in terms of reputation, both for the beneficiaries of tax giveaways and for those who make them. Two things on this subject: first, the extension of country-by-country reporting to all multinational companies. This extension must, of course, be done publicly, in other words, in the annual reports of companies, just as we have obtained for the banks, we must be entitled to details of the activity and the taxes paid by companies, country by country. The second thing is that you can help us with the Anti-Money Laundering Directive. You know that Parliament has voted for a public register of the final beneficiaries of all opaque financial structures. We expect, in the fight - because it is a struggle - that we are opposed to the Council, support from the Commission, so as to force the Council to accept a measure, on the whole, of public safety. On the convergence front, on tax harmonisation, it is obviously more difficult because you are subject to the law of unanimity. On this point, I will say two things: first, I note that, under the mother-subsidiary directive, the Netherlands, of which some representatives now have all the merits, are currently blocking the anti-abuse measures that are being negotiated. On this subject too, I expect the Commission to increase the pressure, in particular by publicly setting out an attitude which is exactly in line with greater tax evasion. I think that the time is particularly appropriate to point the finger at the Member States that practice dual discourse. On the consolidated corporate tax base, it is clear that adopting this base without adopting minimum rates and therefore some convergence of rates - this does not mean a "one size fits all" but at least a certain range of rates under corporate tax - is clearly insufficient. On this point, I would invite you to encourage the States, which, like France and Germany, once said that they would organise enhanced cooperation to form a coalition of volunteers to harmonize corporate taxes. Go ahead!

name: Barbara Kappel (NI). -
text: Madam President! Competition Commissioner Vestager told the ECON Committee yesterday that the Commission is currently investigating four specific cases of tax-saving agreements of multinational companies, two in Luxembourg, one in the Netherlands and one in Ireland. All of these countries are known for their tax-saving models – tax-saving models that are legal and based on legislation, tax-saving models that are responsible for ensuring that corporate values, profits, and dividends are as high as possible, and tax-saving models that ultimately benefit shareholders in particular. So if you are, ladies and gentlemen, shareholders of Google, Amazon, Apple, Pepsi, Deutsche Bank or E.ON, then you too benefit from tax-saving models. At the last G20 meeting, the OECD presented an action plan to combat legal tax evasion by large corporations. This Action Plan is a catalogue of measures to develop effective, internationally agreed rules against profit cuts and profit shifting by the end of 2015 with the aim of closing tax loopholes and untaxed asset movements ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE). -
text: Madam President, in this debate we have to answer some fundamental questions. The first one is about the legality of the measures imposed by some individual Member States, and here we have heard a reassurance from President Juncker that those measures applied by the Luxembourg Government were perfectly legal.  I am very happy to hear this, but on the other hand, if this is the case, then we have to ask ourselves another question: how is it that those measures have raised so much concern and even outrage among European citizens? This is something we cannot ignore as lawmakers here in this House. Therefore I call on the Commission to work on this in order to increase transparency in all those measures, and also to make sure that discrimination is avoided. Because if this measure is a result of obscure negotiations then of course it may raise the suspicion of citizens. If on the other hand it is restricted only to large multinationals, it again puts small and medium-sized enterprises in a disadvantaged position. So this definitely calls on us to amend European legislation in order to avoid those kinds of deficiencies. We all know that tax policies remain within the remit of national governments, but all tax measures which are applied, should be applied in full respect of non-discrimination and transparency.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D). -
text: Some have come to this debate to demand a weaker Europe under the pretext of tax havens. And I, as a Hungarian and a Social Democrat, have come here to ask for a more and stronger Europe, because we are facing new challenges. There's no question about that. There must also be more Europe, better and tighter supervision and, indeed, transparency against tax evasion and their toxic effects, because the people of my city, Szeged, are also demanding that there be no exceptions, that if they pay their taxes, then multinationals should do the same fairly. But in Hungary, for example, at this moment the public is outraged not only because of the ban of the President of the Tax Office himself on suspicion of corruption by the United States of America, because the government refuses to recall the president of the tax authority. My answer to this is that we need more disciplined and fairer Europe to pay taxes, to eliminate tax evasion, and to eradicate tax fraud together. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Do you agree that multinationals need to be held to account for the way that they stifle small businesses? Do you recognise that there is a difference between tax avoidance and evasion? Do you understand that moves towards tax harmonisation are moves that push the UK towards the exit door from the European Union? Like Caesar’s wife, our leaders must be beyond suspicion. Do you accept that Juncker is no longer beyond suspicion?

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Blue card answer. – I trust Mr Moscovici and his colleagues to establish practices and institutions that do not increase bureaucracy in the European Union, but that allow all EU Member States to participate on equal terms in shaping our common DESTINY in the EU. I will not support examples of tax avoidance in the Netherlands, luxembourg or, where appropriate, in Hungary. I would like the proposals of the Social Democrat group, the S&D group, to be adopted by the Commission and to usher in a new era...  (the President interrupts the speaker)

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen (ALDE). -
text: Madam President, combating tax evasion, tax fraud and tax havens is a global, broad and complicated issue. There is nothing wrong as such with competing on investment climates and business climates, but this also has a state aid aspect. In this area the EU has an important role. We think it is a good idea to install a specific committee in this Parliament to have a debate on these issues. However, the focus should be on principles not on specific cases or countries. On the global level the OECD has done some good work with its recommendations and we advise that we use this as a starting point.

name: Dennis de Jong (GUE/NGL). -
text: Of course, tax avoidance must be tackled, because it cannot be the case that ordinary people and SMEs pay full tax and that multinationals do not. However, the means of state aid chosen by the Commission is a means of equine.  The Commission requires Member States to provide information on tax arrangements with companies. It then assesses whether there is undue state aid. The Commission takes these decisions entirely independently. Neither the national parliaments nor the European Parliament can influence them. In fact, they don't even have the underlying information about those tax arrangements. That's the world upside down.  Member States are already working together within the framework of the OECD in Paris. Why is the Commission not committed to facilitating this very process? Then parliaments will remain in charge of tax policy, but we will tackle tax avoidance together. This is more democratic and ultimately more effective, because it is based on support rather than dictation.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President, this situation exposes the European Commission and detract from all credibility. While Mr Juncker was pushing for austeritarian agreements as president of the Eurogroup, he also closed agreements with 340 multinationals so that they would not pay taxes. With what face can Mr Juncker look at those citizens who see his access to public health today because there are no resources? With what face can Mr Juncker look at today those who are removed from the benefit because there are no resources? His credibility right now is low. I must also say that the proposals you have put forward to us today are totally insufficient, as my colleagues have already highlighted. It did not talk about the fiscal transparency of the Member States. He has not spoken of minimum tax levels at European level to avoid tax competition, which is the main problem that is draining public finances. I have to say, moreover, that Mr Juncker's conflict of interest is obvious, because if it is the Commission itself that he chairs who has to investigate the agreements which he closed, if this is not a conflict of interest, someone comes and explains it. I have to say that Mr Juncker, once again, is the wrong person, in the wrong position. Without a clear commitment, without a committee of inquiry and without a clear fight against tax evasion, the only possibility for Mr Juncker is to leave.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul It is with dismay that I have been following the media reports recently, not least regarding the help of Swedish companies with tax planning in Luxembourg. It is with as much dismay as one realises that for a long time it was Mr Juncker, in his role as both Prime Minister and Finance Minister of Luxembourg, who was most responsible for this fraudulent practice of all sorts of fiscal solutions that was allowed to continue during his time. And now we have Mr Juncker here as the new President of the European Union, where he is most responsible for managing the best possible management of the eu contributions paid by 507.4 million citizens. Right here it all starts to get very tragicomic, because the feeling you get is that you have put the fox to guard the chickens. For the ordinary hard-working person, it's like being spat in the face and mocked for working and contributing to social functions through their tax paid, while big business is doing its best to cheat and stay away from the same regulations, and often gets away with it. Enough is enough; rules need to be changed.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE). -
text: Madam President, Romanian citizens, like other European citizens, want one simple thing: that the incomes of people and businesses that are made in a country are fully declared and taxed in that country. It's a simple thing. Unfortunately, that's not the case. There are countless commercial, tax, accounting practices whereby revenue shaves from one tax jurisdiction to another tax jurisdiction, legally or illegally, in order not to be taxed. We have made progress in combating tax evasion through this extension of the principle of reporting, automatic information, automatic exchange of information. Unfortunately, the information that has emerged lately, with a number of tax practices in Luxembourg, but as President Juncker told us today, such practices are still found in 21 other Member States, of course they have rightly disturbed European citizens. I am confident that the European Commission will come up with an objective response to these problems and with the necessary measures to reduce tax evasion.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D). -
text: Madam President, it took almost a week for Mr Juncker to face it. The Spanish Socialists have been demanding until the last minute to appear in this House, because the President of the European Commission must know that democratic legitimacy is won not only by votes, but also with respect for citizens and their institutions. Since the economic crisis began millions of citizens have lost their jobs, their rights, their hope... and how do you think they feel today, when they see that there have been agreements so that large multinationals could tax evade their taxes? I tell you: deceived and conned. Today it is necessary not only an explanation, a reaction. We demand the tax union. We demand the prohibition of tax havens, fair taxes for all. We demand from Mr Juncker a different way out of the crisis, a just way out that corrects what is unworthy of us and, above all, those who are out of here.

name: Fabio De Masi (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President! The great Mr Juncker has just hidden behind the small officials in Luxembourg, and he has said that all this was legal. That is precisely the scandal. He's supposed to explain that to the people up there who have to work hard. We lose EUR 1 trillion every year through tax evasion and avoidance, while Mr Juncker explains saving to these people. Imagine a thief stealing you. Then he rings the doorbell and wants to take your furniture with him, and the police tell you that's legal. Then there are three possibilities: the thief is crazy, the laws are criminal, or you live in the EU. We are calling for new EU treaties with minimum taxes for corporations, country-by-country reporting, withholding tax. Harmonisation of taxes without minimum rates alone is not enough, it can even further inflame competition. We have rejected the godfather of the tax cartel as president. The Commission shall decide jointly on the procedure against Luxembourg. Mrs Vestager confirmed to me yesterday that cooperation has been better since Mr Juncker left. That is why we say that the Juncker system can only be ended without Mr Juncker, not with him.

name: Peter Eriksson (Verts/ALE). -
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratul Effective tax systems are crucial to building functioning societies, we know that. The question of confidence today is whether the new Commission will take the steps that we know are necessary, and also possible, to put an end to the unfair and often parasitic tax policies that individual countries are unfortunately pursuing. There's a change. We know that greater transparency can be obtained. We know that we can use competition law. In these matters, Luxembourg or Holland do not have a right of veto to use. The Commission cannot therefore hide behind the requirement for unanimity in tax matters. But I would also like to remind you that words are not enough. We have had a few words that have been positive today – on other issues the Commission has not taken a position. But words aren't enough. It is action that must be taken for the issue of trust to be released before we can say otherwise.

name: Esther de Lange (PPE). -
text: The practices we are discussing today are not new, we all know that. They're not illegal either. But not everything that is legal is also desirable. I think that is at the heart of this debate.  Let us be clear, the tax decisions we are talking about rightly confirm the sense of dishonesty of citizens and small business owners who do pay their taxes properly. Of course, there is nothing wrong with healthy competition at all, but it does when it leads to discrimination, state aid or unfair competition. Then you have to perform. And if we really want to take steps against tax avoidance, then we in the European Parliament are going to need this European Commission. In an area where - let me say it mildly - the Council is not full of enthusiasm and is decided unanimously.  But please note that we also know that some in this house are not doing anything about tackling tax avoidance. There are those who automatically put the heels in the sand. There are also those who want to resent the vote on the Juncker Commission because he was not their candidate. And there are others who see in this discussion the excuse to raise the overall level of taxes in Europe. That is not our agenda as an PPE Group. Our question to them is: can they jump over their own shadow and abandon their personal vendetta or their secret agenda to tackle joint tax avoidance? Our hand is outstretched. The question is: are you able to take them on in a responsible way?

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D). -
text: Madam President! Tax evasion, as we see it in Luxembourg and in other EU countries, is a provocation! A provocation against ordinary, hard-working people who pay high taxes and in the crisis years has seen their welfare cut, while inequality has exploded in Europe and the rich have become even richer, partly through systematic tax evasion. It is a provocation against and unfair competition against ordinary small businesses, which, incidentally, creates 8 out of 10 jobs in Europe. We need transparency. We need a new way of taxing companies so that they are taxed where their turnover and profits are. So we would like some clear answers to country-by-country reporting, and we would like a timetable: when is that going to happen? We want clear answers now! In addition, it would be fine if the Commission also were to examine the problem in general in the EU - what it takes to get to the bottom and stop tax evasion, tax havens and tax thinking.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, I do not know how the word 'caradura' will be translated into the different official languages of the Union, but I think it is the one that best expresses what we have seen today. Mr Juncker said: "I am responsible for tax evasion in my country, but trust my Commission to pursue tax evasion." Mr Pittella, with his usual bombast, said: "We have to combat tax evasion, but the European Socialists will continue to support him, Mr Juncker." Mr Zalba of my country's People's Party said: "Mr Juncker, in my party we support you." And he is supported above all by Mr. de Guindos, who was CFO of the consultancy who helped him sign those secret agreements. Mario Benedetti said: "Suicide doesn't redeem a torturer but something is something." Resignation doesn't redeem the horses, but something is something.

name: Frank Engel (PPE). -
text: Madam President, special and individual tax arrangements exist in many countries of the European Union and beyond. They exist in some countries because they exist in others and because there is competition to attract international headquarters of international companies. One wonders how many of these companies would still be in Europe if these practices did not exist. Whether they are moral, ethical, laudable, we can debate them, but the world is what it is.  The Commission has just, together with the Council, ensured that the mother-subsidiary directive will soon eliminate certain elements of hybrid capital which are one of the main reasons for early tax decisions across the Union. We'll see what the results are. The new measures to exchange information on advance tax decisions will be another contribution to widespread transparency in this area, but they will not eliminate these types of decisions - let us be reasonable - unless we want to. However, in order to do so, States must want it, and I note that so far many States, a vast majority of Member States, have not wanted it and have prevented progress on this front. Perhaps this opportunity is a chance that we can finally move forward together on this issue.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D). -
text: Madam President, Commissioner, since you are here with President Juncker's left ear, tell him that we have given him our trust in an informed way. He is now President of the Commission, he has a monopoly on initiative and we are therefore waiting for him to meet with this Parliament. To shed light on this path, because of course there is not just a LuxLeaks - others have said before me, these cases of tax evasion or evasion exist in other Member States - we believe that a commission of inquiry can be useful. In the meantime, we would like to hear your answers to the questions that have been asked here by our President Gianni Pittella on the suspension of banking licences for those who assist in tax evasion and on the issue of country-by-country reporting of profits and taxes. I have heard Jean-Claude Juncker argue in favour of tax competition and I must admit my astonishment, because this tax competition is always unfair. It becomes unacceptable in times of crisis, in times of near-deflation. The European Parliament has given Jean-Claude Juncker, a convinced European, confidence. Now it's up to him to prove that we were right.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL). -
text: Things are very clear, while he was campaigning for austerity and impoverishment, cuts in wages, pensions, health, education, social security, while supporting brutal tax increases on the majority of the population, the current President of the European Commission was responsible for secret deals with hundreds of multinationals to save them from paying taxes, depriving states of hundreds of billions of euros of tax revenue due to him. We are therefore talked about the conditions to occupy the place it occupies. We are talked about the interests and objectives it serves. Once the scandal is known, the need for fiscal harmonisation in the European Union is now being defended. There are few or no doubts about the interests that this tax harmonisation would serve. It is evidence that the problem goes far beyond Luxembourg. From the outheaval, the problem is not solved without the pure and simple elimination of tax havens. They really wanted to do something to change the current state of things and that's where they would start.

name: Werner Langen (PPE). -
text: Madam President! If you listen for a longer time, you could say that this is a stellar hour for the hypocrites! Here, Jean-Claude Juncker is blamed for a practice that is common in 22 states. And when I see that the left at the back, here the German communist – the SED spent 6 billion Deutschmarks after German unification in Switzerland to save taxes – or when I hear the Greek colleagues of all the political groups – only in December 2013 the tax exemption for Greek shipowners was abolished – that is a deceitful debate here! This does not mean that we do not need to talk seriously about the issue: whether these are the tax exemptions for Renault in France or the hundred cases in Belgium or the licence exemption in the Netherlands or the low tax rates in Ireland – we need to talk about it, even if it is national competence.  That is why, Commissioner, the most important point is to combat tax fraud and to prevent dumping. The most important point is greater transparency, and you have the opportunity, as the European Commission, to take initiatives that, despite their legal competences, force the Member States to show more transparency and thus to take responsibility.    (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – You have said many good things about how communist parties in Central Europe have seized public assets, but just think about our peoples who live there. Do you not really think that this peak of cynicism makes it difficult for us, for example, to reduce VAT on goods for families and young children when people who want tax harmonisation create artificial doping for investment in their country? In my opinion, this is the height of cynicism, and I think you will agree with that.

name: Werner Langen (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I am absolutely in favour of introducing minimum rates and introducing a margin. However, I am opposed to the idea, as Mrs Berés has proposed, of abolishing tax competition. Then we would get to the tax level of France, with 56 to 58% of the state. That cannot be the aim! That is why I believe that this is possible for temporary job development and investment, but not as a state-owned tax model for all time. That is why we must find a way to be more honest and more transparent.

name: President. -
text: We have a point of order from Mr Iglesias.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President, just one question for you: What criterion do you use to grant the cards?

name: President. -
text: I said at the start of the debate that I would give one blue card per speaker and I would not allow those who were contributing to the debate to ask a question. I am trying to be fair and I have asked the services to assist me in doing that. So far I have. I literally caught the gentleman’s eye and I am taking one blue card. It is due to the time pressures we are under. I hope you understand, but I am trying to be fair to everybody in the Chamber.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I just wanted to say that Mr Langen spoke twice; he spoke to me and now I am not able to answer. That is unfair.

name: President. -
text: Thank you for your point.

name: Rina Ronja Kari (GUE/NGL). -
text: Madam President! Tax evasion is a mess, and it is hammering disjointed. It is, in fact, a robbery of the community and of the access of future generations to the welfare society. Try to think about how many government cuts we could have avoided if only companies that cheat in tax had contributed to the community. We are already fighting for more transparency in the system, but we cannot accept a President of the Commission who, during his time as Finance and Prime Minister in Luxembourg, has been at the forefront of providing smart tax scams to large companies. And yes, it is actually also about Mr Juncker. He himself has admitted that: he has political responsibility! As Prime Minister, you actually have a political responsibility for what is going on. That is why the conclusion is also clear: Juncker cannot credibly lead a Commission to fight tax havens. There is a lot of need for that. That's why he should be grown up enough to take on his responsibilities and resign himself.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE). -
text: I think it has become very clear today that there is no fraud, there is no illegality in Luxembourg as in other Member States, there is no tax evasion, but it is clear that there is aggressive tax planning, there is tax avoidance and in tax matters, each Member State seeks the maximum revenue. Not being illegal does not mean that ethics, values, equity, which are fundamental and therefore more integration, more common rules, more fiscal harmonisation should not be searched. It is quite clear that "proudly alone" does not work on many matters and in tax matters, it is certainly not a good solution either, but they do not want to take advantage of this situation to level taxes, to increase them, on the contrary, the fight against tax avoidance, which is what happens in this case, but there is also fraud and there is tax evasion , they are essential for us to increase revenues and in this case, in this sense, to reduce taxes and, in particular, taxes on small and medium-sized enterprises. I would also like to regret the escalation of this discussion in which I sometimes feel that the European Commission is trying to vote again. What we have at the moment is to come up with a platform of understanding, knowing that the big problem is not even in Parliament, is in the necessary unanimity in the Council to amend the tax rules.   (the speaker agrees to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Article 149(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – Where is the morality and ethics of fiscal amnesty that the Portuguese government, under the adjustment program with the blessing of the Troika gave in Portugal, to the gangsters of the Espírito Santo family?

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – My colleague Ana Gomes often brings national issues to this debate. Just as there are no virtuous Member States, I also believe that there will be no virtuous and fully virtuous governments in this matter and the government of Eng. Socrates and the government that had as vice-president António Costa on the issue of tax evasion, we cannot in any way be proud and be proud of and let the Honourable Member know that in recent years tax revenues in Portugal have increased precisely in the fight against tax evasion that has occurred , although the Troika itself is often suspicious of this possibility and, from this point of view, the example of Portuguese government can even be brought here to share best practices in this area.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (PPE). -
text: Madam President, I think that the more we fight politically in this Chamber, the greater the possibility of having a fair and effective tax system. It is clear that many Member States of the European Union are competing with each other for tax, because, quite simply, we have not decided at government level to have a common tax system. We therefore ask ourselves about the results of our political decisions. I must also tell you that within the countries the regions between them compete fiscally because special situations apply, they try to attract investment and all that. It is wrong to confuse small and medium-sized enterprises - and say that they are over-taxed - with multinationals, because multinationals, however unpleasant that may sound politically, are fighting a more complex fight on a global level, because after all we do not want to cut off the legs of European multinationals in favour of American multinationals or in favour of Chinese multinationals which are extremely dynamic. So here I think there is political hypocrisy: we have seen it all today. It is what they used to say in ancient Greece "I'm an old learner". We have seen the representatives of the Autonomy of the City, the representatives of the autonomy of the Isle of Man, accuse Mr Juncker - unfairly in my view - and we have also seen our Green and Left-wing friends follow a line of "Financial Times" and "Bloomberg". We've seen it all! (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 149(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – Although I would have liked to have asked Mr Langen, my question to Mr Kyrtsos is just as good: we see that 22 countries in the European Union are capable of doing a very bad exercise, almost unitedly, so why not look on the bright side of this, whether 28 of us can come together for a good thing. I ask you, do you or your party agree that the European Union should also be a tax union?

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (PPE)
text: answer a question with a blue card. – A key conclusion that we must draw from this debate, even if it has often escaped, is that we should not raise taxes. And I will also tell you this: Ireland did it with the memorandum and left 'excellently' and we in Greece are still struggling with the memorandum because, unlike the Irish who have held firm, we have accepted the tax increase to protect public spending. Therefore, "all together"; however, this does not eliminate the specificities, whether they are between countries, regions or sectors of the economy.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D). -
text: We all know that there was tax evasion within the European Union, but now we have learned how and where to look. The European Parliament's proposal for almost ten years has provided not only for the lifting of banking secrecy but also for the treatment of tax avoidance, through the tax you mentioned, of the CCCTB. So because the European Parliament had moved in this direction but we have not heard - we need honesty, transparency and justice - the Council and the Member States must assume their responsibilities. And you must press them and listen to the European Parliament, because words are not enough and time is running out. The secret agreements and 'Lux Leaks' have shown that the crisis is due to the inadequacy of a common European policy, as the rules do not ultimately apply to everyone, and the memorandums still apply to a few. Thus, the burden falls selectively on wage cuts and not on multinationals which, through subsidiaries, are the main source of the problem and contribute to the loss of investment from the countries that have suffered the greatest sacrifices in richer countries. Under Barroso's presidency in the Commission, nothing had gone ahead. We hope that Juncker and Moscovici will combat unethical tax avoidance in Europe with sanctions because, basically, we need a specific timetable so that we can say that in the next annual report on taxation we will have fewer targets and more results.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE). -
text: Mr President, this tax debate is really necessary. We know that tax arrangements are being made in EU countries, which citizens often feel are very unfair, even though they are legal in them. We in Finland have a saying that what is not justice and moderation cannot be the law either. In other words, it must be possible to amend laws that are perceived to be unfair.  It is good that the European Commission is now speeding up the automatic exchange of information. This is really important in order to increase tax transparency. Similarly, I would like to encourage the Commission to work on harmonising tax conditions. I do not believe and do not think it is good to try to harmonise the level of taxation at EU level, but it is important that we tax the same sources. In other than that, the basis of taxation would be as uniform as possible. That would increase fair competition.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). -
text: Madam President, at a time when the troika, under the guidance of the Eurogroup and Mr Juncker, has imposed on Greece a heavy tax policy which has impoverished the Greek people, Mr Juncker's Luxembourg and other Member States of the European Union, tax havens operate on their territory. For all this there are political responsibilities of the well-known old political world of Europe to which both Mr Juncker and Mr Moscovici belong. With his decision and his speech today, Mr Juncker did not convince anyone. He tried, without success, to accept his responsibilities. He did not convince anyone of the conflict of interest, since he is President of the Commission which is supposed to do the Juncker gate check. In my native Greece there is the proverb "Yiannis kerna and Giannis drinks". This is also true in the case of Mr Juncker: 'Juncker buys and Juncker drinks'! That is why I voted against Mr Juncker as a candidate for President of the Commission.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE). -
text: While Member States are allowed to regulate and prescribe tax areas for themselves, there is too much gap between Member States and distorts competition in the market and weakens the budgets of some Member States.
