In Slovenia, too, we face the problem of the withering of income and seats of companies from Slovenia to countries with more favourable tax rates. Sometimes companies also choose a fictitious way of doing business for these purposes, which means that they set up a company's head office in a Member State with a more favourable tax rate, but in reality they do not do business there. While the documents show business, in reality it is only a waste of money from a company in Slovenia into companies or branches established in a country with favourable tax rates. Thus, a double situation occurs, namely the avoidance of income tax in Slovenia, which further weakens the state budget, and also distorts competition between companies. We should also not forget the legislation on transfer pricing here, which is particularly an option when it comes to a multinational company when they charge each other's prices with their branches.  There is an urgent need to regulate this area so that tax arrangements are no longer exploited.

name: José Blanco López (S&D). -
text: Madam President, what happened in Luxembourg is extremely serious, doubly serious. While that was happening, a policy of extreme austerity was applied, with dramatic consequences for many citizens, for many countries, and that is a clear social injustice. When inequalities grow; when we have unbearable unemployment rates; when poverty increases, and singularly child poverty; when there is no credit for businesses; when we have difficulty making productive investment, Europe cannot tolerate this. Europe must ensure zero tolerance for fraud, with circumvention, with tax dumping... Zero tolerance against tax havens. There are plenty of words and no compromises. We are at a crucial moment for the European Union. It is urgent to investigate, clarify, act, move forward... Because, ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, either Europe brings people back hope, or people will definitely lose hope in Europe.

name: President. -
text: Ms Matias, I was going to give you the floor so I will not take the blue card at this stage, but I will give you the floor.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL). -
text: If it were not for the state, I would say that today we had come to a church and not to a plenary session of the European Parliament. Mr Juncker started by saying that he doesn't have to prove anything, we just have to believe him, so it's a matter of faith. Then Mr Juncker says that tax engineering is not exclusive to Luxembourg but that it is an ecuménic phenomenon in the European Union and then we have Mr. Moscovici, who played the role of Friar Thomas, very preached, very preached, but then says that the European Commission basically can do nothing. I ask you, Mr. Moscovici, if you would like to hear three very specific questions. A concrete strategy and policy measures to combat fraud and tax evasion? The end of tax havens? The definition of the tax that is applied to all large multinationals operating within the euro area? Which of these are you going to compromise with or remain immoral and indecent as is the President of your Commission?

name: Ana Gomes (S&D). -
text: Madam President, the Luxembourg leaks expose the costs of non-Europe. While our governments in the Council, and the Commission, callously impose brutal taxes and austerity policies, there is little for the middle classes and the poor. They immorally compete to provide schemes for tax avoidance and tax evasion for the rich and large companies via tax rulings, and even via tax amnesties such as the ones offered by the Portuguese Government – with the blessing of the Troika – to the gangsters of the Espirito Santo family in 2012, and many others. We will not have public or private investment in growth and jobs, and we will not have fair competition and a true single market, if our Member States continually embark on this race to the bottom on tax dumping. The Commission must act – and urgently.  First: deliver on the ongoing investigations on state aid to Luxembourg, Ireland, Holland and so on. Secondly: support the European Parliament in the Anti-Money Laundering Directive negotiations and in the demand for a publicly accessible registry of beneficial ownership in social participation, including foundations and trusts. Thirdly: deliver on country-by-country reporting, recovering and helping countries to recover taxes evaded and confiscate the proceeds of tax fraud. Finally, the Commission should welcome the commission of investigation set up by this Parliament, because this will only help the Commission to put pressure on our governments in the Council to act.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE). -
text: Dear colleagues, Until now, the luxembourg case has been at the centre of this debate, even though the phenomenon we are facing is much wider. Lack of transparency, tax evasion, corruption, organised crime are all different strands of the same case. In Hungary, the highest-level VAT fraud scandal, offshore Cypriot companies, Italian organised crime and the diversion of EU funds show the seriousness of corruption in many Member States in the European Union and within the Member States. Comprehensive, unified action against corruption is needed in various related cases. The anti-corruption report that we adopted earlier this year is scandalous because it lacks chapter 29, which examines the European Union itself. There is a need for a comprehensive anti-corruption strategy in Europe. It is necessary to have a European Chief Prosecutor investigate corruption cases, in the meantime to strengthen OLAF, and to sanction the diversion of EU funds in the Member States. If we do not act decisively in the area of anti-corruption, we will not be able to defend our European core values and lose the trust of European citizens.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, this is a debate over tax avoidance with a President who built his career on encouraging tax avoidance in his own country. Then comparisons between the EU and the USA, talking about lame-duck presidents. Maybe a flock of Socialist lame-duck presidents perhaps! In this chamber of fantasies, where earlier on today Members claimed credit for the fall of Communism without mentioning the UK or the USA, I find it wholly inappropriate that such matters should be discussed. Let us leave it to sovereign national governments. They can employ proper expertise, for the benefit of ordinary taxpayers – people who are sick of the stitch-ups that are outwitting this waddle of lame ducks – and maybe the lame duck-in-chief, Mr Juncker, could do the honourable thing and resign.

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, I have listened carefully to the honourable Members' opinions and questions and I thank them for this debate, which was both necessary and useful. The fight against tax fraud and tax avoidance is the priority of my mandate as Commissioner for Taxation and I will not stop repeating that. I will use every instrument at my disposal to achieve the concrete results that Europe needs, that citizens expect and that you ask for. Existing projects and new ideas like the automatic exchange of information, of tax rulings, will be fostered with strength and conviction. We are also going to look into the interesting proposals that have been raised today and I can assure each of you that every useful tool will be analysed and assessed. I will say a few words on two issues that have come up in several speeches. First, on country-by-country reporting. As you know, the Commission remains committed to an ambitious approach, which we will promote at the G20 as part of the OECD's work. I would also like to examine how transparency on advance tax rulings can also be achieved through obligations borne by recipient companies. The question of the optionality of the excise is, I readily admit. The Commission will need to re-examine how the project currently on the table can better respond to the fight against the erosion of taxable bases. I will refer this matter to the College.  In general, there is a question about the resumption of work on tax harmonization, which I want to get over. Several hypotheses exist and several forms of work exist. Either we take up proposals that are already on the table, or we take them up more sequentially or differently, or we rely on enhanced cooperation. I don't want to rule anything out here. Ladies and gentlemen, earlier, Mr Lamberts said that I had a reputation to make. That is not at all the meaning of what I want to do. I have a commitment to make it happen. I am very aware, through your various interventions, that there is a subject here - the fight against tax evasion, the erosion of tax bases, tax evasion - which is decisive for the citizen, which is very sensitive to our opinions and which we have no right to shy away from. In the present circumstances, there are two answers to be given. The first, with regard to investigations, has been given: it is a question of letting things move forward with independence, in transparency, with all the diligence and vigilance that are desired and desirable. On this point, President Juncker has made commitments, of course, and Mrs Vestager will be keen to keep them in office. The second is that we have to be, on the subjects we are talking about now, the fight against tax evasion, extremely offensive, extremely ambitious. That is the meaning of what I want to do in the performance of the duties that have been assigned to me. We will have to talk about all this, often, through legislation that will be gradually presented to the European Parliament. I have of course the tone of the political debates, have no doubt about the determination of this Commission and about mine, personal, to engage in this fight.

name: La Présidente. -
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Is there ever a single discussion in the European Parliament which is not used as an excuse to call for ‘more Europe’? I can hardly believe the calls for tax harmonisation, as though the European Union were in a position to make matters better rather than worse. Jean-Claude Juncker does not have the best of records in this area, and he is President of the Commission. I recall that he told a journalist ‘When things get serious, it’s time to lie.’ So early in his term, have things already got serious for Mr Juncker?

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The tax practices referred to in the "Luxleaks" dossier are likely to profoundly challenge the foundations of European integration among citizens. Indeed, how can we demand more and more effort from citizens and workers when large companies in the Union have mechanisms in which they can benefit from a derisory tax? This is at a time when more than 124 million Europeans are at risk of poverty. Fiscal and social injustices are entangled and unacceptable. The President of the Commission, formerly head of the Luxembourg government, must act decisively in the implementation of a programme aimed at genuine transparency and harmonisation at EU level. But the Commission must also quickly complete the ongoing investigations into several tax cases. All of this must be planned in an extremely tight and rigorous timetable. The Member States will then have to reveal themselves. Their governments will have to unanimously approve the Commission's proposals. The masks will then fall off. We will be intransigent at the level of the Socialist Group. The European project has no future if it is based on fiscal and social injustices.

name: Paul Brannen (S&D)
text: in writing. – The situation regarding Luxembourg and tax raises once again the issue of tax dodging and tax havens. International tax evasion and avoidance not only threaten fiscal stability, by making it harder for governments to balance the books, they also undermine social justice, by pushing more of the tax burden onto low- and middle-income households who already bear the brunt of austerity measures. In addition, tax abuses undermine economic efficiency by allowing inefficient tax-dodging companies to out-compete better, more responsible rivals – often the smaller, domestic firms that typically provide the majority of employment. Corporate tax wars also pose a substantial threat. An EU-wide floor on corporate tax rates could prevent some of the worst excesses of a race to the bottom. Much of the damage, however, stems from ‘competition’ to make it easy for companies to shift in, at low or no tax, their profits made elsewhere. Here the EU’s longstanding proposal for a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base, and the intra-EU allocation of taxable profits according to the location of actual economic activity, could have powerful effects in curtailing the gaming of the system.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. – Disclosures regarding secret tax arrangements between the Luxembourg government and several well-known multinationals show that the internal market is threatened by anti-competitive practices that use fiscal competition and opacity to distort the allocation of productive factors and impair tax collection and the maintenance of welfare policies. Meanwhile, many States have raised taxes on workers and cut social spending as part of the budget consolidation process. That these so-called agreements were secret calls into question the legality of them. The Competition Commissioner should open information proceedings as soon as possible. This scandal known as Lux Leaks must be the turning point for a change in the fight against tax evasion, avoidance and tax evasion in Europe, which must result in the total disappearance of tax havens within the European Union, the automatic exchange of information, the definitive harmonisation of corporation tax and the creation of a specific European tax. That is why I ask the European Commission to put in place the necessary measures to achieve these objectives as soon as possible.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. – One of the main tax challenges currently facing EU Member States is the fight against tax fraud. Effective measures to this end can improve the effectiveness of tax collection and play an important role in increasing tax revenues, as higher vat collection is one of the possible fiscal consolidation measures. At this difficult time, in which all EU countries are making considerable efforts to effectively consolidation public finances, I can only personally welcome any initiative that can support these efforts, whether on the revenue or expenditure side of the budget. Since VAT fraud is a sophisticated international crime that harms public finances, I believe that effective cooperation between the tax authorities of the Member States is necessary in particular to eradicate it. I would therefore welcome greater efforts by the EU institutions to organise activities that would make a positive contribution to this cooperation. I believe that the introduction of a rapid response mechanism would have an impact on the duration of the approval process for specific measures implemented by Member States to combat tax fraud and could increase the likelihood of effective handling of these types of action.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. – It is with concern I note that, when he was Prime Minister of Luxembourg, Mr Juncker appears to have supported a policy of tax avoidance. To regain his credibility and that of the European Commission, effective measures are urgently needed to bring an end to fiscal dumping once and for all.  It is a longstanding disgrace that multinationals are able to get away with contributing as little as 1% in taxes because some Member States are going out of their way to have them set up shop within their borders. It is unacceptable that these companies are literally taking a free ride on state-funded roads and infrastructure while receiving support for research and development and demanding protection when they are in trouble, without contributing their share. This is fundamentally unfair, to Member States suffering under extreme austerity rules, to tax payers who are continuously asked to shoulder a bigger burden while losing EUR 1000 billion a year to tax evasion, and to smaller businesses who have to drop out of the race because they simply cannot compete with powerful multinationals exploiting every single loophole. It is time to close the holes and cracks in legislation and harmonise fiscal policies between Member States.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. – Everyone has to pay taxes properly, including large companies. Tax evasion and avoidance lead to economic deficits which society then has to fill. That is why European rules are needed to combat tax avoidance. Moreover, companies operating in several countries should be open and understand the profits they have made and the taxes they pay on them by country. Worldwide, at least €14 trillion has been put away in tax havens, two thirds of which are even in bank accounts in EU countries, such as Luxembourg and the Netherlands. Much of this money has been sucked out of developing regions without paying tax. That is extra wry because with that tax, twice all extreme poverty can be eliminated. Tax avoidance by multinationals therefore affects the poorest in the world and Europe must act against it. The Party for Animals does not expect Juncker, a former Prime Minister of Luxembourg, to do so. Luxembourg (like the Netherlands, by the way) has always blocked European rules on openness about taxes paid. Is it likely then that he will go to war against the tax haven that he created and maintained himself?

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. – At the origin of the European model was the motto 'no taxation without representation'. Millions of Europeans are yelling at their representatives that there will be no fair representation without fair taxation; that is why this is the first political debate after Juncker's inauguration, to address the issue that best reflects the lousy state in which the EU finds: inequality and injustice in the distribution of sacrifices. And what is the source of that evil: inequity and tax avoidance and fraud and lenity with tax havens. That is why the notics of the Luxembourg agreements are not a surprise but are confirmation of something unacceptable. Workers pay their taxes but multinationals don't, and to top it all off they allow themselves to demand where they don't pay them. That has to stop and a ritual statement by Juncker is not enough to do that. We must investigate how we have come this far and action must be taken, and that requires transparent cooperation in tax matters between member states and harmonisation, but above all to ensure that large fortunes and multinationals are going to pay all their taxes, and not where they choose but where they generate profits.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – Tax evasion at European level amounts to almost EUR 1 trillion. An impressive amount that could have been used in the implementation of solutions and initiatives leading to job creation and social measures in the field of education and health. Tax evasion is theft! Tax havens are theft! Exploiting legal deprivation means theft! The Commission adopted a 30-point Action Plan in 2012. How many of these measures have been implemented? We need a European fiscal plan to combat this scourge. Cases of evasion must be identified, both today and in the past, both in Luxembourg and in other Member States, because sometimes errors and abuses in the past or in other countries have created market imbalances affecting Europe today. However, the fight against tax evasion also goes through better tax education and information. Europe must inform the taxpayer and assure him that his money is used correctly and in his interest.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – Tax avoidance schemes created in some Countries of the European Union cast a shadow over the Community as a whole and the European institutions. The President of the European Commission must therefore ensure that the necessary draft legislation is submitted to the Committees of the European Parliament as soon as possible to prevent further tax manipulation. Even if these proposals are not perfect, we cannot delay the process and start considering new proposals in principle later this year. Today, in the face of the ongoing economic crisis, it is necessary to restore citizens' confidence in Europe. All steps must therefore be taken to dismantle tax havens in the individual Member States of the Community. It is necessary to check the tax systems in each country, to establish a public register to expose obscure beneficiaries and prevent money laundering, ultimately to publicly identify certain countries and to press them not to block decisions in the Council of Europe that could contribute to the restriction of tax avoidance.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. – Tax evasion and the fight against tax havens are a major issue in today's Europe. On the one hand, there are cuts and a dingy public finances, and on the other hand, huge corporate tax evasion where taxes are not paid, as well as tax dumping among EU countries. The situation has been and is unsustainable in the long term. The Social Democrats have long drawn attention to the problem of tax evasion and this has been one of the serious issues of the EP elections. We therefore want Mr Juncker to make clear what he will do specifically as President of the European Commission against tax evasion and tax havens in the next five years. Public scrutiny and political pressure are the only guarantees that something will finally happen to tax evasion and the problem will not be watered down. And also that we will deal with really important things in Europe.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – I do not want to deal with the events of the past, but I want us to finally find political answers to the future, not legal answers to the past, for the next four and a half years. The previous Commission always answered my questions with the word 'this rule'. However, if the public perception of a case is that it's not right, then why don't we change it? It is the responsibility of the Commission, the European Parliament and the Council to look for real problems. It is not right, for example, for Member States to treat tax in such a differentiated way in the EU. There is another good example of this: food, where VAT is 0 % in some Member States and 27 % in Hungary. As far as corruption is concerned, I believe that the Competition Commissioner must play a leading role in reducing corruption by all means, while also taking into account that this does not always come from the level of companies, but sometimes governments can also be involved in corruption.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – (20) We condemn the absolutely cynical way in which the Commission assumes the alleged legality of tax agreements with the Member States and, in particular, with Luxembourg. While the Commission was using austerity and impoverishment, cuts in wages, pensions, health, education and social security, brutal tax increases on the general population, the current President of the European Commission was responsible for secret deals with hundreds of multinationals to save them millions from paying taxes. It has deprived states of hundreds of billions of euros of tax revenue owed to them and which they have so much lacked and do for the financing of the social state. After the scandal, the real meaning of the debate is now being diverted and the need for fiscal harmonisation in the European Union is being defended. A hollow debate, which omits, among other things, the existence of tax havens. If they really wanted to change the current state of things, that's where they started.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The noise surrounding the "revelations" about Luxembourg's tax agreements with monopoly groups for preferential tax treatment, under the prime ministership of the current Commission President Z.K. Younger, reflects the sharpening of monopoly competition within the EU. At the same time, attempts are being made to cover up the substance. That is to say, this is the result of the freedom of movement of capital, established by the Maastricht Treaty, which in Greece voted for SW, PASOK and the ancestor of SYRIZA, PLUS. In the apocalyptic debate in the European Parliament, Unger argued that Luxembourg's tax agreements are all "legitimate", in line with the Treaties and EU law. That is why it is provocative for the political forces that serve and support the EU by all means to now declare themselves 'surprised' and 'indignant'. All kinds of tax exemptions and the provocative privileges of large capital by civil governments and EU institutions are enshrined in national and EU laws and treaties for all Member States. The EU was founded and operates to serve the giant monopolies and boost their profitability at the expense of the peoples, a form of which is tax exemptions in capital on the one hand, and the savage taxation of workers on the other.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský  (PPE)
text: in writing. – The LuxLeaks affair showed us three crucial things. Multinational companies can pay 1% in corporate tax whereas SMEs have to pay even 35% in some EU countries. Paying 1% was legal, the big companies have not breached any rule. Tax avoidance structures were extremely complex and non-transparent. What lesson did we learn? Hard, complicated or national rules will not help to fix the problem. We need simple European rules which discourage tax avoidance. The big and the small must have ‘the same tax costs’ otherwise European SMEs cannot compete with big multinationals. We need rules which combine transparency and responsibility. We need rules rewarding those who pay their fair share and punish those who engage in tax avoidance.

name: Preşedinte. -
text: The next item is the debate on the Court of Auditors' annual report – 2013 (2014/2867(RSP)). I want to begin with to welcome the President of the Court of Auditors, Mr da Silva Caldeira. Besides, I would first like to give the word to Mr da Silva Caldeira. Mr. Caldeira, you have the floor.

name: Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira
text: President of the European Court of Auditors. - Madam President, honourable Members, Vice-President Georgieva, it is an honour to present the Court’s annual report on the 2013 financial year to this plenary session of the European Parliament. This is an important moment of change for Europe. A new European Commission is facing many important challenges. One of those challenges is to improve the management of the European Union budget.  At the start of this new spending period, the Court’s annual report says that the European Union’s financial management is not yet good enough overall. The European Union financial managers are responsible not only for spending the money; they must also ensure that expenditure complies with the rules and gets results. As regards spending the European Union budget, over EUR 148 billion worth of payments were made from the European Union budget in 2013. The Court concludes that those transactions were properly accounted for in 2013, which means that we have now signed off a clean audit opinion on the reliability of the accounts every year since 2007. But despite the high level of payments, which were almost 99% of the maximum available for the year, outstanding financial obligations rose by a further EUR 9 billion up to EUR 322 billion during 2013. This is a sign of the growing pressure on European Union cash-flows. The Commission should prepare appropriate cash-flow forecasts to anticipate potential funding shortages for European Union programmes. At the same time, it should also take care to ensure that funding from the European Union budget reflects real cash-flow needs. For example, less than half of the European Union funds paid into financial engineering instruments since 2007 had actually reached financial beneficiaries by the end of 2013. The European Union budget gets spent but too many payments are still not in compliance with the rules. The estimated error rates for payments has been significantly above the ‘materiality threshold’ of 2% for all the years the Court has audited the European Union accounts. In 2013 the Court estimates that the overall error rate is 4.7% compared to 4.8% in 2012. All areas of expenditure were affected by a material level of error. The only exception was the EUR 10.6 billion the European Union spent on its own administration. The Court estimates that the error rate is higher in shared management by the Commission and Member States than in other areas mostly directed by the Commission. Furthermore, although corrective action by the Commission and national authorities helps to keep the overall rate down, significantly more could have been done to prevent errors in the first place. For example, the Court’s error rate in rural development could, in principle, have been reduced from 6.7% to 2.0%, if national authorities had used all the information they had at their disposal before submitting claims to the Commission for reimbursement. The main sources of error that national authorities should watch out for are ineligible claims, serious breaches of public procurement, and incorrect declarations of agricultural areas.  In the Court’s view, the Commission and Member States authorities should concentrate more on preventing such errors that arise for these reasons not least because they put at risk the efficiency and effectiveness of the European Union’s spending. During the 2007-2013 programming period, the managers of the European funds focused primarily on spending the money available, secondly on complying with the rules, and only then – and to a limited extent – did they focus on achieving results. This needs to change. Our annual report provides many examples, drawn from among the 19 special reports the Court adopted in 2013, to show how better focus on results could enhance performance. In this context, the Court welcomes Commission initiatives to move from a culture of spending towards a culture of performance. In the Court’s view, that culture of performance will require first a genuine commitment at European Union and national level to getting the best results possible with limited resources; second, that suitable targets for the results to be achieved as well as reliable information on progress towards achieving them are set; and third, and most important, there needs to be the right incentives to reward good performance and to sanction poor performance. Up to now the European Union financial managers have primarily been under pressure to spend the money or risk losing it. And lastly, it will also be essential to make the overall results achieved with the European Union money more visible. In particular, the European Commission should improve the coverage given in its annual evaluation report to the European added value of the European Union budget and to progress made towards achieving the Europe 2020 targets. European Union financial management improvement is not choosing between spending the money, complying with the rules, and getting results. It is about managing to do all three at once and making the European Union budget more manageable by clear rules, clear objectives and simple arrangements for spending the money. As I hope the Court’s 2013 annual report shows, our institution is fully committed to assisting this Parliament and the other three quarters to achieve valuable results for the European citizens.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Madam President, I would like to start by reiterating in this plenary our appreciation for the comprehensive report the Court has presented and for its constructive recommendations. The Court identified an error rate for 2013 of most likely 4.7%. This is still quite a way away from the 2% materiality threshold that we are aspiring for, but it is a notch lower than last year, where it was 4.8%, and most importantly, what we see is that the previous years’ trend of the rate increasing has been stopped, during a year of a record high EUR 148 billion of Commission-supported implemented programmes. I truly hope that we are seeing the result of efforts that my colleagues in the Commission have been putting in over the last few years, taking advantage of the recommendations of the Court. But if I am to say what to me is the most important message, it is that we must persevere, we must continue this work. Secondly, we are very comforted by the fact that we can reassure our citizens and our staff that the accounts are free from material mis-statements. This is the seventh year in a row, and this is, I believe, a very positive outcome of the work we have been doing, that the error rate on what we manage in the Commission is below the 2% threshold, and that commitments in all areas of expenditure receive a positive opinion.  As in the past, the Court leads us to focus on areas of shared management – cohesion policy and agriculture in particular – and as in the past we are reminded in the report that there is a factor that is obviously impacting errors, namely very complicated rules in public procurement, in state aid, in eligibility. This presents a risk that the Court directs us to address.  We are mindful that we have to intensify efforts with Member States; that this is where the biggest bang for the buck will come if we want to achieve better results in future years. And we also want to remind honourable Members that we have a particular problem still to address, and it is the multiannual nature of our programmes versus the annual nature of the Court’s reports; that very often we face a situation where corrections are made in future years, but are not captured in the year the report is presented. Just to illustrate this difference between the annual error rate and the residual error rate: over the last five years the amount of financial corrections was on average 2.2% of all payments. In other words, this would have reduced the error rate. But I do not want to defend where we are, because what is most important is to look forward, and looking forward I want to make two substantive points. One is that for the 2014-2020 programing period we have introduced new rules around three main principles: simplification, simplified cost options to reduce administrative burden and, as the Court highlights, to reduce risks of errors; ownership, to foster responsibility in shared management among national authorities – and also we want to promote political ownership at the highest national level; and incentives: net financial correction is a very strong incentive for proper control systems, and this is where we want to be for the next programming period. My second substantive point is to very much embrace the recommendation of the Court to focus on performance and to build and nurture a genuine culture of performance. This would be at the centre of my attention; this would be at the centre of my actions. I intend to work very closely with my colleagues in the Commission, with Member States and all other financial actors in this direction. I also would like to assure Parliament that we are taking very seriously and taking to heart the recommendation you have made to us to set up an interinstitutional working group on performance. Virtually in the next few weeks we will pursue the setting up of this group. We have no time to waste! Our citizens expect us to demonstrate that we take good care of the money they give us to serve their interests. From me, President Caldeira, a very firm commitment for a partnership with the Court, walking on two legs – compliance and performance – to achieve results.

name: Ingeborg Gräßle
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Mr President of the Court of Auditors, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President of the Court of Auditors for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The most disturbing finding by the Court of Auditors – among others in this thick report – is what you have said, namely that results – what we achieve with the money – are that these results come only in third place, that spending money is the most important thing, and, Commissioner, if you manage to tackle it, then you are my heroine! But I am afraid that things will continue as before, because I have already heard the other ten times, namely that everything will be different with the next MFF.  Why do we not know what we have achieved with European money, what results we have achieved? Youth unemployment: what have we achieved in the fight against it? Roma, integration: what have we achieved? Instead, because we can talk so little about results, we're beating each other with error rates, but it's also important because it shows us how administration works. And I have many questions: why is the Error Rate of the Court of Auditors in the Regional Funds so significantly different from that of the Directorate-General for Regional Policy: 2.8% and 6.9%? Or in rural development: the Court of Auditors says 6.7% and the Directorate-General for Agriculture 5.19%. Is this because the Directorates-General are rushing to protect the funds from criticism? Are we dealing with an inherent conflict of interest? You really have something to do with this, Commissioner.  And I also have a few other questions. Financial instruments: Why do only 47% of the funds reach the final beneficiaries? And then there is the state of the fight against fraud: that is a pity when this Office sees its first task in the fight against supervision rather than in the results. And that will soon be your problem, because that is where the grace period expires.  I would like to raise the third point, which is that the authorities in the Member States have given false information. We see the Commission's annual activity reports by the Directors-General as making extensive corrections, and that is why the question arises as to whether, as in the euro area, we need sanctions for false reporting, for false reporting by the Member States.

name: Inés Ayala Sender
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, welcome, Mrs Georgieva, to this new task. And thank you very much, Mr Caldeira, for the efforts of the Court of Auditors, for the new analyses, for the new projects and for the new proposals, wise and courageous. We therefore have a new Commission. This is a new Parliament and a new budget period. And with the same crisis for seven years, it has already become like a biblical plague, and persevering. Therefore, we also have new challenges: An increasingly limited budget, with payment problems. I've never seen him before. A programme, a promise of Mr Juncker's programme: 300 billion for investments, but with difficult and complex financial engineering formulas, which the Court of Auditors itself warns us about and which will have to be monitored, Mrs Georgieva.  On the other hand, the control of banking instruments, which is becoming more and more difficult and on which we will have to work together with the economic authorities of the Union. And new alarms in income and own resources. The Court of Auditors again tells us that there are problems of credibility, of setting up the GDP of the Member States. We are fueling an increasingly deficit budget and becoming worse-controlled customs, making these own resources also in deficit. Therefore, we have great concerns, not only with regard to expenditure, but essentially also in revenue. Anyway, I thank Mr Caldeira, the Court of Auditors, for pointing out what we have spent on a European budget for 2013: EUR 290 per capita per year. And, of those EUR 290 per person per year that the Union budget has spent, there is only material error — only, even though no euro is liable for error — at EUR 13.6 per person per year. It may seem like little, but even that little is enough to make the work of further deepening and deepening control fundamental. However, I thank you once again for the Court of Auditors also working on trends and magnitudes. As has been said here, the common agricultural policy's EUR 45 billion is reducing the error by 0.2% and, on the other hand, rural development, being a smaller magnitude, we have a higher error rate: almost double, 6.7%, although it is slightly reduced. That is, they are different magnitudes and trends. That is why we are in favour and follow the Court of Auditors in its recommendation to go further towards a culture of results, but with incentives, rather than towards a culture of looking only at increasingly limited spending and increasingly with stronger sanctions that do not incentivize, but generate greater scouring to citizens and the administration.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! Thanks to Mr Caldeira, to Mr Lazarou, who is present with us. I am pleased that, for the first time, not at the hearing of the Committee on Budgetary Control, but in the European Parliament, is Vice-President Georgieva – congratulations on this function. I wanted to say that in the latest issue of the American weekly "Newsweek" there is such an interesting map that shows what are the main problems of each continent. As far as Europe is concerned, the issue of youth unemployment comes second, and this is what very large funds from the European Union are going for. Let me be honest, I am not sure that these funds are well used. I have the impression that on the contrary.  Ladies and again, it must be said – and this report says this, and it is good – that the financial management of the European Union is still not good, that it is necessary to improve the spending of these funds. The amount of receivables is increasing and will continue to rise. That is EUR 322 billion at the moment, and since the 2014 budget foresees commitments in excess of payments, of course this debt will continue to rise. There is no significant improvement in the level of error in payments. It was a little below 5% and it still is. I would point out that the two most vulnerable areas of spending are regional policy and rural development. It is so important that this is what the poorer countries – the countries of the new Union – benefit greatly from. And this, of course, poses a certain threat for the future. Once again, I thank the Court of Auditors for its work on this issue.

name: Ali Nedzhmi
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate the European Court of Auditors for its readable Annual Report that delivers important insights for our attention. In this respect we should have in mind that the EU budget should have a robust and consistent system for assessment of Member State GNIs. Correct information in this area is indispensable because the GNI-based own resources form approximately 70% of the EU budget. From that point of view, for me it is strange that the European Court of Auditors has found such a big amount of discrepancies in the work done by the Commission concerning not only its verification strategy, but also the verification process and the whole process of reporting. The Commission in its reply does not agree with most of the European Court of Auditors’ findings. Without going into details of the report, it seems to me that both entities have a completely different approach towards almost everything from a methodological, macroeconomic and managerial point of view.  In this respect I have some doubts. Firstly, after having the negative assessment of the work of the GNI Committee, which includes representatives from the Member States and is chaired by Eurostat, may we rely on the statistical information regularly delivered from these institutions? Secondly, while there are several well-known international organisations that distribute macroeconomic information for the countries in the world, for example, the IMF, World Bank and Eurostat, may we expect to have a sufficient level of similarity comparing the data from all these sources? Despite the abovementioned doubts in the situation, there is something positive. The Commission recognises the importance of the recommendations and agrees to follow them. Additionally, the execution of the European Union budget and the auditing should focus on results and on whether the set objectives are achieved and, in this way, the budget can be improved only if Member States coordinate their activities with local and regional authorities at the very beginning of the preparation of the programmes and procedures. The identification of best practice projects at European level also could be helpful.

name: Bart Staes
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – The facts are painfully clear to us. They are listed by most colleagues. But the key problem is that 80% of the funds are spent in shared management with the Member States and there are serious problems there. Member States do not assume their responsibility. Mr da Silva Caldeira made that clear. In most cases, the Member States know that mistakes are being made, but they do not act. He himself listed the error rate in the rural development, environment, fisheries and health sectors: 6.7%. Provided that member states act, this could have fallen to 2 %. I would add: regional policy, energy, transport, now 6.9%. If the Member States act, we will get to 3.9%. Employment and social affairs, now 3.1%. With the action of the Member States 1,8 %. It is clear that the Member States must act, that there must be an action plan, led by the Commission, by Mrs Georgieva. And the final piece of that must be a national declaration by the finance ministers. In federal Member States this should only be a compilation of statements by the finance ministers of the Länder, but it must be clear: as Finance Minister I have done my job, I have ensured that there was sufficient control. We acted where we had to. And if that doesn't happen, then that minister is politically responsible.

name: Marco Valli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to focus on the Court of Auditors' comments on the performance of structural funding. Since I'm new, I'd like to understand. What is the added value of the European Union in past years? Apparently, the Commission gives general guidelines and then the state actors define the projects. Unfortunately, the report shows that the Member States are unable to guarantee results on funding, because their first interest is to: one, spend the money so as not to lose it; two, to try to comply with the rules; three, only in the last resort, and not always, evaluate its impact and expected results. Allocating all these billions from the sacrifices of those who work and pay taxes and then achieve little, at a time of crisis and fiscal injustice such as this, rightly leads the taxpayer to believe that this European institution is useless and I would add harmful, because it creates an extra passage on the money that could now be managed directly by the Member States. Now I ask myself: how could you pretend not to see over the years? It almost seems that over the years, more than politics for the citizens of Europe, there has been an interest in split the cake in Europe, with political agreements between the parties, with the sole purpose of covering each other.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI). -
text: Madam President! I wonder why some people here do not have the blush on their faces, when, on the one hand, I look at Mr Juncker, who has created a tax haven in his country, where, on the other hand, the people of Europe have to take responsibility for default, and have to co-finance what your Commission President Juncker has done in his country. On the other hand, we are debating EUR 7 billion here, which the Court of Auditors has thankfully uncovered, where 4% of the European Union's funds have not been awarded lawfully, not properly. And I wonder: who takes responsibility where? Is it the people out there in the Chamber of Deputies who are taking responsibility for this EUR 7 billion? Or who else is prepared to take responsibility for this? 120 million people – almost a quarter of the European Union – are at risk of poverty. And it is not possible to deal with european union funds in this way. The conclusion is that the subsidies should be returned to national level, because no one other than the countries themselves has the right knowledge of how to use funds and how to control them.

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE). -
text: Madam President, first of all let me thank the European Court of Auditors and congratulate them. The annual report for the fiscal year 2013 sheds more light on the subject and creates more discussion than ever. According to the ECA, the overall error rate was 4.7% and, if the corrective measures which have already been implemented are taken into account, it was 6.3%. This is totally unacceptable. But I am afraid that what is actually more important is the quality, not the numbers. To give just one example of the reliability of the information the Member States are giving the Commission, the error rate in structural policy is – according to the Commission – just 2.8%. But, hang on, no, take a closer look – like the Court of Auditors did – and it is a whopping 6.9%. So one of the valuable observations in this report is that, in most cases, the national authorities in the Member States did have sufficient information to begin with. We have to fix this. The trail of auditing has to exist all the way down to programme level. For this to happen, we need full transparency of the information already available and simplification of the rules. With these we can concentrate – and we need to concentrate – on what Commissioner Georgieva said when the ECA annual report was presented to our committee ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D). -
text: Madam President, this will be the first budgetary discharge procedure seen by more than half of the new Members and also by a new Parliament. We also have, I may say, a brand new Commission. So we must use the opportunity to deliver clear messages.  We have to close the learning cycle, which some Court members are now discussing, to get the continuous improvement we all simply need. This is all about serious work and application, not about grabbing headlines. Error-free or clean expenditure is not an end in itself, it is very important but not nearly enough. EU money can be used entirely correctly according to the rules but it has to be well directed towards a clear objective – to deliver the growth and employment goals which are so important today.  Commissioner Georgieva and the rest of the new Commission must have the tools they need to measure the social impact and other results of EU programmes. Member States and regional authorities are our partners in this, and have to ensure that every cent of European funding is well targeted. Please remember: invest these means but do not spend these means. We need a debate on what constitutes good performance in different areas of allocation, therefore the interinstitutional working group on performance must involve players from the Commission and from Parliament, covering all key policy areas so we can quickly develop and implement a genuinely reliable concept of performance in the new funding programmes.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen (ECR). -
text: Madam President! Unfortunately, it is not new anymore that the European Court of Auditors cannot approve the accounts. There are simply too many flaws in it to meet the 2% threshold needed for the budget to be approved. Since this is not news, I would like to take on two other issues that are equally serious. Firstly, we do not get any real EU added value from what is being spent on the Union. It is a major problem that the Union has a huge budget, but that it is not in any way ensured that the money spent could not as well have been spent in the nation states. Secondly, we in the European Union have actually promised far more money away than we know we have in the budget in the coming years. The two things together constitute a huge bombshell in the EU budget, and if we do not start to take it seriously in this House, then we face a very difficult economic future. I hope that my colleagues are responsible, and that is the message that must come from me today.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD). -
text: Madam President,  sixty seconds is insufficient to do justice to this report. About EUR 7 billion mismanaged and thrown down the drain. We have got multinationals claiming small-business relief, farms claiming buildings as grazing land, and employees paid five times the going rate for jobs.  The mismanagement and fraud indicates a system rotten to the core. Every failure by a Member State is also a failure of the system itself, and even in projects administered by the Commission, there is still a 3.7% error rate. Last year, the Commission simply ignored 21% of the auditors’ recommendations. Only 79% were implemented in full or even in part. If a private business ignored auditors’ instructions, they would end up in jail, just like they would if they submitted error- riddled accounts for 19 years in a row.

name: Louis Aliot (NI). -
text: Madam President, I thank the Court of Auditors for the clarity of this report. The financial management of the European Union has still not been satisfactory. The Union spends its budget with the main concern of spending on expenditure, regardless of certain consequences and certain outcomes related to these expenditures. We also note expenses made in violation of the rules, modestly referred to by the Court as "errors", which are often the subject of proper fraud, particularly in the area of public procurement. This clearly raises the problem of corruption on some projects at European level. Add to this financial commitments that have yet to be liquidated in the order of EUR 322 billion, and you will understand why fewer and fewer citizens believe in this system. This situation is all the more shocking because the Commission allows itself to remonstrate with sovereign states on principles which it is unable to apply itself.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE). -
text: Dear President of the Court of Auditors, dear Commissioner Georgieva, dear colleagues, I would first like to thank the European Court of Auditors for the report on our table. I'd argue with several of my colleagues. This is a fair proposal that will enable the European Parliament to work. Secondly, I would like to recall once again the two most important figures that President Caldeira was kindly repeating: in 2013, we spent EUR 148 billion in the european Union budget. Some 4.7% of this amount did not comply with the rules, so the expenditure in the category of error is around EUR 7 billion. In this context, of course, we have a lot of work to do to examine the reasons for this in the discharge procedure that is just starting, but at the same time we have a very, very serious problem that we talk very little about. This is almost four times the amount of EUR 7 billion wrongly spent, and eur 25-30 billion is approaching the amount that the European Commission does not pay for properly implemented cohesion improvements. This means that the European Union's budget is thus completely unfounded.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the President of the Court of Auditors. I am sure that most colleagues in the room would welcome the fact that the Court has once again said that revenue and commitments were legal and regular. However, of course, a lot still needs to be done on payments. A 4.7% error rate is far too high. But I would emphasise – unlike other colleagues – that we are talking about errors and not fraud.  We also know that most of the errors take place at Member State level. This is borne out by the figures which show that the percentage of errors in shared management projects is much higher than the directly managed programmes. So we do need to do much more work with Member States, particularly those Member States who, year on year, are problematic.  I would welcome any ideas the new Commissioner has on this. How can we help Member States to reduce their error rate? Like others, I also wanted to comment on the issue of performance … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Richard Ashworth (ECR). -
text: Madam President, I found the negative statement of assurance continues to depress, but I took enormous encouragement from the positive approach taken by both the auditors and the Commissioner. Quite rightly they both said this is a new beginning, and quite rightly they expressed renewed determination to address longstanding problems. Specifically, they both referred to the need for culture change. I agree. But can I suggest that the start point for that culture change ought to be in this House. We are the directly elected representatives of the people. We are the House which determines the expenditure budget for taxpayers’ money. And yet for all the interest we show in the envelope of the budget, we have no powers to monitor the outcome of the budget. We have no powers to scrutinise Commission expenditure, and we have no mechanism to measure and evaluate value for money. Only when we can adopt those powers can we change that culture and thereby get on the road towards a positive statement of assurance.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President of the Court of Auditors for his presentation. I am aware from the annual report of the error rate which, since 2009, has been constantly increasing, demonstrating a systematic problem with a total value of EUR 30 billion. I find it unacceptable that there should also be such significant errors in the European administrative field. Pensions, salaries, allowances and expenditure relating to buildings should not be subject to any error. At a time of historic economic crisis, when the citizens of Europe are being asked for austerity, we have a duty to carefully monitor every single expenditure, every contract, and to reduce the construction of new European buildings as much as possible. We therefore hope, together with my group, that the new President Juncker, who is so attentive to luxembourg's tax avoidance and optimisation, will be equally attentive to the recommendations of the Court of Auditors.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (NI). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, starting my speech, I wanted to greet some 70 mayors of the Piedmont Region, who are here accompanied by my colleague Cirio. Mayors are the starting point of a democracy, an institution, and they are always in the trenches when there is trouble. So thanks to the mayors who are here, who represent the best of Italian institutions. In my small speech, since I only have one minute, I wanted to point out that in my previous experience as a Member of Parliament I was at the Antimafia, in Italy, and I had the opportunity to meet the Anti-Mafia Prosecutor Pietro Grasso, who has now become President of the Senate. He told us that the Mafia is no longer, as one might think in the film "The Godfather", only in Sicily rather than in other areas south of Italy, but goes where the money is, where there are big interests. So it comes to mind, hearing the EUR 7 billion in the Court of Auditors' report, that the Mafia is also here, that the Mafia is in Luxembourg, that the Mafia is then involved in all the crap it does in Europe, because where there is crap there is the Mafia. So my proportion is: Europe sucks the same... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Claudia Schmidt (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! The 2013 budget report confronts us with an error rate of 4.7%, a figure that would have amounted to as much as 6.3% without the financial corrections made. And although the probable error rate has fallen by 0.1% compared to the previous year, 6.3% is nevertheless primarily intheme of incorrectly spent budgets. As the main weakness of the European Development Fund, the Court of Auditors again mentioned the control systems analysed in the course of the audit of the regularity of transactions. The shortcomings in ex ante controls are worrying, as they should be used to prevent, detect or correct irregular payments in advance. I do not have to explain the current financial situation; we all know that this cannot continue. It is time to send out a signal and to use and strengthen the control mechanisms at our disposal.  This annual report is the twentieth of its kind, and it is a regrettable, if not frightening, circumstance that, after twenty years of monitoring, review and support for the European Court of Auditors, the Member States and the Commission are still unable to spend the budget properly and without a significant error rate. We must take action here, because we are spending European taxpayers' money, and nothing harms us more than the illegitimate use of these funds. After all, as carefully as you manage your private money, you want to know how you use the European Union's budget!

name: Jens Geier (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I agree with the general thanks to the Court of Auditors for this report. We have seen that the error rate in the implementation of the EU budget has fallen slightly this year, compared to 4.8% in the lead-up to the eu." But is the previous year really the only benchmark that we need to consider? I think no. Anyone who is familiar with European Union funding knows that the expenditure curves develop differently over the course of a programming period. In other words, there are fewer payments at the beginning, and the more projects approved by the Member States, the more payments increase. It is therefore worth taking a look at where we actually stood seven years ago, at the same point of the 2000-2006 funding period. If you do that, you will see that at that time the error rate was at least 7.3%. In other words, the error rate today, at the end of the 2007-2014 funding period, is 2.6 percentage points, or more than a third lower than it was seven years ago. I think this is a political success. What else can be done to further reduce the error rate? This is where the member states are responsible. I quote from the Court of Auditors' report, because it is obviously necessary for some Members to really hear the original document: 'In the case of a significant number of errors, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the error'. We could have reduced the error rate in rural development to 2%.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR). -
text: Once again, the European Court of Auditors has found billions in errors. For the 20th year in a row, it is once again said that there are mistakes, and nothing will change again. These are only errors relating to expenditure in breach of the rules. It is not at all found that how much expenditure was nonsensical. The European Court of Auditors notes that the first thing is to spend money, secondly, to make it with some administrative rules, and only then is it resolved whether it makes sense at all. This is all ins a coma. This is not the idea on which Europe stands – taking money from taxpayers and giving it back. After all, there is no point in politicians playing Jesus – they take people's money and give it to some others. Spending needs to be misrepresented. The common agricultural policy is a survival of the last century. It needs to be repealed. That's $50 billion. Also Euro funds. They only bring evil to those countries.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE). -
text: Madam President, I would like to comment on this annual report of the European Court of Auditors. This is a sad fact that we must mention here, but it is clear from the annual report that the European Commission suffers from poor financial management syndrome, and we must urgently face up to this problem and work in the new period to cure this ill. I see one major problem here, especially in the underdeveloped priorities. When spending the European budget, it is primarily about spending all available resources, and it seems that whether these spendings are taking place in accordance with the rules is not in the spotlight. It is no longer a question of whether or not the projects financed by the budget achieve the objectives set or have any added value. High error rates, low levels of effective internal control, lack of integrity and inconsistency are the main symptoms of poor financial management. However, Member States are also to blame for this situation, do not provide true data, and some of them contribute deliberately to new errors thanks to a lax approach and some deliberately contribute to new errors.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Georgieva, thank you, Mr da Silva Caldeira, for an in-depth report. It is therefore absolutely essential to investigate all the causes of such a high error rate, not least in order to understand why the financial corrections have not worked properly and, if necessary, to rationalise the spending mechanisms in the ways suggested by the Court itself. However, I am most concerned about two other aspects: the effectiveness of expenditure and the gap between commitments and payments made, which has led to the accumulation of liabilities that will have serious repercussions on future payments within the framework of the multiannual European programmes. On these two aspects, Mrs Georgieva, I believe it is necessary for the European Commission to act quickly and incisively, making it a priority of its work in the coming months.

name: Wim van de Camp (PPE). -
text: I would like to thank the President of the European Court of Auditors and the Commissioner for her words. You will not be surprised if I agree with Mrs Gräβle's critical tone. Is something really going to change in the next few years? That is the central question. A error rate that drops from 4.8% to 4.7%, with all due respect, is too little for the European citizen. We cannot, to put it this matter as popularly, come home with that. We have lost EUR 7 billion and I certainly do not agree with colleagues who say that this money went to the mafia, but with this money we could improve half the backlog of German infrastructure. My question to the Commissioner is therefore: what are we going to do in the coming years, especially to the Member States? Because the Member States play a much bigger role here than we think. I again call for your attention - we did it at the hearings - for the national management statement. The Member States have a greater responsibility in spending European money than we think here in Brussels. Finally, Mr President, the question of simplification. It can be simpler for both requests and checkout. [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Jens Geier (S&D)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr van de Camp, I know you as a serious colleague. That is why I have asked to speak because I believe that you have made a mistake. You have claimed that EUR 7 billion is gone. I will read to you what the Court says about this. The Court says: "The error rate estimated by the Court is not a measure of fraud, inefficiency or waste. It is an estimate of the funds that should not have been disbursed." Against this background, would you kindly withdraw your statement that EUR 7 billion has disappeared?

name: Wim van de Camp (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. That is indeed an clarification of my position. That seven billion - the colleague is right - has not disappeared, but has been spent incorrectly. Thank you very much.

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I thank the auditors for this report, and the vital and often insufficiently appreciated work that they do. Frankly, this Chamber should be significantly fuller than it actually is. Whilst I agree with my group colleagues on this report that a performance approach on control is important, I think we must not forget the key issue of absorption. It is still very important in terms of use of funds. In the UK we are below the EU average for a proper absorption of funds, and this is important. In reality, in overall terms, this means, for example, that youth guarantee money, flood help, supporting redundant workers, all of these things in reality could be made much better use of, as well as the funds that are specifically looked at and addressed by this report. And in answer to the colleague over there, it is absolutely not true that EU money is a waste. It is good value for money. If you look at the UK public accounts there are major qualifications … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). -
text: Madam President, there is more hypocrisy in the European Commission. A European Commission which, as a member of the troika, shakes its finger at Greece and the countries of the European south and demands a violent financial adjustment and dismissals of civil servants on the grounds that they are supposedly inadequate, while the Commission itself cannot put its own house in order and check its own officials for cases of inadequate financial management explicitly mentioned in the Court of Auditors' report. : Who takes responsibility for the EUR 7 billion paid unduly? What will you say, gentlemen of the Commission, to the millions of unemployed in the European south about the scandals described in the report, about corruption in the award of works, about the waste of resources, about maladministisation, about how expenditure will take place? The Commission's financial management is therefore not justified and satisfactory, we have had rule violations and a plethora of errors.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE). -
text: Of course, I, too, welcome the report of the European Court of Auditors, and I consider it extremely important that this institution reviews every year the correctness and performance of european funds.  But I would like to draw attention to one thing: the management of the EU budget could, of course, be much better than it is. The Court of Auditors also notes this. Above all, we must make it easier to manage the budget if the objectives are clearer and the rules are simpler.  And this seems to me to be one of the commission's essential guidance for further work. It would also be good to review those rules that are too complex and which do not allow for the appropriate use of public funds and become a barrier rather than an incentive, because no rules will ever be able to prevent bad intentions from being broken and bypassed, and many rules can prevent a good purpose for respecting them, and I therefore propose... (The President interrupted the speaker.)

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD). -
text: Madam President, I sit on the Committee on Regional Development; we have gone through some of the discrepancies that show up and I accept that many of them are actually not anything sinister or malicious, they are genuine mistakes that get made.  I think it is important is that we find a way for the system to allow for a more clear way of understanding, where people cannot get so confused. I actually believe that a vast majority of the discrepancies are done in good faith, but it is still taxpayers’ money, and if we have a system where people do not really understand what they are doing, there is a possibility that fraud could come through, and on a grand scale. While money is tight for all of us around Europe and every country is desperate to ensure the cash is used properly, I think there needs to be some work done to make sure that whatever money does go through this place is used properly and there are no errors or mistakes in the process.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI). -
text: Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support In your speech, you literally said that citizens expect us, i.e. the European Commission, to demonstrate that we take care of their money. What is your personal opinion, Commissioner, on how citizens can believe this when your committee and the European Commission are led by a man who has practically been proven to have entered into secret agreements with foreign multinationals in his own country, Luxembourg, about the fact that they do not have to pay virtually any taxes there in Luxembourg, thereby taking a sea of money out of the pockets of his own compatriots. and put its own small and medium-sized enterprises in an extremely poor competitive position? Goats with cabbage? Is that the kind of person people trust, citizens, with their money? Don't you personally think you should resign? And a professional question. If everything was as good as Mr Juncker claimed... (the President interrupts the speaker)

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D). -
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in its annual report on the financial year 2013, the European Court of Auditors warns that the budgetary system is excessively focused on the quantitative aspect of expenditure. We note that in the period 2007-2013 priority was given exclusively to the amount of expenditure, secondly to compliance with the legislation and only ultimately and to a limited extent to results and impact. Honestly, an estimated expense error of about 4.7% is too much. I have to say, however, that I am satisfied with what Commissioner Georgieva has said. He said well: there is no time to waste. It is therefore necessary to perfect the spending mechanisms and pay close attention to the quality of the same, passing as they say to the culture of performance. I also very much appreciated the reference to debureaucratisation and transparency, which are the other side of the coin. There is no time to lose, but we must not get lost in proclamations. I hope that the Commission will really accept the Court of Auditors' recommendations and take the necessary steps, ushering in a new season in the management of European funds.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI). -
text: Madam President! Every year, like Christmas, the Court of Auditors' report is available. Thank you very much to the dedicated staff who provide us with a lot of good material! However, it is shocking to me – and I have been following these reports and the discussion for five years – that the Court of Auditors' proposals are consistently ignored. And they have very good proposals, for example to review the practical benefits of the money invested and not just formal criteria. We should not lie to ourselves, because the forms of the report are not meaningful, and the actual achievement of the objectives is not a priority. We promote things that do not meet other obligations: environmental protection, animal welfare are mentioned here, cross-compliance problems. In this context, ladies and gentlemen, the Union reminds me of a thick, cumbersome oil tanker that is moving at full speed, but which is unable to quickly correct its course. And what is even more shocking is that there is a captain on the command bridge who does not want to change this course!

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. - Madam President, I want to start by expressing my appreciation for the comments that have been made. There were very clear messages from the rapporteur – the three points that we heard – and also from many who have expressed their desire to see better financial management for the sake of delivering to our people. Let me make three points: One: what exactly is an error rate? This is what it is: errors. Some of this may be mismanagement of funds, some of it may be misrecording, and a small percentage – to be exact 0.2% – is actually money stolen. Of course, 0.2% is 0.2% too much, but we must not confuse the errors that are genuine clerical errors with mismanagement and, even worse, fraud. We have to be clear in our minds what we are talking about, because if we do not define the problem accurately, we will not be able to solve it. My second point is: what are we doing about it? For the majority of errors that are exactly that – errors – we are relentlessly investing with Member States in the training of people who deal with European money. We find this to be a task that deserves even more attention, because if we have people who understand and apply the rules, then the error rate goes down – and we have plenty of evidence that well implemented training programmes lead to a reduction of error rates – then people leave and the error rate jumps up, so this human factor is very important. We are also providing strong incentives in the new programming period: positive incentives – 6% of the money set aside to reward good performance; and negative incentives – more severe clawing-back of funds when there is inappropriate management of EU money. We are doing a lot, and we are keen to do more in simplification of rules. We now have eligibility rules harmonised across different areas, but I can tell you that yesterday I met with my fellow Commissioners who are colleagues in spending areas, to discuss how we can take this forward because it is really important, as the Court told us. My third point is: Do we take this report seriously? Yes. And the Court told us in Special Report No 19/2013 that the Commission adequately follows up the Court’s recommendations and that the Court’s review of a sample of recommendations showed that these, being implemented by the Commission, have improved financial management. We too intend to take this report very seriously, especially in this shift we need to make from a strictly compliance-based culture to combining efforts in compliance with very strong emphasis on performance. I will be here next year and the year after, and I hope that we will have results to report. More than hope; I pledge there will be results to report.

name: Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira
text: président de la Cour des comptes. - Madame la Présidente, Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, j'aimerais d'abord vous remercier pour les propos bienveillants que vous avez adressés à la Cour des comptes pour son travail. Je crois que tous ceux qui ont œuvré à ces rapports vous en remercient. I would like to address some of the points that were raised in this debate, not because the Court was directly asked to answer, but because I think we need to have a clear idea what needs to be done. In our report we state clearly that we need to change this culture of using the funds because they are available and because otherwise we risk losing them, not having the possibility to use them. We need to make the systems work more effectively. We have shown in our report that the Member States have information to prevent those claiming reimbursement of funds from the European Union funds from making those claims. That is the primary concern. If you want the Member States’ authorities and the European Commission to do their job fully, they need to increase this preventive action.
