And we are talking about reasonable arrangements, and we have gone against all logic, sanctions against Russia. So what are we talking about instead of doing? Turkish actions in the EEZ of Cyprus constitute direct aggression against the European Union. No discussion and action until Turkey withdraws the research vessel and warships from the region, proceeds to abolish the pseudo-state and officially recognises the Republic of Cyprus.  Turkey has already revealed its true self when it comes to the jihadists of the Islamic caliphate. A super-aggressive, expansive and aggressive country-bubble, with syndromes of Ottomanism of the past. Finally, it's time to stop put up with her, finally let's pull her ear.

name: Ελένη Θεοχάρους (PPE). -
text: Ladies and gentlemen, you have raised very important aspects of the Cyprus problem and I would like to thank you very much. Commissioner, I repeat to you for the umpteenth time that the problem is not between the two communities: the problem is Turkey, which illegally holds military, with the power of its weapons, territories of the Republic of Cyprus and is currently trying to occupy the seas of the Republic of Cyprus. Turkey's actions have been declared illegal by the United Nations, by the Council of Europe, by European Courts, you told us a moment ago by the Commission, by the Council. Turkey does not understand calls, Commissioner. It is not possible to make appeals at a time when the other sends his battleships and submarines into the sea of Cyprus. What we are calling for is for Turkey to be condemned and for practical measures to be taken against it, economic and political sanctions, and for accession talks to be suspended in accordance with the declaration of 21 September, with which both the European Union and the European Parliament are committed. Turkey builds a wall worse than the Berlin Wall and divides the people of Cyprus in two and divides the territories of Cyprus in two. We must recognise this reality and help the Republic of Cyprus to stand in solidarity with the Republic of Cyprus at a time when it cannot cope with the power of arms. Weapons do not create justice, Commissioner. Guns only impose illegality. (Applause)

name: Richard Howitt (S&D). -
text: Madam President, I fully support the Cypriot colleagues in my own S&D Group who rightly seek to raise a concern affecting their own national sovereignty and concerning proper support for rules of international law, and I am a joint signatory to this resolution.  I say to our Turkish friends, we in Parliament join with Commissioner Hahn when he calls on Turkey to show restraint and to avoid any further actions which could cause friction, but I also welcome the Commissioner talking in his speech tonight about the Turkish European perspective and the deeper, wider and closer relationship which the European Union wants with Turkey. I regret that other groups in this Parliament have failed to put the joint resolution into a proper context by not supporting a paragraph, now represented by our S&D amendment, also stating our continued commitment to the reunification talks, supporting the work of the UN Special Adviser, and arguing for a comprehensive solution to the Cyprus problem. I will always try to work in solidarity with our Cypriot colleagues, but I always seek to do so recognising the need to promote and not undermine reconciliation, to encourage trust building between both sides, and recognising there can only be a negotiated diplomatic solution both to the current crisis as well as to the long-standing division of the island. I believe trade and economic activity, and in this case the discovery of hydrocarbons, could be a great opportunity for both communities in Cyprus, and actually help a settlement, and I ask all colleagues to support these positions and Parliament to vote for our amendment. This is an issue of provocation, and this European Parliament should show the self-discipline to pass texts which do not themselves further provoke, but which encourage de-escalation in the interests of all.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR). -
text: Mr President, we all want a solution to the Cyprus problem, and both sides undoubtedly bear some responsibility for the present situation, but frankly it is not helpful when we are trying to find a way of restarting negotiations to produce a one-sided resolution which seeks to place all the blame on Turkey and the Turkish Cypriots or, indeed, for the Commissioner to speak in the way that he has at the beginning of his remarks this evening. I hope he is listening now. I do not think he is. Are you listening, Commissioner? Yes. Thank you. For the recent causes of the present impasse, we should look to the events of 2004. In May of that year, the Republic of Cyprus joined the European Union and immediately set about blocking any progress, in particular on the undertaking given by the European Council the previous month to end the isolation of northern Cyprus. If this promise had been kept, none of the difficulties that are being discussed today would have arisen. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: answer a question with a blue card. Mr President, I will not say that Mr Van Orden is provocative, but I would like to think it is out of ignorance. I would therefore like to ask you: Have you read the agreement between Christofias and Talat which states that these stocks belong to the Republic of Cyprus, which will be federal after the solution? You also know about Christofias' agreement with Eroglu, whom you vigorously defend - but he is a dichotomy - an agreement that also determines how to share, that is, percentage. In any case, when one is a Member of the European Parliament, one must have read before taking the floor.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – As my colleague, – and, I believe, friend – Mr Hadjigeorgiou notes full well, I take great pleasure in looking in great detail at all these particular matters. This has not been a debate this evening but a one-sided criticism of northern Cyprus and indeed the Turkish position. If we want to make any progress on unifying the island – as I am sure we all want to – then the only solution, as we know, is a solution that respects the interests and concerns of both communities on the island. That goes right back to the point that I made about what happened in 2004. We have just got to get over it and we have got to speak in more generous and sympathetic terms to understand the Turkish Cypriot position. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)

name: Eleni Theocharous (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Van Orden, you quite often blame the Greek Cypriots because they rejected the Annan Plan in 2004 and you did it again, indirectly, today. Do you know that the Turkish Cypriots rejected the Annan Plan also – and not only the Greek Cypriots? It was the settlers who were brought from Turkey who voted in favour of the Annan Plan.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – I have not actually mentioned the Annan Plan; I was talking about what happened in 2004. I was referring specifically to the promise made by the European Council in April 2004 to end the isolation of northern Cyprus. A month later, all that was pushed on one side and we have made little progress since. Every now and then we get a glimmer of hope. Every now and then something happens which makes us think ‘oh, maybe there is now progress’, but then obstacles are put up. We have got to get over that and we have to find a way ahead that respects the rights and concerns of all the communities in Cyprus.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, this is the second time in this House that I have to refer to Turkey's violations of international law; but this time it is not from alleged funding from integrationist groups that practice terrorism, nor from destabilization in the Middle East. This time we are talking about Turkey's threats to a member country of the European Union: Cyprus. The threats of Turkey, which I recall as a candidate for accession to the European Union, are threats to the whole of this Union, to all of us. The movement of Turkish vessels to the exclusive economic zone – that is, to the territorial waters of the Republic of Cyprus – and the NAVEX Maritime Directive, issued illegally by Turkey, infringe international law, maritime law and the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. The High Representative must demand the cessation of Turkey's occupation of Cyprus, she must condemn Ankara's continued violations of international law in order to freeze bilateral relations, including accession negotiations.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I do not understand Turkey, I really do not understand it! We are talking about a wonderful country, which has been trying to reach us for thirty years. We in this House would like to be able to praise its progress towards accession, its use of the huge amount of funding it has received, and not, quite the contrary. First we are forced to condemn the crackdown on social media, then its opportunistic indifference to the massacres in Kobane and, lastly, the illegal invasion of the economic zone of Cyprus. What path has Turkey taken? It is not just oil and gas drilling in the Mediterranean that is at stake, to which we five stars are also opposed. There is a very heavy responsibility for breaking up the fragile negotiations between the Republic of Cyprus and Northern Cyprus. A candidate country should consistently use its influence to help us put out the fire in the Middle East – as you said earlier – to push the two sides towards a fair sharing of opportunities for all Cypriots, to negotiate peacefully and constructively. A place in the Union does not tear itself up with fine words, it is won by deeds.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to thank Mr Juncker. It has shifted our debates, so we are almost two hours behind schedule. He's gone to dinner and we're working on some key issues. But what's the problem tonight? Is it Mr Juncker or is it Turkey? To the Commission, I would just like to say one thing. Today you are referring the Cyprus file to this House, but you have never done anything for Cyprus. You make you cry in the cottages, but I think that once again you are not going to make a difference.  On the essentials, I would say that we are in favour of balanced and fair international relations between sovereign states. We intend, of course, to defend exclusive economic zones, which are the hallmark of the tutelage of States over their immediate maritime spaces. Today, these areas must be respected by all States, including Turkey, which is not a signatory to the Convention, especially now where the Republic of Cyprus is being questioned. I believe that we must - and I am addressing the Commission - respect... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Μανώλης Κεφαλογιάννης (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Turkish aggression in the Exclusive Economic Zone of Cyprus is a flagrant violation of the sovereign rights of a Member State of the European Union and international law of the sea. Turkey must commit itself to the principles governing good neighbourly relations and peaceful settlement of disputes between all states in the world. Turkey must sign and ratify the International Law of the Sea, part of the European acquis - it is the only country that has not signed the Agreement for 20 years. I'm not going to be able to do that, but I'm going to be able to do that. ƒ±έƒÉƒÍς, ƒÅ ƒ±ƒÍƒÒƒÏƒÈίƒ¿ ƒÎƒÏέƒÎƒÃƒÇ ƒËƒ¿ ƒÐƒÃƒÀƒ¿ƒÐƒÑƒÃί ƒÑƒ¿ ƒÈƒÒƒÏƒÇƒ¿ƒÏƒÔƒÇƒÈά ƒÂƒÇƒÈƒ¿ƒÇώƒÊƒ¿ƒÑƒ¿ όƒÉƒÖƒË ƒÑƒÖƒË ƒÈƒÏƒ¿ƒÑώƒË ƒÑƒÅς ƒ£ƒÒƒÏƒÖƒÎƒ¿ϊƒÈής ΈƒËƒÖƒÐƒÅς, ƒÑόƒÐƒÍ ƒÐƒÑƒÅƒË ƒÒƒÓƒ¿ƒÉƒÍƒÈƒÏƒÅƒÎίƒÂƒ¿ όƒÐƒÍ ƒÈƒ¿ƒÇ ƒÐƒÑƒÅƒË ƒŸƒÎƒÍƒÈƒÉƒÃƒÇƒÐƒÑƒÇƒÈή ƒƒÇƒÈƒÍƒËƒÍƒÊƒÇƒÈή ƒ¤ώƒËƒÅ ƒÑƒÍƒÒς: ƒÒƒÓƒ¿ƒÉƒÍƒÈƒÏƒÅƒÎίƒÂƒ¿ ƒÈƒ¿ƒÇ ƒŸƒÎƒÍƒÈƒÉƒÃƒÇƒÐƒÑƒÇƒÈή ƒƒÇƒÈƒÍƒËƒÍƒÊƒÇƒÈή ƒ¤ώƒËƒÅ ƒÑƒÖƒË ƒÈƒÏƒ¿ƒÑώƒË ƒÊƒÃƒÉώƒË ƒÃίƒËƒ¿ƒÇ ƒÒƒÓƒ¿ƒÉƒÍƒÈƒÏƒÅƒÎίƒÂƒ¿ ƒÈƒ¿ƒÇ ƒŸƒÎƒÍƒÈƒÉƒÃƒÇƒÐƒÑƒÇƒÈή ƒƒÇƒÈƒÍƒËƒÍƒÊƒÇƒÈή ƒ¤ώƒËƒÅ ƒÑƒÅς ƒ£ƒÒƒÏƒÖƒÎƒ¿ϊƒÈής ΈƒËƒÖƒÐƒÅς. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Kefalogiannis, you were very eloquent on Turkey’s violations of Cyprus and of the Law of the Sea. You are probably aware that the European Union has been paying over EUR 900 million a year in pre-accession funding to Turkey and similar amounts have been allocated for the next five years. Are you in favour of these amounts being continued if Turkey continues to … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Μανώλης Κεφαλογιάννης (PPE)
text: answer a question with a blue card. Mr President, I personally would be against continuing these funds. But these, my colleague must know, are not issues that we are discussing in the European Parliament, they are matters of the European Treaties that we cannot change in the European Parliament.

name: Kati Piri (S&D). -
text: Mr President, eight months ago this House welcomed the positive developments coming out of Cyprus. The Joint Declaration by the leaders of the Greek and Turkish communities of Cyprus marked the relaunch of talks on the reunification of the island which would bring all unresolved issues to the table to reach a fair, comprehensive and viable settlement. Today, a Turkish maritime survey vessel is within Cyprus’ exclusive economic zone and the reunification talks have been suspended. We risk losing completely the momentum of eight months ago and this would have detrimental consequences, not just for the people living on the island, but it would also negatively affect the entire region.  What the Eastern Mediterranean needs most right now is a beacon of hope. All parties should act with awareness of this responsibility. Turkey must respect Cyprus’s sovereign rights in its exclusive economic zone. The legality of the exclusive economic zone of Cyprus cannot be questioned. But it is also important to underline that the conditionality can be put on the right of both communities on the island to benefit from possible gas exploitation. The leaders of both communities have to return to the negotiation table for a comprehensive settlement to the problem. In this regard the UN Secretary-General’s Adviser for Cyprus, Mr Eide, must be fully supported in his efforts. In the Joint Declaration eight months ago, the leaders of the two communities committed themselves to avoiding blame games. The people of Cyprus and the region now need them to honour this commitment.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). -
text: Mr President, Turkey has illegally invaded Cyprus and illegally holds 37% of Cypriot territory. It has now begun to carry out, in violation of international law, illegal seismic surveys in the exclusive economic zone and continental shelf of Cyprus. The European Union must take strict measures against Turkey in order for Ankara to stop its aggression towards Cyprus, which is a member of the European Union. At the same time, our Parliament must tell Turkey that: It is Cyprus' sovereign right to conclude agreements on the exploitation of natural resources in its exclusive economic zone. Secondly, to call for the withdrawal of Turkish occupying troops. Thirdly, to call on Turkey to comply with international law and to stop illegal actions and threats against any State of the European Union. Fourthly, to stop Turkey taking actions that call into question Cyprus' right to exploit hydrocarbons in its exclusive economic zone.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union, following the hermaphrodite policy of the International Community on cyprus, has ended up negotiating the accession of the country which with 45,000 soldiers holds 3,500 square kilometres of European territory. Today, the furious conflict of economic interests imposed so far by this policy leaves the political leaders who served it naked, embellishing the tragic reality. Negotiations without content, blackmailing project-type dilemmas, tolerance for the creation of fait accompli, circumvention of structural rules of accession process, neutral declarations and recommendations for restraint, have, among other things, set the course for Barbaros. Ladies and gentlemen, we are obliged to set the strictest framework so that we do not allow the slightest misinterpretation by anyone. Turkey's aggressive actions are strongly condemned as an attack on the European Union and its citizens, threaten the Union's energy security, strengthen efforts for a meaningful solution to the Cyprus problem and require a review of Turkey's accession path. Any retreat from the above offends the Cypriot people and is a blow to the cohesion of the European Union.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI). -
text: Mr President, the EKE stands by the Cypriot people and supports the fight for a unified and independent Cyprus, with a single sovereignty, citizenship and international personality, without foreign bases, troops, foreign guarantors and protectors. The European Union has not condemned either the Turkish occupation of Cyprus or Turkey's violations, while NATO defiantly recommends restraint on all sides. The Communist Party of Greece demands an unequivocal condemnation of the Turkish challenges and is opposed to attempts to undermine it with amendments to the resolution that call for the distribution of hydrocarbons, by methodizing a dichotomy solution, legitimising unacceptable Turkish claims and challenging the sovereign rights of Cyprus and Greece. The fair resolution of the Cyprus problem is crushed in the vise of the competition of energy monopolies. It can only be served in conflict with the EU and NATO, with the people leading the way for their own interests.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are faced with a very worrying situation because, as we have already heard from previous speakers, these series of threats of unilateral action, which Turkey is carrying out against the State of Cyprus and its rights over the exclusive economic zone, represent the most serious escalation of tension in the recent past between the two countries. Respect for and recognition of the territorial sovereignty of the Member States is not only an obligation under international law, but also an essential component of the process of accession to the European Union. I believe that we should send a firm and clear signal to the Turkish authorities. Turkey will have to take account of the position of this Parliament. I would like to remind you that, as my colleague Eleni Theocharous said very well, we have kept quiet so many times and we have not supported, we have not shown closeness to the Cypriot people. I believe that tomorrow we will find the right solution: dialogue, dialogue and great closeness to the Cypriot people.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D). -
text: Mr President, a few hours ago we celebrated the collapse of the Berlin Wall. But today, as we speak, in the European Union there is a wall imposed by the Turkish army and it divides a people, a Cyprus, Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots in the same state. The Republic of Cyprus seeks by peaceful means to remove this wall and looks forward to our family, here in the European Union, in the rules of law. On the basis of this law of the sea, part of the acquis communautaire and international law, the Republic of Cyprus has agreed with all neighbouring countries, Egypt, Lebanon and Israel on the separation of the Exclusive Economic Zone with a view to natural gas offering a prospect for energy security in the European Union. This resolution records the events with a clear message to Erdogan's Turkey to stop all its illegal actions within the Cypriot EEZ, as required by European Union law rules. Without respect for such basic rules, the European Union cannot function and, at last, Turkey can take the step and...  (The President interrupts the speaker).

name: Renate Sommer (PPE). -
text: Mr. President! Turkey is celebrating itself because of its new EU strategy and for its national action plan, which has been relaunched. But is what Turkey is doing new? It is once again provoking the Republic of Cyprus, and thus the whole of the European Union. Once again, it wants to demonstrate its claim to power. Of course, she wants the money from offshore support, which she can get, because no one has anything against it – but only if she goes to the negotiating table and also gives in, just as southern Cyprus has to give in. That does not suit Turkey, nor does it like the fact that the other countries in the region are involved – Israel, for example. That, too, is a great thorn in Turkey's side! And then all this is a welcome reason for this country not to continue the Cyprus talks in order to continue to market and exploit the northern part of the island in peace. The republic of Cyprus and the European Union are once again blaming the Republic of Cyprus and the European Union for this. I do not think we can allow this to happen. I also want a robust relationship with Turkey, but it also requires people to express their views very clearly!

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Turkey's move to adopt the illegal Navtex directive within the Exclusive Economic Zone of the Republic of Cyprus, that is, within European borders, is a violation of international law. Are there rules of law or not? Finally, are interests prevailing in the European Union and are we closing our eyes? How can the European Union allow a candidate Member State to mock and mock it in this way? We want Turkey within the European Union, but it cannot turn its back on the values and principles of the Union. This is a candidate country that is seeking the approval and assent of all of us to continue the process: that is, if it had not claimed it, what action would it have taken? How far could it go, how can we leave Turkey without sanctions, a country which, on its own responsibility, is moving away from European institutions?

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE). -
text: Mr President, a lot has been said already, and I think it does not take a very many words. I believe that the most important thing to say at the moment is that Turkey, a member of NATO, a close partner of the Union, a candidate country, must display responsible behaviour and avoid unilateral action. It's clearly unacceptable what he's doing right now.  But I would like to refer to what a colleague earlier, Mr Mavrides, was saying, comparing the conflict between Turkey and Cyprus with the Cold War. I believe that we must maintain a sense of proportion, there is nothing in common between what the war between the communist bloc and the free world meant, and, on the other hand, this Turkish-Cypriot conflict. Moreover, I want to tell you that I was shocked to find today, by the way, also by the sense of proportion, that in the debate about the anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, the longest speech was given by a communist. I personally, coming from a country that lived this experience, I consider that the memory of the hundreds of thousands of people who died during Communism, when today Communism ... (The President interrupts the speaker).

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D). -
text: Mr President, the fall of the Berlin Wall, as many have said, was not achieved with weapons, but with genuine solidarity based on peoples' law, the principles of freedom and common sense. Nicosia, however, is the last capital of Europe with a wall, the result of military invasion and illegal occupation, which must explicitly indicate our solidarity with Cyprus, which must safeguard its sovereignty and exercise its sovereign rights freely, like any European country, with respect for international law. Otherwise, what Union are we talking about? And you colleagues in your countries exercise your rights without terrorism and threats. What Union are we talking about and what alliance if we allow so much aggression against a country in the European Union? Without respect for international law, Turkey is marginalised on its own. We need geopolitical stability and not to continue the silence, but to have a common voice as the European Parliament. And finally, it is impossible to have a European Union if it does not have common borders, if it does not have the courage and bravery to defend them when it is needed by any small or large challenge. Today is Cyprus, tomorrow may be the Baltic countries, the day after tomorrow Finland... (The President interrupts the speaker).

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE). -
text: Mr President, this resolution once again reminds us of the ever-present issue of an EU Member State being occupied by a foreign country. The actions taken by Turkey can only be viewed as a threat to the economic well-being of Cyprus, and this is a clear violation not only of international law but also of the UN Charter and the Convention on the Law of the Sea, which was established to prevent such actions and to preserve law and order, especially the claims of countries to specific bodies of water that fall within their domain. As Turkey has given numerous examples of its disregard for the legitimacy of the Republic of Cyprus, this can only be viewed as yet another attempt to deny its existence. I stand here to support Cyprus and condemn the continued actions of Turkey.

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, recently the Turkish vessel Barbaros, accompanied by warships, illegally invaded the Exclusive Economic Zone of Cyprus with a view to carrying out investigations into hydrocarbon deposits. In Turkey the government is attempting to islamise society and restrict the secular state within the framework of its neo-Ottoman policy. The European perspective and respect for the obligations arising from it remains the only counterweight to such a development and still has significant support in Turkish society. It is precisely for this reason that the Government of Turkey chooses to sharpen the Cyprus EEZ. Previously, unfortunately for her, she chose the fall of Kobani, the open flirtation with ISIS and the freezing of relations with Armenia. Today we call for a strong condemnation of the actions of the Turkish Government and an immediate withdrawal of Turkish vessels from the EEZ of Cyprus. The aim is to restart talks between the two communities in Cyprus to find a just solution to the Cyprus problem within the UN. This is the only way to guarantee the rights of the two communities to hydrocarbon revenues.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ (PPE). -
text: Commissioner, Mr Hahn, just yesterday, in the European Union-Turkey Joint Parliamentary Committee, you know that Turkey's violation of the Exclusive Economic Zone was discussed in detail in an extensive debate. Today, Turkey repeatedly violated Greece's airspace over the island of Mykonos. This means, quite simply, that Turkey consciously, in the context of a chosen strategy, ignores international law, the acquis communautaire, the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, the decisions of the Security Council, does not recognise the Republic of Cyprus, does not respect the Member States of the European family and I wonder: You said in your introductory remark that we expect Turkey to show restraint. I wonder, how long do we have to wait? (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: blue card question. – Mrs Vosenberg, I also invoke your capacity as a lawyer and I would like to ask whether you believe that the tolerance of the European Parliament and the non-explicit declaration of illegal occupation in Cyprus could set a precedent that one could use in the future, given that today is Cyprus, tomorrow may be the Baltic and the day after tomorrow it could be Finland.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ (PPE)
text: answer a question with a blue card. It's not a matter of, you know, legal knowledge. I have seen your comment and your suggestion and I agree with that. The mere fact that a country which claims membership of the European family through accession talks, but at the same time does not respect international law, should determine our attitude. Resolutions and simple communications prove that this behaviour is not prevented and our decisions must now be prohibitive with regard to Turkey's accession to the European family... (The President interrupts the speaker).

name: Vincent Peillon (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, what a disappointment after the hopes of 11 February 2014. Our position must be clear, of course: how could the European Union fail to strongly condemn the violation of international law and an obvious aggression against one of its member countries? And, at the same time, I fully support what the Commissioner said. We must not talk about the cold war, but keep a cool head and measure that we must, vis-à-vis Turkey, ask for clarification which also implies that on our side we have made it clear that we want Turkey to be able to join the European Union and deepen discussions. That is why, rather than making the conflict that is taking place today inflamed, I believe that we must play appeasement and firmness on international law, and promote hope and prospects for the region and Turkey. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation)

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: the blue card. " Indeed, Europe's security today depends on NATO's position, on NATO's actions. Turkey is a NATO state. Turkey does not comply with international law. Should it not be subject to NATO-sided sanctions? How do you think?

name: Vincent Peillon (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer. "Dear colleague, no one here, and this is a bit of an inanity of our debates, is not going to contradict you on the fact that we must respect international law. I started by saying it. At the same time, you are probably interested in the situation in the whole region and you know Turkey's strategic position, the concerns that may be ours, moreover, with regard to a number of attitudes of Turkey in recent times, particularly with regard to the conflicts that are taking place in Syria and Iraq. I therefore believe that we must, at the same time, condemn very strongly, as I said, and, at the same time, to measure that we must hold the dialogue with Turkey.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to raise the following concerns with colleagues: in 2004 we were all sure that Turkey wanted to be a candidate country for the Union. Today, as the Turkish political leadership behaves, are we still certain - in 2014 - that Turkey wants to remain a candidate country of the European Union? I will give just one example: on the one hand, it continues to ignore, ten years later, since the start of the accession negotiations, the Republic of Cyprus. At the same time, however, it is now blatantly violating the Cyprus Exclusive Economic Zone, which we must all make clear here as the European Exclusive Economic Zone. So does Turkey want to be a candidate country for the European Union? Are there ways, in addition to the resolutions, to send a serious, resounding message to Turkey that in order to continue to maintain the status of candidate country it must comply with international law and European data? Can this be done even by limiting financial aid? Let's all deal with it here.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, what Turkey is doing today in violation of international law is one consequence of what it did when turkish troops occupied Cyprus.  The behaviour of the Republic of Turkey is deeply disturbing. It is provocative to each of the countries in the region. May I remind you of the provocations against the State of Israel, should I remind you of the provocations turkey makes by directing illegal immigrants to the territory of Greece and Bulgaria. Turkey's behaviour, governed by its neo-Marxist doctrine, seems to me to have no intention of continuing Turkey's efforts to join the European Union. Turkey's current behaviour is not the behaviour of a European state, it is the behaviour of an aggressor country and I strongly urge both this Chamber and the Commission to take a decision, to express their insistence at the highest level that this aggressor's behaviour should be stopped.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul Yes, the sovereign right of the Republic of Cyprus to operate in its own exclusive economic zone has been seriously provoked by Turkey, which has also flagrantly violated international and all international law. This puts European solidarity to the test.  Right here, just tonight, all of us in this Parliament – those of us who are elected by the people – must stand up with one voice and do the only thing: firstly, condemn the Turkish occupation and activities and, secondly, demand that Turkey withdraw immediately. Anything else is a threat to security, not only to the Republic of Cyprus but to our entire Union – all of us European citizens – and this is a perspective that we must take into account.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL). -
text: I begin by expressing once again, on behalf of my party, our solidarity with the Cypriot people, who have been living under Turkish occupation since 73, when Turkey invaded the northern part of the island killing thousands of people. This crime continues, to this day, unpunished. This occupation has never been recognized to date by any State, with the exception of Turkey itself. This invasion of cyprus' exclusive economic zone is an unqualified provocation, which should merit our most heartily repudiation. Once again, we note the duality of european union criteria: a European Union that is fast and ready when it comes to following the guidelines of NATO and the United States, but which is merely pious statements when it comes to the sovereignty of one of its States. I hope that the European Union will nevertheless be able to go further by imposing sanctions on Turkey, thereby helping to continue peace negotiations with a view to reunification.

name: Εμμανουήλ Γλέζος (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, this is not just a provocation by Turkey. It has already invaded the area of the Exclusive Economic Zone and is doing research: It is therefore a conquest. But the lack of progress we have shown so far in the face of Turkey's attitudes is due to the fact that Turkey is a member of NATO. If he were not a member of NATO, our answer would be different, I mean the response of the European Union and the European Parliament. I therefore wonder whether we would take the same stance if Turkey did something similar in Italy, Spain, or France. Why double standards? I strongly denounce the European Union and the Commissioner for forgiving everything in Turkey for being a member of NATO.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, honourable Members, I should like to thank you for inviting me to join this discussion today and to thank Members for the valuable points they have made. It is absolutely right to have taken this opportunity to express our concerns about recent events, to make very clear our position on the rights of Member States, and to stress Turkey’s obligations in crystal clear terms. We will convey this message strongly and engage our Turkish counterparts towards a solution.  This debate makes it very clear as well that we need to find ways forward. The Eastern Mediterranean is in a fragile geopolitical situation. It is in the strong interest of all of us that tensions are decreased quickly and we need more than ever to achieve progress on a Cyprus settlement. Earlier this year, the EU gave its strong support to the restarting of Cyprus negotiations. We have made clear our readiness to help. It is time to deliver; it is time to stand firmly behind the United Nations Envoy, Espen Barth Eide. It is time to help the leaders of both Cypriot communities find a way back to the negotiation table, and I think it is high time to find an adequate answer and to give support to both communities.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: At the end of the debate, seven motions for resolutions were tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 13 November. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. The escalation of unilateral actions by Turkey in the exclusive economic zone of Cyprus should not be underestimated and deserves a great deal of attention, given that Turkey is a candidate country for accession to the European Union. To date, these actions have led to the suspension of peace talks between Cyprus and the north of the Turkish-controlled island. I therefore call on the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs to call on Turkey to withdraw its warships immediately, so as to create the conditions for the resumption, as soon as possible, of the peace talks with Cyprus. Turkey's actions cannot but lead this Parliament to reflect in depth on Turkey's candidacy to become an EU Member State. I would stress the strong need for the European Parliament and the European Commission to step up monitoring of Turkey's activities in the exclusive economic zone of Cyprus and the need to intensify the dialogue with it in order to achieve full normalisation of relations with all Member States.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – I wish to express my deepest concerns over the outright challenge to the sovereign rights of Cyprus. This provocative action of Turkey seriously affects security in the eastern Mediterranean region. Tension is definitely on the rise, and unfortunately hydrocarbons are inseparably linked to the problem; they have escalated rather than de-escalated the situation. In my view this move of sending warships was mainly aiming to monitor a Greek Cypriot oil-and-gas exploration mission off the coast of Cyprus. I believe that the Republic of Cyprus has the full and sovereign right to explore the natural resources within its exclusive economic zone. All EU actions should, no doubt, aim for defending international law and the sovereign rights of Cyprus, a Member State of the EU, and its EEZ. In fact, the discoveries of large hydrocarbon reserves in the eastern Mediterranean and around Cyprus should provide further impetus for a political solution to the division of the island.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Turkey clearly does not note the existence of the Republic of Cyprus, which is once again confirmed by the NAVTEX Directive. Since mid-October this year, under that directive, part of Cyprus' territorial waters has been explored by a Turkish vessel seeking natural gas. Are the Turkish manoeuvres intended to undermine the right of the Republic of Cyprus to natural resources in its exclusive economic zone? If so, they must be seen as incompatible with international law. Turkey is an important partner of the EU and a candidate for its membership, so this cannot continue. The Turkish authorities should be called upon without delay to abolish the NAVTEX Directive and to respect the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS). The international community expects Turkey to cooperate for stability and peace in the eastern Mediterranean, not provocative behaviour within the exclusive economic zone of the Republic of Cyprus and at the same time the territory of the European Union.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – The size of gas assets near Cyprus is estimated to reach 140-200 billion cubic metres, which is also significant for European security of supply. Although it is not yet decided how gas will be traded at the end of the decade, either through an LNG export terminal or through a regional gas network, there is no question that the Eastern Mediterranean can play an important role in reducing european gas imports. Current trends and project plans point to the fact that the need for resource diversification in Central and Eastern Europe is not met by a large alternative project, as we thought until the death of the Nabucco project, but by a number of smaller opportunities for diversified supply. That is why it is important to exploit all opportunities in Europe. I support the continuation of the dialogue between the Greek cypriot and Turkish communities. Long-term settlement can only be achieved peacefully.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE)
text: Written. – Turkey has not acted correctly in continuing seismic research and its military presence in the exclusive economic zone of the Republic of Cyprus. On the other hand, the Republic of Cyprus has not agreed to confidence-building proposals, e.g. in the case of cyprus. joint commissions or the exchange of information between communities prior to the re-association of the island. The delicate situation in the eastern Mediterranean does not need any more escalating conflicts. That is why EU action must contribute to the rapid and undisturbed continuation of the re-re-accession negotiations as quickly and undisturbed as possible - the most important thing for lasting peace and for the future of the island's inhabitants.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. – The Turkish Government announced on 3 October that seismic investigations would be carried out within the exclusive economic zone of the Republic of Cyprus. For this purpose, the research vessel "Barbaros" was sent to Cypriot territorial waters accompanied by the Turkish navy. In protest, Cypriot President Anastasiades has suspended his participation in the Cyprus peace talks. Offshore oil and gas exploration is of great economic and strategic importance to Cyprus. Exploration of the Aphrodite field and the construction of a multi-billion dollar LNG terminal on the Vassilikos coast are top priorities for the Cypriot government. Projects that can also contribute to increasing the European Union's energy security in the medium term. Turkey, on the other hand, rejects all offshore exploration activities before the Cyprus conflict is finally resolved, and is now provoking Cyprus by sending a research vessel. At the same time, Turkey is also breaking international law. But not only that: Turkey still occupies more than a third of the island of Cyprus and is condemned for it by a UN resolution. Turkey is clearly at odds with the values of the European community of states. This new provocation requires a clear response from Europe, namely full solidarity with the Republic of Cyprus, a suspension of EU accession negotiations with Turkey and a freeze on the EUR 900 million EU pre-accession aid. In this sense, I support tomorrow's resolution.

name: Der Präsident. -
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the humanitarian situation in South Sudan (2014/2922(RSP)).

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union For Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Mr President, honourable Members, South Sudan, the world’s youngest country, has been at war with itself for eleven months now. A power struggle among members of the ruling elite has plunged the country into a human catastrophe of alarming proportions. The conflict which erupted in the capital, Juba, on 15 December 2013 has created one of the worst man-made humanitarian disasters we are currently facing in the world. Fighting and violence have forced nearly two million people away from their homes. 1.4 million conflict-affected people are displaced inside South Sudan. Over 100 000 of them live in the protection of civilian areas at overcrowded UN bases around the country. Small-scale fighting continues. At the end of October, heavy fighting erupted in Bentiu, the capital of Unity State, triggering condemnations by the EU as well as the UN Secretary-General. Both sides not only continue to build their forces on the ground but also continue to make menacing and quarrelsome statements, and by doing so break their own commitments to seek a peaceful settlement. The crisis in South Sudan has also had a destabilising effect on the region. Over 470 thousand South Sudanese have become refugees in neighbouring Ethiopia, Uganda, Sudan and Kenya this year. IGAD, the East African Intergovernmental Authority on Development, is conducting peace talks. The latest IGAD Summit on South Sudan which took place on 7 November sent encouraging signals, with South Sudanese parties stating their intention to cease hostilities immediately and reach agreement on an inclusive power-sharing arrangement within 15 days. Nonetheless, it is too early to say if a breakthrough will materialise, and there remains a risk of a return to active hostilities in the near future, not least given the political leaders’ weak control of their commanders in the field. The conflict has dramatically increased food insecurity, and disease is on the rise with a dramatic increase in deadly Kala Azar (visceral leishmaniasis) infections. A quickly spreading cholera epidemic was contained after a massive international aid effort supported by the EU, and the looming famine threatening the most vulnerable was avoided in 2014. The European Union has been at the forefront of the response, providing more than one-third – precisely 38% – of all international humanitarian contributions in 2014. The European Commission alone has committed over EUR 110 million for life-saving humanitarian assistance in South Sudan, and an additional EUR 20 million for the refugee response in neighbouring countries. Despite these significant contributions, many of the urgent needs are going unmet. One example: 55 000 severely and acutely malnourished children under five have been treated so far, but there are an estimated 235 000 children facing severe acute malnutrition in South Sudan. The relationship between the government and the humanitarian community is deteriorating. Humanitarian agencies are under constant pressure to conform to the endless demands of authorities, both in government and opposition areas, to control the delivery of independent and impartial aid. In addition, several humanitarian aid workers of South Sudanese nationality have been killed, while some are still missing, and this apparently because of their ethnicity. Let me conclude by stressing that, firstly, a political solution of the crisis is urgently needed as a precondition for peace and reconciliation among the various groups in South Sudan, which the European Union is actively supporting. Secondly, humanitarian assistance saves lives and alleviates suffering, but it cannot solve this crisis. The assistance cannot even be sustained at the current level for very long. Third, as long as a political solution has not been found, and the humanitarian needs continue to exist, we have a moral duty to continue our efforts in responding to the humanitarian needs to the extent possible and necessary, while at the same time political and diplomatic efforts have to be intensified. Fourth, the warring parties in South Sudan have to understand that they have exhausted the patience of the international community. They must get their act together to the benefit of South Sudan’s citizens and the development of the world’s youngest nation.

name: Joachim Zeller
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, I am pleased to see you again in your new role. Colleagues, the debate on South Sudan has again come close to the end of today's agenda. This is roughly in line with the public attention that the situation in South Sudan is attracting. Unfortunately, because the situation in that country can only be described as a humanitarian and political disaster.  Four years ago, people welcomed their independence as liberation from slavery – after fifty years of war and civil war. But people's expectations have not been met, on the contrary; Fighting has resumed in South Sudan since December 2013 as the country's powerful struggle for power and influence.  As the Commissioner said, almost two million people have now been uprooted and forced to flee – hundreds of thousands of them to neighbouring countries, so this is no longer confined to South Sudan. Thousands have been killed or mistreated! Aid deliveries did not reach the addressees, and even the UN refugee camps no longer offered protection. The ceasefire agreement of 7 November between President Salva Kiir and rebel leader Riek Machar, mentioned by the Commissioner, is already the third this year. The two predecessors of the ceasefire have not brought peace to the country, the world community must finally act, and together! There must be no more arms deliveries to South Sudan! Sanctions must be imposed on those responsible for the conflict so that there is no threat of famine next year.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, since this conflict began in December 2013, this Parliament has repeatedly appealed to the parties to work towards a ceasefire and to ensure political stability. Today, however, we have growing concern that there are continually ruptures of fragile high fires—the last one reached last Friday and broke last Sunday—and therefore we are in a situation of continued war. This continuing war is affecting the displacement, as has been pointed out, of two million people, is leading to continued violations of the most essential human rights , up to 10,000 murders – and is also endangering the lives of thousands and thousands of children who, as has just been pointed out, do not have basic nutrition. We know that there is no military solution to the conflict and that efforts must therefore be made to support the African Union in its efforts to engage in a national dialogue on the basis of the agreement reached in Addis Ababa. And that national dialogue has to be a general national dialogue, covering all the causes behind the conflict; it has to be inclusive and therefore incorporate all the actors that are facing each other; and has to build the foundations of a trust that allows us to move towards conflict resolution. From a humanitarian point of view we are particularly concerned about the difficulties of access to the population in need, the violations of the rights of humanitarian actors, whose lives are being punished, and respect for the principles of independence and neutrality typical of humanitarian action.

name: Bas Belder
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – In the run-up to this debate on the humanitarian crisis situation in South Sudan, I have looked into the most recent reports. I also spoke at length with the Dutch aid organisation ZOA, which since 1998 has been closely involved in a south Sudanese population that is currently plagued by violence, disease and hunger. The image that rises up with me when I see it all on the keper is truly shocking. Take the forecast that 2.5 million South Sudanese will face severe food shortages in the first quarter of 2015, i.e. next year. After that, there will be even tougher months. It is clear that the structural approach to the current humanitarian crisis situation in South Sudan calls for an immediate end to political violence. At the same time - and this has been underlined by the Commissioner - European aid remains highly urgent. The Dutch organisations that are closely involved also have a great deal of appreciation for this European support. Only there is one point I would like to raise here. When it comes to deregistration of projects, these organisations are given very little time to register and participate in well-founded ones. That's why they miss the boat. And that can never be the intention. I hope that this will be taken into account by the European Commission and ECHO in Brussels, because there are excellent, well-equipped organisations in the Netherlands with experts keen to participate in European aid for South Sudan. But then they should be able to do the same.

name: Charles Goerens
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, we are once again faced with the situation of a country that is struggling to get out of the difficulties: political, security and humanitarian difficulties, not to mention the natural disasters that are added to it. When it is not cholera, it is famine, when it is not the uprooting of the population, it is the threat to humanitarian workers. South Sudan is fragile, vulnerable, but not without resources. It is against a background of ethnic differences that hostilities have developed in this part of the African continent. Since the regal functions of the State are no longer sufficiently assured, it is becoming difficult in the meantime to get humanitarian aid to the poor people who are in dire need of it. The biggest obstacle to South Sudan's take-off is the country itself, hence the European Parliament's call for the responsibility of the parties to the conflict to respect the ceasefire agreement. Insecurity is the biggest obstacle to the country's development and yet South Sudan should know that the international situation is not very favourable to it as there are many hotbeds of tension, crises and conflicts that require humanitarian assistance from our states and the European Union. In the meantime, the European Union must reschedule its aid, as South Sudan's absorption capacity has so it all disappeared. Our message to South Sudan is: yes, we are ready to help you, including at an international donor conference, provided that everyone, starting with you, get their own work into it. It is therefore time for diplomacy, mediation and reconciliation. The African Union and the European Union can offer their help, but nothing can be imposed on them.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. I hear Commissioner Hahn say that the warring parties need to understand that we are becoming impatient. I think he's right about that. Only, what does that mean "that the warring parties understand that we are becoming impatient"? 1.8 million people on the run. Famine lurking. Two men who should build a new state together are fighting each other out of the tent. And this youngest state in the world, rich in oil, falls into war and falls again for the curse of the raw materials. Things are getting out of hand and yes, you're right, we're getting impatient. But we cannot get impatient, because humanitarian aid will and must always be provided. Of course we have stopped supporting budget. After all, what else can you give budget support to when there is no government anymore? But what we have to pay for is that we continue to pay for humanitarian aid, that we are not going to use the budget support for anything else. For food, for the position of women, for reproductive aid and reproductive rights - which is quite a debate in this house - because in times of war women are struggling, women are being raped, women have to make a living.  What we can also do is to insist on further sanctions, sanctions by the African Union and perhaps also to strengthen our own sanctions, because they have so far had too little effect. I agree with you, we are running out of patience, and yet we have no choice but to keep trying.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there are very few reasons in South Sudan to celebrate the third anniversary of independence. Since the conflict between the rival forces of the president and former Vice-President Riek Machar erupted in December 2013, the civilian population has been systematically targeted in towns and villages, houses and mosques, hospitals and even at UN bases where they had sought refuge. A recent amnesty international report revealed the horrific atrocities committed by both sides involved in the conflict: massacred civilians, girls and pregnant women raped, the elderly and the sick killed mercilessly. Attacks on civilians on the basis of ethnic origin and alleged political affiliation are real crimes against humanity. Concrete action is urgently needed at local, regional and international level to put an end to the violence, to stop reprisals against civilians and to hold those responsible for violations to account. The Union must do everything in its power to ensure that the South Sudanese find a way for them to live together constructively and peacefully, overcoming the horrors of recent months.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI). -
text: Mr President, after the dismemberment of Sudan into two states, the people are living in miserable conditions created by the imperialist interventions that took place under the pretext of ethnic and religious conflicts which the imperialists themselves had insulators in order to get their hands on the country's resources of wealth. Impoverishment, epidemics, barbaric repression make life hell for the people while, at the same time, the business groups representing the EU, the US and NATO are being treasured. The Communist Party condemns the new persecution of the civilian state of Sudan against the political Secretary-General and officials of the Sudanese Communist Party, as well as pioneering workers of that country. The bronzed accusations fall into limbo. Release all political prisoners immediately. Hands off sudan's communists!

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE). -
text: Mr. President, I agree with what my colleague Zeller said at the beginning. It's a pity we have this discussion this late at night. But on the other hand, it is good that we have this debate at all and that we will adopt an appropriate resolution of the European Parliament, because I think it sends the right message that the international community must not forget about the situation, about the civil war, about the victims of the civil war and about the humanitarian crisis in South Sudan.  Namely, the fact is that other security threats and situations, such as the threat of the Islamic State or such as the Ebola epidemic in West Africa, have in some way overshadowed this situation in South Sudan and if you will somewhat reduce the attention of the international community. And that's why it needs to be fixed now, because indeed there is a humanitarian catastrophe going on in South Sudan.  So not only a crisis, but indeed a catastrophe, when we see that 2 million people have had to flee their homes. We see units of the army out of control, not to mention hunger and all the other topics mentioned before. So we have the youngest state in the world, South Sudan, but which currently exists only on paper, because indeed state institutions on the ground cannot provide those minimum functions that the state must provide to its citizens.  Therefore, Europe and the international community that supported the creation of an independent South Sudan have one additional responsibility at the moment, and I agree that they need the necessary additional measures, they could sum them up, deliver them and enable the delivery of humanitarian aid and stop the arms trade.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D). -
text: Mr. President! Many had hoped for a better future in peace, freedom and prosperity with the independence of South Sudan. However, the longed-for new state was not able to guarantee the struggle for power and resources by means of the rule of law. The result was civil war, lawlessness and a systematic violation of human rights. But it would be wrong to join the chorus of those who now think they foresaw the same thing. Right now, the country needs our attention, not better knowledge and right-handedness! We need help for the hundreds of thousands of refugees. It is a question of finally establishing the rule of law and ensuring a high level of law enforcement. Above all, however, it requires the understanding of those in power and their willingness to leave the disastrous path – then our help also makes sense. Above all, however, it must also be linked to the fact that humanitarian aid is passed on to those for which it is intended, and not to the parties to the conflict. Above all, we have this in our own hands by not allowing arms to be supplied to South Sudan.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR) -
text: 2015 will be the European Year of Development and will bear the slogan 'Our world, our dignity, our future'. What the future holds for the world's youngest country, South Sudan, is hard to predict. The power conflict between the two politicians, which has grown into ethnic murder, displaced or mass rape of women, also concerns us. The African world is also our world, and not only in 2015. South Sudan was accompanied by the motto 'Justice, freedom and prosperity' at its inception. However, in order to meet it, South Sudan must take the first, most important step , to take care of its war-torn people and, in particular, to ensure that it has access to humanitarian aid. And we all need to make sure that the conflict does not escalate further and that children, who are the most vulnerable group and become involuntary potential soldiers, are not drawn into it.

name: Giulia Moi (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, South Sudan is the youngest country but one of the least developed in the world and, according to UN data, with the worst level of humanitarian crisis. The current crisis, largely caused by armed conflict, has exposed its population to an imminent famine and a worrying cholera epidemic. The serious humanitarian situation is clear. We welcome the 28th Extraordinary Summit of Heads of State or Government of IGAD, held on 7 November, at which the Government of South Sudan and the opposition faction of the People's Liberation Movement signed a resolution, committing themselves unconditionally and immediately to putting an end to the hostilities. Mediation has reached an important milestone and we call on the European Union to continue to assist IGAD by providing staff to monitor the ceasefire.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I support the European Parliament resolution because the situation in South Sudan is extremely difficult and requires decisive steps to be taken. According to the UN, sudan has a third level of humanitarian threat that could destabilise the entire East African region. The ethnic dimension of conflicts is particularly worrying. Power based on ethnic violence and division is contrary to the democratic rule of law and constitutes a violation of international law. Let us point out that South Sudan's economy is oil, which accounts for 70% of GDP. The European Union and the Member States have already provided more than 250 million aid, which represents more than a third of the total humanitarian envelope. Let us remember, however, that humanitarian aid alone, although necessary, will not solve all the problems, because it is the Government of South Sudan that should ensure the safety of its citizens. In order to avoid a humanitarian catastrophe, the European Union should support all actions that will contribute to improving the situation in the country.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the resumption of fighting in South Sudan two weeks ago is further aggravating a situation of serious humanitarian crisis which, since 2013, has left more than 10 000 dead, many of them civilians, more than 1 800 000 displaced persons forced to leave their homes, and 3 800 000 people in need of humanitarian assistance. NGOs operating in the country and carrying aid that do not end up in the hands of the armed forces, from this week, most likely thanks to the adoption of a specific law, will be limited in their scope, with very serious consequences that will certainly have an impact on humanitarian actions. Several attempts have failed to reach an agreement between the parties leading to a ceasefire. Our hopes now rest on the success of the extraordinary summit, which took place in November, and which envisages a final decision being taken for peace in the next fortnight. If this is not the case, however, we must strongly support the continuation of the arms embargo on South Sudan by the European Union and similar, not cosmetic, action by the United Nations, with full support for NGOs, so that they can continue to work to stem the level of emergency in which the country finds itself and which would lead to further violence and sexual abuse against women. , to severe famines and an exponential increase in people in need of food. Let us not forget that very recent estimates say that one million civilians are trapped in South Sudan and that they are just waiting for a better future. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Giulia Moi (EFDD)
text: Blue card question. Mr President, I would like to ask my colleague how she maintains that the conflict is still continuing, if a resolution was signed on 7 November in which they committed themselves, in an unconditional and immediate way, to an end to hostilities.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: Answer to a blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, these are journalistic estimates that are considered more than reliable. By the way, the Summit is quite recent. No one can tell us that the fire has actually stopped, especially in the border areas of the south of the country, where there is talk of almost a million people who are trapped waiting for a solution and, above all, waiting for basic necessities.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE). -
text: Mr President, there are two indices which clearly measure the consequences of the war situation. First, South Sudan is at emergency level 3, the worst degree available to measure global humanitarian crises. Second, there are many areas of Sudan that are officially classified as phase 4 according to the global food insecurity rate. This is a stark and harsh reality that evaluates what happens there. Regardless of the data that has already been given – and which refers to 11.3 million inhabitants – I would like to add a few more: they have the highest maternal mortality rate in the world; In addition, the country has a very low literacy rate – 70% of children between the ages of six and seventeen have never been to a school; and eleven thousand children have been recruited as combatants for conflict. The European Union, and the countries of the European Union, have donated EUR 254 million. It's insufficient. I would, however, like to highlight the work of two organizations: Unicef and Oxfam. They need a lot of help and they need no weapons. to stop the conflict. No, the conflict continues, ma'am.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D). -
text: The conflict in South Sudan, which has been going on for almost a year, lacks an urgent political solution. The United Nations representative for sexual violence in armed conflict so few days ago reported to the Security Council that, in thirty years of experience, she had never seen so much human suffering, in particular of women and children who have been victims of rape with a weapon of war and on an ethnic basis. And this is also the framework in which humanitarian NGOs are being prevented, including by the Government of Sudan itself, from intervening. The time has come to question IGAD's own ability to mediate the peace process when IGAD member countries are complicit, supporting and also responsible for the entrainment of the conflict. The European Union has a lot to do with the existence of southern Sudan. You can't wash your hands! The UN Security Council must intervene - now - to impose an arms embargo on southern Sudan that should have already happened. And to impose targeted sanctions at the highest level so that they do realize that this cannot continue. We must also have to see the inclusion of civil society in the peace process because, without it, we are in fact contributing to the fact that ceasefires are not systematically respected. A peace agreement cannot guarantee impunity to those responsible for violence in southern Sudan. We have to include a special hybrid tribunal - with international involvement - or determine the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court to investigate and punish war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in the south in Sudan. Only then can one day build peace in this martyred country.

name: Maurice Ponga (PPE). -
text: Mr President, the humanitarian situation in South Sudan is, as colleagues before me have pointed out, very worrying. Indeed, since December last year, South Sudan has been in a situation of civil war, against the backdrop of ethnic conflict. There are thousands of victims of this conflict and human rights violations are daily. Nearly 1.4 million people are internally displaced and about 500,000 seek refuge in neighbouring countries. The need for humanitarian aid is enormous and access by NGO staff is made difficult on the ground. It is important that our Parliament, through the adoption of a resolution on the subject, reminds the international community of the need to support the peace process in South Sudan and to honour its funding commitments. The European Union is a major donor - it allocated $130 million in 2014 - but the needs are enormous.

name: Vincent Peillon (S&D). -
text: Mr President, as you have said one after the other since the beginning of this debate, South Sudan is experiencing an absolutely dramatic crisis which is both a humanitarian catastrophe, directly affecting the populations, and in particular the most vulnerable populations, and a civil war whose outcome is not clear. We are in a situation where, despite the European Union's efforts in terms of humanitarian aid and taking responsibility with the imposition of sanctions, we are not achieving results. In the face of this situation, it is a good initiative to adopt a resolution to effectively remind the international conscience that this issue must be given priority in the midst, unfortunately, of so many other conflicts. We need to strengthen our humanitarian assistance, to do even more, but we must also support the peace process.  From this point of view, the observation that we can make of the inadequacy of European sanctions is this: it is not the European Union that should be reproached, but we must ask ourselves, as my colleague Ana Gomes has just done, about the need to take sanctions at another level and, in particular, to ask the United Nations to get more involved. We need to put pressure on the political process that alone can unlock the effectiveness of humanitarian aid.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, since South Sudan became the youngest country on the planet in July 2011, there has been an ongoing discussion about the viability of this new state. What is clear is that it will be unworkable if the international community is inaction and, in particular, if the European Union does. The terms of the drama have been described in every possible magnitude: four million people affected; with one and a half million internally displaced persons; with half a million displaced persons to other countries; and, in any case, with the massive suffering of the most vulnerable population; with the systematic use of rape of women as a weapon of war; and with unquestionable harm, especially to minors, by malnutrition. Therefore, the European Union cannot intervene militarily, it cannot resolve the situation militarily because there is no military solution to the conflict. But there is unfinished diplomatic action to force the Salva Kiir government to practice the necessary reforms, to combat corruption and systematic clientelism, to address severe poverty, to try to alleviate the damage inflicted on the most vulnerable population. But above all, there is humanitarian action that requires funding, which requires strong action by the European Union to address serious food shortages, at the level of building emergency and shelters, and economic support for programmes and projects aimed at providing coverage to the most vulnerable population, the innocent victims of this conflict which has worsened since December 2013. We cannot allow South Sudan's expectations to sink into misery because of the Passivity of the European Union.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE). -
text: A Uachtaráin, is cuimhin liom trí bliana ó shin in Strasbourg nuair a bhíomar ag plé chás Shúdáin Theas agus an tír nua á bunú go raibh dóchas againn go n-éireodh go maith leis an tír nua. Ach ag an am céanna, dúirt a lán Feisirí ag an díospóireacht sin go raibh amhras orthu freisin nach mar sin a bheadh agus go mbeadh cogadh cathartha agus mar sin de ann agus sin díreach atá tar éis tarlú. In ionad dul chun cinn, tá siad tar éis dul ar gcúl, in ionad saibhreas a bheith acu tá bochtanas acu agus go háirithe daoine óga agus leanaí, tá siad i mbéal an bháis de bharr ocrais agus níl seans acu oideachas a fháil. Is truamhéalach an scéal é agus dar ndóigh cé gur cheart dúinn leanúint ar aghaidh ag tabhairt cabhair dóibh go háirithe don chosmhuintir, is dóigh liom go bhfuil an ceart ag Coimisinéir Hahn gur cheart dúinn a bheith níos tofáilte leis an dá ghrúpa chun iad a thabhairt le chéile agus sos cogaidh a bheith acu a leanfaidh.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR). -
text: Mr President, the humanitarian crisis in South Sudan is peaking. Millions of people have fled their homes and thousands of them have taken refuge in neighbouring countries. So today South Sudan is facing the world's most worrying food crisis, with nearly 4 million people facing food shortages. Humanitarian aid in this region has increased to almost EUR 7 million, but these funds are not enough. Humanitarian organisations must be urgently strengthened with resources to support Sudan's long-suffering population and children hit by hunger, epidemics and diseases. Finally, the international community must take initiatives to solve the problem in South Sudan, which has religious and ethnic dimensions.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, in regard to all that has been said, I would like to ask the Commission to embrace the idea of the donor conference for South Sudan to fund the needs of humanitarian agencies on the ground. As you know, the last conference on South Sudan was held in Norway, but I do not think that calling upon the international community to convene the next round of the donor conference is a task for a single country. It is clear that the EU – with its global ambition and global responsibility – should play the leading role here.  I am convinced that if the EU institutions work together on this, we can convince the international community to convene the next round of the donor conference on South Sudan and to make the difference which is desperately needed.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, sometimes the independence of a country is the culmination of a long-awaited and lasting peace process. A few more, it becomes the antechamber of a new hell of violence, cruelty and barbarism. The latter is unfortunately the case in South Sudan. The youngest state in the world has already been bathed in the blood of more than 10,000 victims. At times, even aid workers have been raped and massacred. While the two factions are fighting to prevail over each other, for almost a year, there are those who are deaf to common sense, there are those who will lose anyway. There are 3.8 million South Sudanese, without treatment, 1.4 million internally displaced persons, 470 000 refugees in neighbouring countries, hundreds of thousands of children waiting for food and medicine. But who funds the two factions? Who supplies them with weapons and equipment? We as the Eu ropean Union must respond to these questions and use our authority to penalise those who speculate on this war and the leaders responsible for the conflict, in order to strengthen the role of the International Criminal Court. Humanitarian aid is right and important, but it is not enough. To put out a fire you can throw water, but I prefer to stop the arsonists.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, I should like to thank Members for their comments, considerations and engagement. Let me conclude by saying that, to avert the continuation and even worsening of this humanitarian catastrophe, it is paramount first of all to promptly secure a political solution to the crisis. Humanitarian bodies will not be able either financially or operationally to continue responding to a long-lasting crisis of this scale. The European Union must use all its means and channels to help resolve this crisis politically, through continued support for the IGAD-led peace negotiations, as well as through other international fora.  The conflict parties in South Sudan must understand that the patience of the international community has come to an end. At the same time, the Union has a moral duty to continue mobilising life-saving humanitarian funding, especially as all indications are that humanitarian needs will pick up again during the first quarter of 2015, with 2.5 million people expected to be in need of food assistance alone. Let us be clear: the humanitarian crisis in South Sudan is a man-made crisis. The political leaders whose actions have created the tremendous human suffering are finally also the ones to bring back peace and initiate reconciliation, because the world’s youngest nation deserves better than a lost generation of child soldiers and the continuation of a senseless conflict. South Sudan needs a transitional government of national unity which looks after the wellbeing of all its citizens and creates conditions in which the country can prosper.

name: Przewodniczący. -
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday, 13 November 2014.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. South Sudan is experiencing severe hours. The humanitarian situation is simply abominable. South Sudanese are forced to leave their homes and sometimes even their country to seek refuge in neighbouring countries. Water and food are sorely lacking and health care is urgently needed for victims. The civil war that has been raging in South Sudan for almost a year is responsible for irreparable devastation. The European Union has already put in place many programmes to meet the most urgent needs of the local population. More than a third of international humanitarian aid has been provided by the EU. We must not leave it at that! Within the limits granted by the European budget, we must do everything in our power to help the victims of these abominations.
