Member States must also take responsibility for such a crisis. The European Union advocates peace and freedom beyond its borders. We must not confine ourselves to fine words, we must act! I welcome the efforts already made by the European Union and hope that this aid will continue.

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE)
text: in writing. Since December 2013, the humanitarian situation in South Sudan has deteriorated by the day. The escalation of violence against the local population shows no sign of a decrease. Rebels loyal to former Vice-President Riek Machar fight against pro-government fighters, slaughtering the population. Schools are closed, children are recruited as soldiers, entire villages destroyed. We cannot go on like this. A peace agreement has been painstakingly reached, it must be respected and constitutional reforms must absolutely be initiated which will turn South Sudan into a state of law. In fact, this is just the latest of the wars that are tortured the territory of South Sudan, which has not found peace for years. Today, South Sudan is in extreme poverty, yet it is an oil-rich country. However, this immense wealth is not exploited due to the lack of adequate structures and a legal framework convenient for the use of the famous 'black gold'. Europe must not leave South Sudan alone on the difficult path of reform, but it must also ask it to assume its responsibilities in the protection of civilians and in the establishment of a mixed war tribunal, composed of representatives of the international community and South Sudan.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. – The UNITED NATIONS has declared the situation in South Sudan to be a third-degree humanitarian crisis, i.e. the most serious humanitarian crisis. The situation is catastrophic, with 1.9 million people fleeing their homes since December 2013 alone, of which nearly half a million have arrived as refugees in the surrounding countries. A million people are at risk of starvation if there's no displacement. Although the EU has already provided effective financial assistance to the region, aid is regularly attacked and aid workers are at risk. Today's debate is therefore necessary and timely, as international actors must take steps as soon as possible to prevent the situation from escalating further.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. For almost a year now, the internal conflict in South Sudan has caused tens of thousands of deaths, looting of villages, churches and hospitals, and the escapes of almost 2 million people. The ongoing conflict diverts attention from other urgent health issues affecting the country, such as the malaria epidemic that is afflicting the western part, and which the continuation of hostilities worsens on a daily basis. There are many calls from NGOs working on the ground for concrete measures to stop the conflict, given the inefficiency of the peace agreements attempted in recent years. It is news that an agreement has been reached in recent days for a government of national unity between the rebels and President Kiir. Europe is taking immediate action to act as guarantor of this agreement, reaffirming the priority of an immediate ceasefire, including the introduction of arms embargo measures. For 11 months, we have seen war crimes and continuing violations against civilians, particularly religious minorities. It is time to show the face of a new Europe, which does not raise its attention to Africa only when it is threatened by ebola risk or migratory pressures.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The humanitarian situation in South Sudan is undoubtedly one of the biggest challenges facing the international community today. As a result of the disputes of a narrow group of politicians, the Sudanese became victims of their power game. As a result, South Sudan is experiencing the world's largest food disaster, with more than half of its population starving and some 50,000 children dying if they do not receive immediate assistance. The European Commission and the Member States of the European Union have already provided a total of EUR 245 million this year to help the most deprived people in South Sudan. This is undoubtedly a significant sum, but in view of the scale of the problem in South Sudan, it is sufficient only to cover the most pressing needs. It is therefore particularly important to select the right beneficiaries so that the aid is as targeted and effective as possible and, as a result, reaches those who need it most. Unfortunately, in the face of attacks by both sides of the conflict on humanitarian workers, even properly targeted aid is struggling to reach its destination. It is therefore also necessary to implement all the terms of the ceasefire agreement and, subsequently, to end the conflict.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. – The situation of the people of South Sudan is catastrophic as a result of the ongoing conflict. The lives of 3.8 million South Sudanese depend directly on humanitarian aid. However, there is not enough help. The European Union must make a full possible action to end the conflict in South Sudan and, in cooperation with the UNITED NATIONS and other donors, review the state of humanitarian needs and opportunities and, if necessary, convene an international donor conference in South Sudan. At the same time, humanitarian aid must be prevented from reaching the hands of armed groups and the security of aid workers must be ensured. Those responsible for violence and human rights violations must be brought to justice and the International Criminal Court should be involved.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. – South Sudan is the youngest country in the world. And its population is young, half of them are children. But these children, instead of going to school, are today subjected to violence, displaced from their homes, recruited into soldiers and forced into armed conflicts. Today, children in South Sudan are at risk of famine, water shortages and deaths from avoidable diseases, that the conditions in which they live in refugee camps are better.  South Sudan has been hit hard today by a conflict that has killed thousands and displaced hundreds of thousands. Fleeing terror, refugees have also sought salvation in neighbouring countries. Hundreds of thousands of people are in refugee camps, which have also been flooded by rains. Cholera, typhoid and other illnesses broke out, and in some camps, according to media reports, mothers were waiting in line to bury their children. Because of the conflict, the fields are not seeded and the country is threatened with famine.  According to UN estimates, by the end of this year, a third of people will be facing starvation. People in South Sudan need our help. Children in South Sudan need our help. I firmly believe that EU aid will not be absent and that we will not let them down, and that is why I support this statement by Commission Vice-President Federica Mogherini.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – One cannot but fully support the maintenance of humanitarian action by the EU in South Sudan. Also its extension and strengthening. However, the time has come for the Union, on an autonomous basis, to initiate and improve its intelligence-gathering and assessment capabilities in Sudan and contiguous areas regarding: security; changing patterns of tribal and ethnic tensions; land use; raw material resource potential and contested claims to such resources; climate change; and most importantly perhaps, ongoing population movements, voluntary or not. Such capabilities are at present deficient. On population movements, we need to know what the prospects are over the short to medium term. Tension and strife in the Sudan and contiguous areas have triggered bloody civil wars, dilapidated infrastructures, destroyed stable social structures and forced millions to find refuge away from their home. This has contributed to the disruptive pressures of illegal immigration across North Africa and the Mediterranean. We need a better understanding of the extent to which these pressures can develop, or to which they can be relieved, so that humanitarian and immigration commitments are made by the EU and nation states within a framework that our citizens will consider to be reasonable, prudent and enlightened.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. The current situation in South Sudan is very worrying. It is a pity that the optimism felt at the birth of this new country is replaced by the suffering resulting from armed conflict. If the situation worsens, there is a risk that the conflict will spread to neighbouring countries, which could lead to increased violence and piracy on the coast of Somalia. The EU has MISSIONS related to the CSDP in this region, and if they were sent the necessary equipment, there would be a greater chance of peace and stability being restored. Ceerum censeo France will seriously regret its decision to sell the Mistral helicopter carriers to Russia.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. – As the issues in South Sudan become ever so dire I would like to voice my continued support for the South Sudanese people. The necessity of working with what remain of the humanitarian aid groups in the region, to make sure that the support gets to where it is needed most, is vital. While the resolution is very direct, I feel we must put a human face to the document. More than 10 000 people have died since December of 2013. Many social services are no longer in operation, which has had the largest impact on children who are not able to attend schools and which the violence is heavily directed at. In addition, basic health care and clean water services are currently non-existent. Further, the ever-so-apparent ethnic aspect of the conflict cannot be tolerated. The EU must support the Sudanese through this conflict and reassure them that the safety and wellbeing of the people come first and foremost. We must not forget that this is a young country built, as we are, on democratic values, and while this conflict threatens those values it is important that they be protected and given the opportunity to prosper.

name: Przewodniczący. -
text: The next item is the joint debate on the Commission's statement a amend to Protocol 31 to the EEA Agreement on cooperation in specific fields outside the four freedoms (31.3.2014, COM(2014) 197) on the European Union Programme for Employment and Social Innovation ("EaSI") and the European Microfinance Facility for Employment and Social Inclusion "Progress" (2014/2885(RSP))

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, this item on today’s agenda concerns two decisions of the European Economic Area (EEA) Joint Committee and one decision of the EU-Swiss Joint Committee on the Free Movement of Persons Agreement.  Let me start with the first two decisions which concern Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein. The first one concerns the amendment to Protocol 31 to the EEA Agreement which enables the EEA-EFTA states to participate in the EU Programme for Employment and Social Innovation (EaSI) and in the European Progress Microfinance Facility for employment and social inclusion. It also provides for a financial contribution by these countries based on the same distribution key as EU Member States. The second decision concerns the amendment to the same Protocol 31 in order to provide for cooperation regarding the free movement of workers, the coordination of social security systems and measures for migrants, including migrants from third countries. The EEA-EFTA states – Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein – participate fully in the EU rules on the free movement of workers and on social security coordination. The aim of this second Council decision is therefore to continue cooperation in this area through a financial contribution by the EEA-EFTA states to the monitoring of Union law on such issues. The decision is adopted every year and has become a standard procedure since the conclusion of the EEA Agreement.  The Council adopted both decisions establishing the EU position to be taken in the EEA Joint Committee on 5 June, and the EEA Joint Committee adopted the decisions amending the EEA Agreement on 27 June.  As regards the decision of the EU-Swiss Joint Committee on the Free Movement of Persons Agreement, the Commission submitted the draft decision amending Annex II to the Agreement to the Council. The Council’s decision is expected on 25 November. This fourth adaptation incorporates new EU legal provisions in order to ensure the consistent and correct application of Union legislation and to avoid administrative and possible legal difficulties. This is a technical amendment that will incorporate the changes to the EU legislation, for instance those concerning persons working in two or more Member States, and that will help determine which legislation applies. I would like to highlight that the adoption of this decision will contribute to ensuring that the same rules are applied to the coordination of social security systems, irrespective of whether EU citizens live and work in Switzerland or in another EU Member State.

name: Thomas Mann
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. One priority for Parliament and the Commission is to create new, high-quality and sustainable jobs. 85% of all jobs in the EU are provided by small and medium-sized enterprises. We need to create a climate that encourages the emergence of new SMEs. For the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, this includes, in addition to cutting red tape, above all financial support for these new businesses. Progress has proved effective here, an instrument that facilitates better access to microcredit for those who have been struggling to get access to bank loans. The European Commission's report on implementation of 20 October shows that this instrument has made a major contribution to creating jobs. More than 20 000 prospective entrepreneurs have benefited from loans and guarantees totalling more than EUR 180 million. That gives hope! An EU programme for employment and social innovation has been building on the success of Progress since the beginning of this year.  A study published in parallel with the report shows that the demand for microcredit is far from being met! It is estimated that the gap is around EUR 2.7 billion. There is a need for action here, especially in view of the record unemployment in many Member States. I also support the extension of parts of microfinance to the EEA/EFTA countries, as Mrs Thyssen has just described. The European Economic Area, as a deep free trade area, expands our EU internal market to 31 countries.  If countries such as Norway and Iceland are to participate, it will not only strengthen trade and not only the markets, but above all the much-needed workforce in the EU. I believe that coordination with other financial instruments, such as our European Social Fund, is essential!

name: Jutta Steinruck
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, on behalf of the European Socialists and Democrats, I would like to welcome you to this Chamber for the first time! We look forward to working with you! The amendments made here in Protocol 31 to the EEA Agreement are important because they provide positive support for employment and the free movement of workers in the European Economic Area. After all, we have long since had a European labour market in which our states and our citizens benefit from the opportunities also offered by cross-border worker mobility. Of course, there is still much to be done here. Nevertheless, joint cooperation – seminars, better coordination, mutual support, learning from each other – is already helping to improve. That is why we support this amendment. As Parliament's rapporteur on the EaSI programme, I am pleased that these parts are also being extended.

name: Anthea McIntyre
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would very much like to welcome Ms Thyssen here as our new Commissioner, and on behalf of the ECR Group, I very much look forward to working with her in the months and years ahead. It seems to me that the three measures that we are looking at are pretty uncontroversial. They are highly technical. It is a standard procedure. I do not really think it is something that this Parliament can influence, and I agree completely with a lot of what Mr Mann has already said. We have often rehearsed the importance of SMEs to job creation, but here tonight I find it rather strange that we are sitting here to debate agreements which I believe have already been agreed in the Council and the EEA Joint Committee. So I am not really sure what our role as a Parliament is, apart from being informed, which of course we have been. I do not think we should be wasting parliamentary time on issues where we, as legislators, have no role. Not so long ago we listened to Mr Timmermans, whose role it is to foster better regulation. I would suggest that, as a Parliament, we ought to adopt the idea of better regulation to simplify and reduce administrative burdens. I would urge us, as a Parliament, to reflect that in our business.

name: Marian Harkin
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I too would like to warmly welcome Commissioner Thyssen to Parliament here this evening on behalf of the ALDE Group in the Parliament. I too am looking forward to working with her and her secretariat for the next number of years.  I tend to agree with Ms McIntyre – as I sometimes do – on the item we are discussing here this evening. I am not sure what role we play here other than for information, but nonetheless we are discussing it, so I therefore have just a few comments to make on the amendments that are in front of us. The first one is to allow the cooperation of the contracting parties to extend to social affairs. By doing this, we will ensure that Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein will be able, for example, to access the Progress Microfinance Facility. As we know, this fund was set up to help microbusinesses. It provides funds of up to EUR 25 000 for small businesses, if they are either setting up or expanding. It is particularly targeted at those who have difficulty accessing credit from conventional credit lines. I am very pleased to see this and to see the good outcomes so far in a recent Commission report as to how this Progress Microfinance Facility has worked. It has given over EUR 182 million to over 20 000 entrepreneurs, and the crucial point is that 60% of those final users were unemployed or inactive, and 30% were women. So it is getting to those who are targeted and, from that perspective, not only do I think it is an excellent facility within the EU, but I am glad to see that it will be extended to the EFTA countries.  The other amendment we are discussing this evening is the amendment to include cooperation concerning the free movement of workers. My only comment on that is that I – like most people in this Parliament – believe that this is a cornerstone of EU policy and I will be pleased to see that right extended to the countries in question.

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I have asked to speak because, working in the Committee on Regional Development, I have been able to see how important and interdependent the four freedoms and the local economy of the regions and therefore also of each Member State are. Reading this proposal, I would like to point out that, in formulating the European Union's position on the agreement with the Swiss Confederation on the free movement of persons and the coordination of social security systems, I would like to take account of the fact that Switzerland, being also the beneficiary of many European programmes and funding, such as EaSI and Horizon – under certain conditions, but benefiting from it – , under no circumstances should it propose measures to prevent the free movement of persons. Discriminatory actions against so-called cross-border workers, such as those taken following last February's referendum, should be avoided, as should any administrative and legal difficulties relating to social security schemes.

name: Marcel de Graaff (NI). -
text: The proposed amendment to Protocol 31 to the EEA Agreement of 12 May 2014 will once again extend the European Commission's financial scope to facilitate the free movement of migrants from third countries via EFTA countries, including Norway. We now know the extent of the problems with Muslim migrants in Norway. In Oslo, rapes of Western women by non-Western immigrants are the order of the day. The police don't dare enter islamized neighborhoods anymore. A country like Norway, with an absurd open borders policy towards non-Western immigrants, is the gateway to the rest of the European Union. This contradicts United Nations Resolution 2178, which imposes an obligation on each country precisely because of the danger of jihadists to prevent this free movement between Member States. I therefore conclude that this proposal is scandalous and must be thrown in the bin.

name: Verónica Lope Fontagné (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, since its inception, the European Union has been characterised by being a region of economic, social and territorial integration that fights for freedom and seeks social welfare. With economic improvement, the new European Commission has set out to move forward on social issues as a key measure to strengthen the crisis, with the aim of achieving sustainable growth. But to do so, credit needs to flow again. We are not tired of repeating that small and medium-sized enterprises are the key to growth and job creation, as my colleague Thomas Mann has said, but to achieve this, there has to be a sequence in events. There has to be growth to create jobs, and for it to happen it requires an investment from companies that can only be achieved if they have access to credit. I therefore welcome the view that States outside the European Union deepen their agreements with us, adopting them as their own and participating financially in Community policies which, as is the case today, offer great opportunities to small and medium-sized enterprises, especially through microfinance appropriations, which will contribute to improving the European business fabric and , therefore, the well-being of our citizens.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D). -
text: Mr President, freedom of movement is one of the basic pillars with which we have built the European Union and, therefore, today I welcome and support the ability to extend this freedom of movement, these agreements, to third countries, to neighbouring countries of the European Union. But it is also true that freedom of movement is much more than the elimination of borders, it is much more than being able to travel without a passport. Freedom of movement must also ensure that a number of basic rights can be transported within the European Union, in order to ensure equal opportunities and citizens' rights. To be able to advance freedom of movement with third countries is fine, but to do so we must also ensure that freedom of movement between the countries of the European Union contemplates, as I say, the possibility of 'portabilizing' a number of rights which we consider basic, such as the right to unemployment benefits, the right to pensions, the right to health and the right to education. They are essential pillars of our European social model and, if we believe in European citizenship, we must work to ensure that this concept of European citizenship, the principle of freedom of movement, undoubtedly includes the 'portability' of these rights among the European Union's own states.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, the European Economic Area is an agreement based on four fundamental freedoms – the freedom of movement of persons, goods, services and capital. This is what I like very much about European cooperation. And I admire that countries that are in the European Economic Area and are not in the EU have these four freedoms without what I would call a ballast, without that bureaucracy, without subsidy programmes, without a common agricultural policy. These countries do not have to apply European customs duties to imports of goods. They just have four freedoms and they don't have extra bureaucracy. So I would not confuse this contract with anything else, on the contrary, we should take an example from this model here. I think that if we disbanded the whole EU and we all stayed only in the Agreement on the European Economic Area, we would have done our best.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI). -
text: Mr President, the agreement on the European Economic Area allows states such as Norway to cooperate with the European Union in specific sectors, negotiated on a case-by-case basis. Today, we are being offered to extend this cooperation, and I quote, to "actions on behalf of migrants, including migrants from third countries". This reflects the desire to improve the situation of immigrants and I consider this will anachronistic, because it will encourage more emigrants to come to Europe. However, European states are experiencing a major economic crisis and no longer have the means to welcome people fleeing poverty and who will be dependent on them. The proposal being discussed today is all the more anachronistic because it goes against the realism displayed by the European Court of Justice. In a judgment handed down yesterday, 11 November, the Court recognises the right of states to deny social assistance to immigrants who are not working. The conclusion is clear: the European Parliament is completely cut off from social realities.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE). -
text: First of all, thank You to Commissioner Thyssen. The fact that she is making her first appearance in the European Parliament here at 11 o'clock in the evening is a great commitment. I agree with previous colleagues who have already said that we look forward to cooperation over the next five years. I also agree with colleagues, Mrs McIntyre and Mrs Harkin, who have raised some questions about the values of this debate this evening, especially since we are talking here in November 2014 about decisions which should have actually taken effect on 1 January 2014. My question is: how does this work and how has this gone in the last 11 months? Secondly, I am very pleased that we are also aligning our agreement on the free movement of workers and the coordination of social security with countries such as Norway, Liechtenstein and Switzerland, with which we, as European countries, also have many limits. I would also like to call for a good look at how the coordination of social security and the free movement of workers in our own EU is regulated. I believe that there are still many areas of improvement in the area of frontier labour, access to cross-border care and cross-border enterprise. I hope that we will be able to emphasise this together over the next five years. I wish you every success.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I wish you every success in your work. As you know, the free movement of workers is one of the fundamental pillars of the European Union, it is even an identity right. The Union exists because there is a possibility for people living in this part of the world to be able to move freely. This is a great advantage for them, for the realisation of their personality, and it is a great advantage for companies, because it represents the availability of an extraordinary resource denied to other countries. However, in order for freedom of movement to express its potential, it is important to do what we are doing this evening, which is to ensure that people who move, whatever the reason for their mobility – work rather than leisure rather than the performance of cultural functions – that there is coordination of social security systems. People give their best when they are protected; otherwise, they risk simply becoming instruments in the hands of a financial or productive system that exploits and does not value them. That is why it is very important to keep these two things together: free movement with the protection of people and the recognition of their rights.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI). -
text: Mr President, the regulation setting out a European Union programme for employment and social innovation was adopted on 11 December, less than a year ago. This regulation provides for a mid-term evaluation on July 1, 2017. I think it is particularly hasty to extend its application to the states of the Free Trade Economic Association, members of the European Economic Area. Moreover, the extension of this regulation seems particularly risky, especially after yesterday's decision by the European Court of Justice, which points out that the conditions for granting social benefits are solely the responsibility of the Member States. According to the Court, a state has the right to exclude nationals from other Member States from the benefit of certain social benefits. As a French Member of Parliament, I also regret that my country refuses such a restriction, since in France, social benefits are sometimes also paid to non-EU foreigners, including those who have entered our territory illegally.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking The inclusion of non-EU countries in the European Economic Area in the latest initiatives in the areas of social policy and the labour market seems to be the rightest and worth supporting. However, we should consider why these countries do not want to take full advantage of this possibility. Their reluctance to join the Employment and Social Innovation Programme must be of particular concern. In principle, only Iceland expressed its readiness to participate in the programme and Norway declared its participation in one of its axes. Given that this programme aims to develop innovative ways of combating social problems, it is surprising that eea countries are not interested in them, especially as they are acting as effectively as possible in the areas of social policy and the labour market. Perhaps they therefore do not see added value in the EU programme, but only additional costs. It is therefore worth considering whether it has been designed in a sensible way, especially as programmes such as Progress and EURES have long been criticised for their poor effectiveness and no way of improving their effectiveness has yet been found. Nevertheless, the restraint of Norway and Liechtenstein, whatever its cause, should signal to us the need to monitor the functioning of the Employment and Social Innovation Programme on an ongoing basis and to modify its mechanisms where necessary.  However, following the changes to the EU-Switzerland agreement, I ask the European Commission what it will propose in the wake of the February referendum in Switzerland introducing maximum quotas for immigrants? Initially, there was talk of excluding Switzerland from programmes such as Erasmus and Horizon 2020. But what are the specifics for today? What is the situation with the Free Movement agreement between Croatia and Switzerland? Is the EU's position firm enough on the freedoms in the de facto internal market that Switzerland benefits from?  Commissioner, I wish you much, much success in this difficult dossier.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D). -
text: What we are talking about here is more important than the interest shown here, because the four main European core values are at stake here. I would like to reassure anyone who thinks that there must be some form of immigration here to protect our community. No. This is also about, say, a citizen of an EU country going to a country in the European economic area. Yes, there too will be social rights for EU citizens. So we are talking about defending common values, and at the same time we are giving excellent evidence that even populist governments cannot have an excuse and an opportunity to chip away at our existing core values simply because they think they may not like someone personally. By the way, the European Court of Justice's decision was about individual judgment, not in general.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would like to wish the new Commissioner every success. I join my colleagues in deciding to tighten up the commitment that they will have to make, we need it. The amendment to Protocol 31 to the EEA Agreement contains a number of important social demands, including entrepreneurial ones, but also, if I may say so, cultural ones. Let us see what are the elements, clearly not without grey areas, areas where there are obviously risks, as my fellow Members have said, risks that affect the relationship with the movement of persons and risks that affect the relationship with certain States. The case of Switzerland has been mentioned in this regard. First of all, I would like to point out that, on the one hand, we are dealing with a central issue, which is the spread of a mentality according to which a strong Europe is a Europe with united social policies. That is the first point. We have today discussed, for a number of reasons linked to the vicissitudes of Luxembourg, the problem of the unification of fiscal policies, but let us not forget the need for a path linked to the unification of social policies. On the other hand, the development of an awareness of business culture. Support for small and medium-sized enterprises, as has been mentioned, is support for a great cultural battle. Starting again for us today means first of all giving oxygen to those who risk, to those who undertake, especially if not protected by that network that often protects the productive realities even on our continent. Those who risk his must be supported because he generates value and educates the people.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D). -
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done on this I too would like to add my voice to so many other speeches which wish you every success in your work as Commissioner. On the subject: the EaSI programme is a financial instrument of the European Union for the promotion of employment, social policy and labour mobility. It is therefore a question of social innovation. This is very important in this context, if we are talking here at a very late hour in this round about the fact that we are not mixing apples with pears here. There have been speeches here which have then more or less drifted in the wrong direction and which repeatedly call into question the fact that workers here are using more or less things that they are not entitled to. That is not the issue. It is always important to point out that people who immigrate and pay their taxes here are also making a very valuable contribution to this European labour market.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I am very glad to have the opportunity to say that I believe that Mr de Graaff’s remarks earlier in the debate broke the rules of this House. I believe his remarks were explicitly racist and xenophobic and promoted racial intolerance in a way that is not acceptable or allowed in the constitution of this House.  I would ask you, please, to see that after this debate Mr De Graaff’s remarks on the record are examined carefully, exactly what he said is scrutinised by the President, and that if he is found to have broken the rules of this House he should be censured and he should not be permitted – and nobody should be permitted – to come back in here with that kind of racist filth that this House is better than and does not accept.  On the substance of the debate I disagree with colleagues who said that we do not need to talk about this. I think it is very useful this week to be able to talk about labour mobility in the context of Switzerland, Norway and Iceland, all of which are recipients of hugely disproportionate influxes of EU citizens into their economies. That is what people need to understand: this is not about them coming here; it is actually about us going there. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, I am very committed to freedom of expression; myself, I have suffered very serious attacks on my freedom of expression in my country simply because I had dared to express political opinions that not everyone likes. I believe that it is fundamental that, in this Parliament at least, there is a kind of peaceful haven that promotes respect for everyone's freedom of expression and I ask you, Mr Simon, if you are, as I am, attached to this freedom of expression, because I have been extremely shocked by the way you seem to be exercising a police of thought on Mr de Graaff's words.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – Freedom of expression is not an absolute right, it is a privilege. You do not have the freedom to say anything you like, anytime you like, to anybody. This House has a constitution which puts limits on the level of abuse and filth that you can bring in here. That man crossed the line and broke the rules and he should not be allowed to do it again.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL). -
text: I will only talk about the application of these agreements in Swiss territory. This has to do with a very lively concern that there are about 120,000 Portuguese workers in Switzerland. These workers are present in many sectors, from construction, hospitality, metalworking, watchmaking... Of course, most of these workers suffer the scourge of unemployment. The Portuguese social security does not automatically recognise the social benefits allocated by Switzerland. That is, this covers pensions, disability and unemployment benefit itself. In this regard, we support these measures aimed at harmonising social security standards and thereby facilitating the mobility of workers.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: member of the Commission. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you very much for the warm welcome I have received here as the new Commissioner in the house where I have worked with so much pleasure for so many years. I am, of course, also grateful for the fruitful debate we have had and for the welcome you are giving to the Progress and EaSI European programmes, to the free movement of workers and the coordination of social security, and for the fact that we also want to share these things with people from the EFTA countries. I have also heard a number of comments, a comment on the agenda in this Parliament. Why are we discussing this here? Well, that is a consequence of the Interinstitutional Agreement between the Commission and Parliament. We are asked to make statements on this subject, and if it is requested from Parliament's services, we are happy to come here to make the statements we were asked to make and to listen to the comments you make about it. Secondly, there was also criticism here that these agreements would increase the rights and freedoms of certain persons. I have to deny that, because no new rights are granted in these agreements. That has to be rectified. Then we were also asked about the timing of these changes. According to some colleagues, including our Dutch colleague Jeroen Lange, the timing seems too late. But the agreement is that the incorporation of the legislative act into those international agreements must be done as soon as possible after they have entered into force in the European Union. So I think that timing can still be considered to have been respected. A number of comments have also been made on the free movement of people and the referendum in Switzerland. I think that this discussion is over the subject of tonight's debate, but I can assure you that the Commission regularly comes to the Committee on Foreign Affairs to inform the European Parliament's colleagues about the relationship with Switzerland on this issue and that the Commission is also prepared to continue to do so in the future. Then there are a few comments on the judgment handed down by the Court yesterday, in which it responds to a preliminary question on the application of German law. This, too, goes beyond the subject of this debate. In any case, I would ask colleagues to interpret this court's ruling correctly. The Court has said that Germany does indeed have the right to deny certain people certain social protection benefits in the circumstances clearly defined in the judgment. But this is such a delicate question that I recommend everyone to read that judgment thoroughly. In any case, it is a judgment that respects the free movement of persons and gives an interpretation, makes a review of a piece of German law. Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for all the comments that have been made. You can be sure that, on the part of the European Commission, the programmes mentioned here, Progress and EaSI, will be implemented as efficiently as possible, and, of course, to the free movement and coordination of social security regulations. I would just like to answer the question put by Mrs Jazlowiecka, who asked how it is that some of the EFTA countries do not participate in certain parts of the programmes. Well, Mrs Jazlowiecka, Norway has announced that it will soon join the other part of the programme and Liechtenstein has decided not to participate in everything, solely for financial reasons. Because if the EFTA countries participate in the programmes, they, like the countries of the European Union, are also expected to contribute their share of their funding. And Liechtenstein felt that this was not appropriate for financial reasons at this time.

name: Przewodniczący. -
text: I close the discussion on this item on the agenda. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In today's debate, the issue of 'zoning' or retraining of teachers who have been made redundant as a result of the reduction in school branches due to demographic decline among children is an important issue. Sometimes teachers over the age of 60 do not meet the expectations of children and young people for health reasons (physical education teachers) or because of the use of increasingly modern IT techniques, to which young people adapt immediately (computer science teachers). An employment programme for unemployed teachers should be prepared, using their specialities and professional experience in service positions for vulnerable children or the elderly. Europe's ageing population will require such a programme. When it comes to innovation, teachers should be included in the further education and in-service training programme in order to be able to influence students' creativity.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. – As is known, the proposal is for EFTA States to participate in actions relating to the following budget line entered in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2014: - Item 04 03 01 03: "Free movement of workers and coordination of social security systems and measures for migrant workers, including migrant workers from third countries". This will also make Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland partners, while at the same time a possibility for closer European cooperation in order to freer movement of workers. At the same time, we must also pay attention to the fact that, following the judgment of the European Court of Justice C-333/13 of 11 November 2014, the free movement of inactive EU citizens who are not seeking work cannot be unduly and unjustified.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In the context of the debate on the amendment of Protocol 31 to the EEA Agreement on cooperation on the free movement of workers, the coordination of social security systems and actions for migrants, including migrants from third countries, I draw attention to the need to respect the principle of free movement of workers. This key principle, which more than half of EU citizens consider to be the greatest achievement of European integration, has recently become too often the subject of national political competitions. Such actions undermine the credibility of the EU project and create resentment towards migrants among local communities. It is also important to highlight the fact that immigrants not only do not strain social security systems, but mainly contribute to the economic growth of the country of immigration.  We must also bear in mind that we have more than 2 million vacancies in the Union, so mobility, especially in regions with labour shortages and skills mismatch, is essential for their development. Action to ensure that Union citizens enjoy the principle of free movement is also crucial. Almost half of migrant citizens complain about administrative obstacles related to ignorance of the EU's right to free movement among local government employees.  Europe needs growth and new jobs. So instead of undermining the principle of free movement, we need to focus on fighting unemployment and boosting investment that will create jobs.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The anti-immigration rhetoric in Europe is one of the most worrying tendencies gaining traction in our Union. Freedom of movement, which is in fact one of the core principles of the EU, is threatened due to the growing fears of welfare drain, expressed by some of the wealthier nations. Crucially, however, we need to distinguish between free movement of people and free access to Member States’ social assistance systems. It is inappropriate and extremely worrying that some European countries point to ‘benefit tourism’ as a pretext for curbing immigration and hence for restricting the basic rights of the EU citizens. Admittedly, the number of beneficiaries of social welfare in some states, like Germany, has grown in the recent months, yet it has been established that immigrants, on average, receive less financial assistance than the local population in the host country. In Britain, for instance, immigrants contributed 64% more in taxes than they received in welfare in the past 10 years. Even if ‘benefits tourism’ was a real danger, it would still not be a sufficient reason to limit free movement. As I previously pointed out in an open letter to British PM David Cameron, and confirmed by the ECJ ruling from 11 November this year, countries are under no obligation to pay social benefits to migrants if they are economically inactive. Spelling out and uniformly applying such rules across the European Economic Area can counter populist anti-immigration debates, which undermine the very pillars of the European Union. I thus welcome the extension of the EEA agreement to including cooperation concerning free movement of workers, coordination of social security systems and measures for migrants, including migrants from third countries.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. This amendment, which incorporates EU-funded projects for the free movement of workers and actions for migrants into the EEA agreement, accompanies the strengthening of economic and social rights in Europe. Migrant workers, including those from third countries, must be able to assert their social security rights and gain easier access to the European labour market. It is essential that the Union, together with the EEA countries, finance projects in this direction. There are many voices in Europe calling for restricting the free movement of people, a freedom that our Union has built on. The idea of undermining this freedom is unbearable, because it means wanting to reform barriers within Europe and to close in on ourselves. Let us stop pointing the finger at migrant workers in Europe as those responsible for the crisis. On the contrary, mobility and openness will help to reorient Europe on the path to growth, through the pooling of skills and the enrichment of our economies by the arrival of new talent. Against the rhetoric of rejection and hatred of the other, Europe must remain strong in defending the free movement of people while continuing to open up to the world.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. – The European Union needs a smart policy of coordinating migration within its territory and between it and third countries. An intelligent policy must first of all be fair and humane, but it must take into account the creation of the best economic and social contexts for the definitive or temporary integration of migrants. We need to attract talented and project-based people to the European Union. We cannot close the door to the despair of those who try to cross our borders in the name of survival, but it is more daring and courageous if we are able to implement an active policy of openness and exchange. The more migrants arriving in the Union - not on a desperate run, but part of a common project they want to share - and the more Europeans leave our territory not in disillusionment, but with a universalist sense and global vision, the more humane and more sustainable migration policy in the EU can be. This is the meaning of the proposed amendments, although clearly insufficient, and i should support it.

name: Przewodniczący. -
text: The next item is one-minute speeches on significant political issues (Article 163 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Claude Rolin (PPE). -
text: Mr President, the free movement of workers is indeed an essential achievement, but it cannot become an instrument of social dumping. The Detachment Directive has been revised and the President of the Commission has stated his intention to have it applied to the letter and to implement a targeted revision. In Belgium, sectors such as construction are now at risk. Since 2012, more than 12,000 jobs have disappeared and the worst is to be feared if the situation does not change. This dumping endangers the lives of companies and creates a climate of mistrust among salaried workers while fuelling the rejection of the European project. The Belgian state has put in place a legal mechanism to prevent abuses, but the European Commission is now threatening Belgium with proceedings before the Court of Justice, in contradiction with the announced desire to vigorously combat social dumping. Jean-Claude Juncker said we had five years to succeed. It is therefore urgent to translate these words into action by implementing the provisions preventing social dumping. This is an essential issue for the European project.

name: Maria Arena
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr. President, I will talk about a subject that may seem a little lighter than the one my colleague has just touched on, and yet it is just as important. It concerns football, and particularly a match that has put the stability of the Balkan region in difficulty - and perhaps in great difficulty. In October, the Serbia-Albania match took place, during which something intolerable happened, especially in the stands, where insults were uttered against the Albanian players. Of course, the Union cannot say anything to UEFA, but the Commissioner for Enlargement and the High Representative will, in any case, have to try to underline the responsibilities of both the Albanian and Serbian sides in this matter, so that such incidents - there have been others - cannot happen again and, above all, to ensure that the difficult efforts that are being made to stabilise the region can be continued. Sometimes it takes little to do and often the football stands are laboratories. So we have to be very careful about what happened.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR). -
text: Mr. President! We are celebrating 25 years of the fall of the Berlin Wall this week. There were at least 138 dead at the border. We are celebrating the end of the wall. Our honourable Colleague Mrs Zimmer from the SED successor party Die Linke put on the record this morning that it was only in 1988 that we had the first slight doubts about the GDR system, after 137 deaths at the border. Now Ms Zimmer's friends have stolen the memorial crosses for the victims and desecrated the memorials. Today, Mrs Zimmer missed an important opportunity – to distance herself from it. In her speech, which is far too long, not a single word of regret!  However, I am pleased to be living in a country where such speeches can be made and where the successors to the SED can also exercise their right to freedom of expression without restriction. Democracy and the rule of law endure this! The colleague who has just spoken has already wanted to restrict freedom of expression. If we get this, let us oppose all efforts to curtail freedom of speech and expression, with whatever argument!

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE). -
text: Mr President, colleagues, my homeland, the Republic of Bulgaria until recently was seen as an example of balanced ethno-religious relations, which, thanks to the model of tolerance, was the only one in the Balkans to make a bloodless transition from totalitarianism to democracy, despite the forcibly changed names and forbidden religious customs of Muslims in the period 1984-1989. Unfortunately, since the country's admission to the EU, we have seen a kind of boom in extreme nationalism, in the language of ethno-religious hatred, in order to lead to the direct participation of the xenophobic political force Patriotic Front in today's government of the country. Today, Bulgaria is the only EU member country with a total ban on the use of mother tongues in the election campaign. With this in mind, we find it particularly important to know that the President of dps, Mr. Lyuthvi Meston, and seven other colleagues have been sanctioned by the authorities of the administration of justice for saying some of their phrases in their mother tongue during their pre-election meetings with voters. Notice— and in your mother tongue, not only. That includes me. Today I present to you the decision of the Central Electoral Commission. We've been hearing voices at the highest level lately. The Deputy Prime Minister of the Republic, Mrs. Rumyana Bachvarova, pleaded for the removal of the five-minute news in mother tongue from the airwaves of national television. I beat the bell here in the European Parliament and call on the European institutions to engage with the case before it is too late.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, recently, in all weather, nearly a quarter of a million people took to the streets across Ireland to protest at the privatisation of our water and to protect the public supply for future generations. This latest tax on the Irish people was expected to raise around EUR 0.5 billion in 2015. At the same time, between now and 2032, the Irish Central Bank will take in and destroy EUR 28 billion. That is enough to build a state-of-the-art water supply system, but instead, at the behest of the ECB, this broke country borrows billions to destroy in order to pay for the legacy of bailing out the European banking system. Today in this Chamber we celebrated the fall of that wall in Berlin, but let us also recognise that there is a new wall – an even higher and an even longer wall – which is the wall between those who have and those who have not, the wall built and reinforced by the likes of Jean-Claude Juncker. The Irish people have suffered enough at this stage. We have sacrificed enough. I am now asking for the support of the supposed solidarity that we have in the European Union to destroy these odious promissory notes. We would like to do it with you, but we will do it on our own if we have to. That is all I have to say.

name: Margrete Auken (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President! Endocrine disruptors have become part of everyday life for ordinary people. A new Danish study shows that no one walks free from hormone chemistry: men's fertility, fetal brain damage, testicular cancer. The consequences are dramatic. In the European Union, we still lack clear criteria for endocrine disruptors so that we can take action. The Commission has so far held back for fear of hitting the chemicals industry. That can't be right! That is why I would urge Health Commissioner Andriukaitis to comply with the legal requirements of the EU 7th Environmental Action Programme, namely to 'develop harmonised hazard-based criteria for the identification of endocrine disruptors'. It is time we protected citizens and set legislation according to science and not after the lobby of the cynical chemicals industry.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I shall speak about public water and private water. In Sicily and Sardinia, even today, there are major problems with water supply and all too often families and farmers literally remain without a drop of water. We voted in Italy for a referendum to guarantee public water to all Italian citizens but, at the moment, public water remains a utopia and those who really enjoy it are those who make millions of profits from a good that should be everyone's. Historically, water has been an instrument of control of the territory by the Mafia. Mafia management of water resources is one of the oldest privatisation experiments. The Mafia is the first organisation to have realised the economic potential of the deal and the state, alas, subsequently imitated it. Think that, a few days ago, a 68-year-old pensioner from Lucca Sicula died of a heart attack after suffering the detachment of the water supply. You can die from lack of water in Europe in 2014. We call for all citizens to be able to enjoy the right to water as a fundamental right and for the institutions to ensure that the funds do not end up in the hands of mafias and corrupt politicians. Water is a common good, put it in your head.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI). -
text: Mr President, in Greece, the government and the troika are planning to raise the retirement age again, effectively abolish supplementary pensions and further reduce the remaining health benefits by consolidating the sinking insurance funds, as employers and the state are exempt from their obligations to benefit from private occupational insurance in accordance with EU policy. They plan to release collective redundancies, lockout for employers, effectively abolish the strike right to deal with reactions to the escalation of the attack. The European Union, with long-term memoranda, imposes a generalised poverty line everywhere with crumbs on the impoverished, wage reductions with a minimum guaranteed income, a pension guarantee of EUR 360. These are the cause of workers' war against the European Union, their monopolies and their power. That is why on November 1st with the Pan-Working Racing Front in Athens of the Memorandum, on November 6th in Brussels with no memorandum, hundreds of thousands of workers took to the streets with common demands. Hands off Social Security, yes to wage increases, down to unpopular taxes!

name: Daniel Buda (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I would like to draw attention to an extremely serious problem that happened in Romania in the presidential elections on 2 November, when the right to vote was violated, especially for the more than 3 million Romanian citizens outside the country's borders. The government led by the Prime Minister, Victor Ponta, candidate for the presidency of Romania, decided to set up only 294 polling stations abroad, and these poorly distributed, having only one polling station in communities with tens of thousands of Romanians. Romanian diplomats in these countries drew attention to these shortcomings, and local authorities in the various countries expressed their willingness to support this electoral process, but Victor Ponta, as Prime Minister, took no action. The resignation of the Foreign Minister, Titus Corlățean, and its replacement, but without increasing the number of polling stations, is not such as to solve this problem for the second round of 16 November, and a fundamental right, namely to choose, provided for by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, is still being violated.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D). -
text: Sur President, f'Mejju, i大-ikeittadin Ewropew wera li jrid bidla fit-tmexxija tal-Ewropa. Forsi wkoll xtaq li s-sinjal għall-bidla jingħata minn dan il-Parlament. Kważi shit xhur wara l-elezzjonijiet Ewropej, nistaqsi: il-bidla li l-kostitwenti tagħna riedu, qiegħda stħħ? Ingħid li mhijiex. Stennejt li jkollna dibattiti dwar xi jridu l-popli Ewropej, dwar fejn, fl-aħħar snin, ittieħdu de大iżjonijiet tajba u fejn saru żbalji-tmexxija tal-Unjoni Ewropea u taż-żona euro. Stennejt mistoqsijiet dwar kif l-għaqda Ewropea qed taffettwa għat-tajjeb u għall-ħażin il-ħajja taħjja taħdini li eleġġewna, ħħ fejn hemm x'jinbidel, jinbidel. Minflok, komplejna b'li kien qed isir hawn qabel Mejju. Ftit f'pajjiżi fehmu l-maniġġi dwar min laħaq President ta' Gumssjoni, ta' kumitati, ta' delegazzjonijiet u ma nafx x'aktar. Ftit jimportahom. L-argument favur aktar jew anqas Ewropa jħallu li大-ikeittadini fjakki minn għarfien ta' x'inhu joħloq l-istanar ekonomiku u jġib daqstant nies qiegħda. M'aħniex niddisutu għaliex il-mudell so大jali Ewropew qed jiżżarma u kif nistgħu nibnu politika serja dwar l-immigrazzjoni. Din l-aġenda ġiet ikkapparata mill-estremi politi大i, u mill-hekk imsejħa populisti. Dan hu żball kbir. L-isfidi quddiem i大-ikeittadini Ewropej ma jingħelbux bid-diskorsi teknokratii li nisimgħu, qisna sirna funzjonarji tal-Fond Monetarju Internazzjonali. L-isfidi jingħelbu wara li jkun sar diskors politiku bla kantunieri, bejn rapprezentanti tal-popli Ewropej, inkluż li nids discutu mill-qiegħ l-istrutturi politi大i li bnew ta' qabilna jekk mhumiex iservu tajjeb flower-Ewropej.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR). -
text: Mr. President! First of all, I greet the last Europeans in this Chamber. Commission President Juncker has said that he wants to boost private initiative by intelligently bringing in public money. I wonder: where does he get the money for it? What is crucial is the intelligent application, i.e. the collection of public money. Should the unused waste from various EU pots be scraped together? Not much would come together!  Juncker could try to ask Member States to increase the European Investment Bank's equity capital – then it could become more indebted. One can only warn against this! If the planned investments are deemed to be unproductive, the bank loses its AAA rating. Should the free resources of the European stability mechanism be tapped? That would be a breach of the Treaty! This will take my party, the Alternative for Germany, to the Federal Constitutional Court. So where does Juncker take the money from? I wish him the best of luck in intelligently raising the resources he needs for his programme!

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE). -
text: Mr. President, the integration of the six Countries of the Western Balkans is of course the interest of these countries, but also the interest of the European Union. These are countries that are geographically located within the European Union and border the five Member States of the European Union. However, these countries have a very large number of peoples who live in multiple countries and are very interconnected. In order for this integration, which is therefore in the interest of both the European Union and those countries, to be successful, a plan should be made for a holistic approach to the integration of these countries into the European Union in order to ultimately gain an area of stability, peace and prosperity after this quality integration, which I repeat is also the interest of these countries, but also of other members of the European Union.

name: Senra Rodríguez Lidia (GUE/NGL). -
text: Lantero workers and workers in Vilagarcia de Arousa have been on strike for a month. They are on strike because this dutch-based company, which has received European ERDF funds, wants to lay off 32 people and reduce its salary by 30% to another 99. Lantero is taking action to frighten its workers, including hiring a security company that remains in the factory with guards armed with pistols and dogs of a breed considered dangerous. It places people in workers' assemblies and sends guards to the vicinity of the facilities where they are taking place. These actions violate the right to strike recognised in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Also in Galicia there are prison sentences for 4 people for having exercised the right to defend themselves against the violence of capitalism. This Parliament has an obligation to act so that the Spanish authorities do not allow the violation of the right to strike in Lantero and guarantee the right to it in my country, galicia and the Spanish State.

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE). -
text: Mr President, on 3 November a policeman declared in Valencia, in the Spanish State, charged with a lack of aggression against Algerian minors. The minors were unable to testify because they had already been expelled, so it will be difficult for the trial to be held with guarantees. It is one more case of the many reported in the so-called "Foreigner Internment Centers", places of shame, where those who commit the administrative failure not to have their papers in order can be held for up to 60 days. These are illegal prisons where people are stripped of their most basic rights. In the Spanish state there are seven, with 9,000 people in prison, more than six per cell, much worse than in any prison. There are a total of 280 in Europe. There are constant reports of abuse, overcrowding, unsanitary conditions, but Europe does nothing. Is this the Europe of human rights that we presume so much about? Do we want to convince the world of the goodness of our democracy? With such a scourge in our territory, dear colleagues, that is impossible. Detention centres for foreigners must be closed now. They are our shame, the great shame of Europe, and we cannot tolerate it anymore.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD). -
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, every autumn, for several years now, Italy has been mourning some catastrophes, which some people call sudden. These days Liguria is under attack from thunderstorms, defined in the press as "water bombs", which everyone considers responsible for such tragedies. I would say that anti-territory political mines are to blame. In any case, little changes: Italy is at war and almost no one knows, it is at war with the unworthy political class that governs it. The media circus is moved by injuries, damage and deaths, victims of hydrogeological failure. We are not fooled because we have a good memory. Those who pass laws such as the building amnesty, those who allow the ability of speculators devoted to cementing at any cost to be satisfied do not have the right to mourn the lives and communities buried by the waves of mud. I would like Europe to work harder to push the culture of prevention and to nail Italy to its responsibilities. We in the Five Star Movement will certainly work to explore the possibility of opening new infringement proceedings, but I would also like you colleagues to ask the Italians in your groups whether, after their moving and hypocritical statements before the TV, they really have the courage to look in the mirror.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE). -
text: Mr. President, dear colleagues! In my speech, I would like to address you in relation to President Schulz's statement. Following the referendum in Scotland, President Schulz said that in Catalonia, Flanders or South Tyrol, much depends on what is happening in Scotland. If Scotland were to achieve "reasonable" self-determination "under the umbrella of the United Kingdom," it could become "a model that can also contribute to pacification in other regions." Mr President, Mr Schulz, I agree with what you have said, but I would like to draw the attention of all my fellow Members to the fact that, according to you, there is still an imaginary Berlin Wall. In Eastern Europe, too, there are communities for which democratically created autonomy can mean an important advantage. The same applies to my community, namely the Hungarian community in Slovakia. We should not forget that the east of the former Iron Curtain is also home to minorities whose situation is unresolved and whose democratic and legally guaranteed development should be in the interests of European democracies.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D). -
text: Mr President, after the launching of the European Union’s common security and defence policy (CSDP) and its inclusion within the Treaty of Lisbon, some steps have been taken towards endowing that policy with the institutional structures and military instruments necessary to make it an effective mechanism for dealing with insecurity in Europe’s geopolitical neighbourhood. New challenges are emerging which should provide new impetus for the CSDP. Firstly, the complicated security situation in the Middle East, especially in Syria and Iraq, posed by the Islamic State. Secondly, the dangerous situation for Europe’s security and stability posed by separatists and Russia in southern and eastern Ukraine, which constitutes a direct threat to the European Union and NATO countries in eastern and south-eastern Europe. Now is another moment when Europe has to deal with the lack of integration of the military structures of the EU Member States. The participation of the EU Member States in an increased number of CSDP interventions has not resulted in a real harmonisation or deeper integration of military structures or a maximisation of synergies. The EU needs urgently to develop the security and defence instruments available, but unused, under the Lisbon Treaty, and particularly PESCO and the start-up fund. It also needs to galvanise the European defence industry on large collaborative projects and, definitely, the step-by-step integration of the military structures of the Member States, in collaboration with NATO.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR). -
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking I, like my colleague Mrs von Storch, would also like to refer to today's anniversary. President Schulz said that back in 1989 it was about returning to Europe and that it was a victory for the desire for freedom. I would just like to remind you that this was also a desire for prosperity and that it was it that contributed to the fall of communism, an absurd economic system that condemned people to misery. Well, this return to Europe turned out to be different than people thought. Prosperity is, we all know, only for some, and Polish workers from Solidarity did not anticipate that their factories would disappear and not be modernised. People from Central and Eastern Europe continue to vote with their feet and for many 'EXIT' is the most important political option.  The Blühende Landschaften, which Wolf Biermann recently referred to, was unfortunately not created in Central and Eastern Europe, perhaps originating in the former GDR. I would like to remind you of this and link this to the debate on the free movement of persons, migration, social rights. Those who pay attention only to the consequences of immigration to their countries forget about the benefits that their countries have of opening up the market in Central and Eastern Europe and how workers and workers in these countries are treated by their companies, which contribute to their wealth. We should see these two sides of the coin, and I think that this anniversary of the 25th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall should be a cause for deeper reflection.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE). -
text: Mr Back, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to In eastern Ukraine, the threat of a new military confrontation is growing within hours, and Russia is already generating in a second frozen conflict in Ukraine this year after the illegal elections in Donbass on 2 November, Russia did nothing to prevent these elections, but on the contrary it has mascuped them, and now a clear direction has been taken to create a new frozen conflict zone.  In view of the recent reports of the re-deployment of Russian forces along ukraine's borders, including the movement to eastern Ukraine, and also the fact that Ukraine has so far not been allowed to fully control its border, the Foreign Ministers of the Council of the European Union and the European Union should also return as soon as possible to the imposition of new sanctions, i.e. those responsible for conducting these so-called elections in the Donbass region should also come back to the sanctions list. , both from Russia and from the local area. Unfortunately, so far, political efforts have not yielded results, and the Minsk process is likely doomed to failure.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL). -
text: Mr President, so-called welfare reform, welfare cuts, are not about tackling poverty; rather they are an attack on the poor, the disabled and the disadvantaged. In England malnutrition is on the increase and there has been a tenfold increase in those dependent on food banks. People can no longer afford fresh fruit and vegetables but rather are eating junk foods high in saturated fats and sugar.  The already high levels of child poverty in the North of Ireland will be made worse as a result of the Westminster tax and benefit policies. Millions have been wasted on an IT system that is not fit for purpose, and despite all this the British Government, in pursuit of its failed policies, is financially penalising the Northern Executive. Just as the Troika and austerity have affected the most vulnerable in the South of Ireland, in Spain, Portugal and Greece, British Government Tory cuts are adversely affecting the most vulnerable in the North of Ireland.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Greece is one step ahead of the end of the support programme and, despite the successful stress-test of the banks, liquidity for small and medium-sized enterprises has not yet been restored. We therefore need to help everyone here to have an urgent injection of liquidity. The new financial framework enables companies to finance investments and take out loans at a reduced interest rate and through the Structural Funds. But what about those small and medium-sized enterprises that are healthy but have liquidity problems and difficulties in repaying the old loans they received during the crisis at high interest rates? Mr President, this legislation does not allow existing loans to be refinanced by the new financial instruments. I believe that the new treaties require exceptional action and that is why I call on the Commission to take a legislative initiative to improve, to change the existing regulation. It is time to give healthy small and medium-sized enterprises suffering from liquidity an opportunity now that the crisis in Greece seems to be coming to an end.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D). -
text: Mr President, honourable colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Sánchez-Neym. In the context of the parliamentary elections in Ukraine, I would like to draw your attention to one worrying factor.  Turnout in eastern Ukraine was very low, at only 30 to 40%, which is a disregard for regions controlled by separatists and where elections have not taken place at all. In previous years, this figure was between 50 % and 60 %. The people of eastern Ukraine regularly supported former President Yanukovych. Now a large proportion of these people did not take part in the elections.  Colleagues, this low activity is a bad sign. Let us remember how naïve and out-of-sight we Europeans were in Iraq. We were so pleased that this country was finally on the path of democracy, that we did not even notice that a large group of sunnis were excluded from the decision-making process, using the pretext that they had supported Saddam Hussein.  We now see clearly the result of this blindness.  The Sunnis have supported radicals from ISIS, not because they like radical ideology, but because they felt humiliated, marginalised and ignored. Colleagues, we need to listen to what the people of eastern Ukraine think, what they want. It is time to learn from our own mistakes.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR) -
text: On 17 November, we not only commemorate the day of the struggle for freedom, but also this day belongs to premature babies in the world. To those who are with us, but also those who were too fragile and had to leave us. Every year, up to 15 million babies are born prematurely in the world, more than a million of whom do not live to see their first birthdays. This means that up to one in ten children come into the world weighing less than 2,500 grams, and many times it also moves below the limit of 1000 grams. Premature babies are exposed to many health complications and many will face disability throughout their lives. It is therefore essential to improve the quality of healthcare for women during pregnancy, thus halting the upward trend in premature births. It is also crucial to improve early care for these children in order to improve their quality of life as well as that of their family.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE). -
text: Mr President, Jean Monnet said, from his vision of ending uniformist nationalisms of state, that of 'we do not unsern States, we bring people in'. In Catalonia, several million of these people participated last Sunday in a consultation to free our opinion on the political future of our country, although not in the way we would have wanted, since we did so when the Spanish government had suspended everything that could be suspended. However, Catalan society continues to take the lead in the face of silence, refusal to dialogue and prohibition. Prohibition and threats can never be the solution to a political problem, a problem that directly affects democracy within the European Union. Unfortunately, the time when the Catalan question may have an internal solution is running out if it has not already been exhausted. Now more than ever, it is time to sit down and talk, listen and reach agreements that allow the cry of Catalans who ask to be consulted on their political future. You cannot prevent someone from feeling European and Catalan, you cannot ask for uniformity in diversity, nor can you prevent the diverse from being different.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D). -
text: Mr. President, gender equality in European politics has so far largely rested on party quotas of social democratic options. I want quotas to stop being a topic and for women to take high places on lists because they deserve it and because their merits are recognized.  Croatia is in a debate on changes to electoral legislation that would introduce 40% gender quotas on party lists. Parties that do not comply with the quotas will be disqualified from the election contest.  Countries where women participate equally in all spheres of society have been shown to be more prosperable and successful. The quota is only the first step that will lead to positive change, but I also advocate additional mechanisms that will ensure the uniform distribution of women on the list. We need to stop pretending that women do not want or are incapable of influencing decision-making processes and become aware of the fact that rapid and effective mechanisms must be put in place to engage them equally in society.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE). -
text: Mr President, I rise to condemn the outgoing Commission for raiding the emergency fund for agriculture to create a crisis reserve and thus taking 433 million out of direct payments to farmers which equates to 1.3% across the board. I order the new Commission to reverse this act of sabotage with all possible haste, in line with the request of the Ministers for Agriculture to their Ecofin counterparts and also a cross-party letter signed by Members Dess, De Castro, Nicholson and Rohde. This is coming at the worst possible time for farmers, as morale is low due to the Russian embargo, milk prices being in free fall and, in my own country, a differential in beef prices of EUR 350 between similar cattle in Ireland and the United Kingdom, leading to an embargo in the last few weeks to protest at various stipulations such as age restrictions, movement restrictions and a grading system that even Einstein could not understand! So I order the new Commission to look at these issues.

name: Neena Gill (S&D). -
text: Mr President, I welcome yesterday’s European Court of Justice ruling clarifying the right of Member States to deny social benefits to migrants not actively looking for a job. This underscores the complete baselessness of the claim that our national welfare systems are under attack from EU labour mobility. It makes clear that the national governments have the necessary tools in hand to address any possible negative effects that are brought about by intra-EU freedom of movement.  Whatever some on the Right may contend, economic policy is too important for us to allow it to be based on phantom stories created by populist parties out of electoral interest. It needs to be based on facts and figures. It is a fact that European immigrants to the UK have made a net fiscal contribution of GBP 20 billion to our economy in the past decade. It is also a fact that migrants from the original 15 Member States contributed a staggering 64% more in taxes than they received. The more recent migrants – often vilified in our press – handed over more than 12% more than they received.  It is also a fact that migrant entrepreneurs are helping to create jobs. A recent study shows that migrants founded one in every seven UK companies, with fellow EU Member States figuring among the top 10 countries of origin of these entrepreneurs. So the free movement of workers is not only a fundamental right, but also a fundamental blessing to our economies. It would be in the strongest interest of all of us if we finally started to acknowledge this important truth.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE) -
text: November 17th is the same symbol for the Czech and Slovak peoples as the fall of the Berlin Wall for Germany. Twenty-five years ago, our peoples returned to Europe. A united Europe stands by the defeat of Nazism and Communism. It would be a threat to Europe if we did not recall Nazism and its crimes. However, it is also threatened by ignoring the crimes of communism. Communism was defeated by the courage of men and women who believed in freedom and human dignity. The gate to November 89 was opened by thousands of activists of the Underground Church and a candle demonstration in Bratislava the year before. I would also like to recall two great figures whose support for us at the time meant a great deal: Pope John Paul II and President Ronald Reagan. In the end, law prevailed over injustice. Freedom over totalitarianism. And I am very happy to recall this as a Member of the Citizens of the Slovak Republic here in the European Parliament.
